Overall, I'd pass because while the cocktails are good, the food is mediocre at best.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Two of the servers I encountered during my experience here are the rudest human beings to grace the streets of San Francisco.  

The drinks were great, and I loved the ambiance, but I felt really really badly mistreated here. 

Came here on a Friday night and luckily found a table for our party. The first thing our waiter said to us was "You guys gonna get a drink or what?  Maybe put down your phone so you can read the menu and figure what to order." Holy crap why the attitude man? The three of us were pretty taken aback that he was soooo rude without a single word out of our mouths.  Yeah we didn't know exactly what we wanted the exact second he came but he didn't wait for us to even open the menu while he stood there!  He just made that snarky ass comment and shimmied off with his nose almost touching the ceiling.  Btw he had slicked back grey hair and glasses, and was about middle aged (just so you know to avoid this dude).

So we picked drinks right away, and waited for him to come back to take our order but 5 minutes go by, 10 minutes go by, and we get sick of waiting so I decide to grab drinks from the bar instead.  The bartender was great, no complaints here.  

Then the same waiter dude found us waiting at the bar after already buying our drinks, and all of the sudden became much more polite and said we should order from him instead, and that drinks at the bar take too long to get.  (Even though it literally took me 30 seconds just making eye contact with the bartender).

The other server we had at our table, a waitress with short-ish blonde hair, did the same thing as the other waiter after our large party arrived.  She asked if we'd like more drinks (sans any emotion on her face) and then waited about 15 seconds while the new arrivals scanned the menu and then strutted off without a word.  Wtf dude no one here can give guests at least a minute to make drink decisions?  Just the way she went about it came off really sh*tty and made us all feel like the wait staff didn't want us here at all.  

She came back again in about 10 minutes and did THE SAME THING.  She never took a single drink order, she came twice asking, and both times didn't wait more than 15 seconds before she left rolling her eyes.  

We weren't even being rowdy either, we were just chatting and trying to have a good time, but the servers totally ruined our time here due to their butthole attitudes.  

It was only after we ordered about 10 drinks did the original waiter with the grey hair and glasses start to act like he was a nice human.  (I'm 110% sure he just wanted our tips which is why he didn't want us going to the bar....)

Thanks for the drinks Comstock, but some of your waitstaff seriously need their attitudes checked, I would never come back to drop that much money and be treated like that, that's never ok in my book.
author: Christina L.

description: One of my favorite places in SF. Excellent and creative cocktails. And some of the best bar sbacks on the planet. Try the Greenbrier cocktail and the fried Brussels sprouts.
author: Philip S.

description:
I really enjoyed our long visit here. The drinks were perfectly balanced and complex. We ordered quite a few of the cocktails and spent some time soaking up the scene before ordering food. Our group can never all be on time so its fun to people watch. The crowd at Comstock seemed to all be having fun. The bartenders looked happy but some of the waiters looked annoyed with, well...everything. Cheer up guys! You work in a really cool place.
 The food was delicious (OK, I was four sheets to the wind) especially the duck sausage. Good wings also. The salad was a bit small but very fresh and full of flavor. 
 The ambiance and decor are spot on for an old style bar in SF. Despite my hurting brain     (Devils leap indeed) and lightly punished credit card, I'm very glad to have spent my Friday evening there. Keep it up Comstock and see you again soon.
author: Steve M.

description:
Just stopped by for a quick drink while waiting for a table down the street. There are two bars, a dark long wood bar with a tiled trough at the foot - hearkening back to those Barbary Coast days when the bar was men only and they could just piss while drinking at the bar - and a brighter white tiled bar with small tables around the room to sit at. I prefer the brighter bar but it's worth walking through the other one to check out the trough and a piece of history.

The bartenders are friendly and get the drinks out fairly quick. No pretentiousness. I only had the cherry bounce but it was a lovely aperitif - light, easy to drink but also serious though it included champagne. Good cherries too. Different than the ubiquitous luxuardo cherries.

Full but not too crowded. Made it a very pleasant and fast 30 minutes.
author: Jean K.

description:
This place is my go to wildcard for drinks in the area,  classy drinks but not button up. Bartenders able and willing to sling deadly drinks, and the drinks are strong enough to grow hair on your chest and knock you on your butt.

Most recent two times both produced similar results, intoxication.  They have nice cocktails that change with seasons with absinthe in it, yes it does not contain wormwood but who wants to start tripping after 9-10 too many drinks (you see enough weird shit sometimes without stepping out of the bar).  Besides the carefully measured and mixed cocktails, they are more than willing to throw down some 4 Roses Bourbon in boot shaped shot glasses. 

And if you are in classic 2 note cocktails like jack and coke, or Anchor Steam they got that too.  This place gets packed on the weekends, as they should because this places is great for small group of friends to knock back 4-12? drinks
author: Tom Y.

description: This place is a delight. Every time I've visited this unique bar I've enjoyed delicious cocktails in a beautiful saloon, served by knowledgable, friendly and attentive staff. Great cocktail bar!
author: Colin A.

description: Ordered apple pie to share without stating that sharing would be involved. Server provided 4 forks. Apple pie was more of an empanada. Napkins are huge.
author: leo b.

description: Love this place!!! Old fashion was amazing, love music, great service. We will be back again!
author: Rhita B.

description: According to the sign, soup of the day is whiskey. Funny. Not funny? $21 Laphroaig 10. That is the highest I've ever seen it in SF.
author: Alison A.

description:
We came in pretty late around 11:30 on a Saturday night and it wasn't crowded at all. 
The waitress was visibly not interested in providing a good service. 
Drinks were just OK.
author: Rohini A.

description:
The staff is well educated.
The glass ware is exceptional
The decor is lovely

So why only 3 stars?  Because the drinks were OK, but only just.
author: Libby R.

description:
I can't attest for the alcohol here because the day I came here, I just did not feel like drinking the day I was here. However, it is a neat saloon. Not many places to sit and it's funny because there are two entrances to this place, and the staff go outside and then come back inside to go between rooms, even though they're connected. 

The lemonade I had was very lemon-y, I'll say. I also had half a burger here and it was a bit salty. Very solid and hearty though. Staff was great though and there was even a band playing. I'll have to come back at some point to have a drink here to have a proper review. Only 3 stars for not that much seating and ok food.
author: Julie L.

description: Nice little cocktail bar in the financial district. Josh makes a hell of a side car, which is uncommon these days.
author: Steve J.

description: Excellent mixology cocktails. Great ambiance and location. Perfect for a pre-dinner and/or post-dinner drink if you're in North Beach!
author: Jaching H.

description: Great place! Love the bourbon pudding. Love the ambience. Super nice waiter. Would definitely go back and try the dinner.
author: Shengyin G.

description:
Nice atmosphere, delicious drinks, and reasonable prices. Live music as well. The old fashioned and Manhattan are good. 
Manager, bartenders and wait staff were all very friendly and accommodating for our large party
author: Jones T.

description: Coming from seattle, was really excited to try this place. Went with party of four, and had four of the worst cocktails we have ever had. The manhattan, sazerac, martinez, some classic whisky elixir that my friend has already erased from his memory. Drinks were all unbalanced. Seemed like a drink from the worst college bar you have been. Even that worst college bar you have been to would have had better drink proportions. Wondering if they were training a bartender on a friday night? This was a huge let down. Really expected some quality craft cocktails. Real shame because the staff was nice. The star goes to ambiance but thats it. If you want a tourist trap, go here. It is near downtown. If you know cocktails, go elsewhere. Mission district had some excellent places.
author: John B.

description: This plays itself as a cocktail bar, but the only thing worth writing about is the physical bar. The bar is classic and lovely and so well restored but the wood alone can't satisfy my thirst. The cocktail I ordered was very off-balance. I had a Manhattan that was so sweet it was as if the ratios on the drink were confused, a mistake for whatever the cause. It's not often that I leave a drink on the table but I had to walk away from the drink, leaving it behind in my pursuit for a real cocktail elsewhere in the city.
author: Diana B.

description: Michael the bartender is a great dude and his cocktails are basic yet legit. Try his sazerac
author: Tyler M.

description: I took my girl to this establishment as a Valentine's gift. We reserved a table, and were seated right away by the hostess. The hostess would be the primary person serving us for that night. Our cocktails for night were Manhattans, and Blood and Sands. The drinks were nearly perfect, the right amount of alcohol, so it didn't feel like we were getting immediately drunk at first sip. We had three each because it was our night out. The "actual" waiter didn't come around till half time we were there. It was mainly the hostess who served us in the beginning. The place is a bit noisy, and the seating was not as intimate as I would've liked. We ordered the oysters, and they were okay. I would've rather had normal size oysters instead of the tiny one we were served. My meal was mostly satisfactory, a bit too fried, and the batter didn't agree with my stomach. Despite the food, it's a good place to get an old fashioned cocktail, and the building itself is a historical monument.
author: Joel G.

description: Literally walked in the door and someone named Katie (Katy?) and a manager named JB met me and greeted me with smiles.  Then Ashley the bartender was so kind and recommended asparagus.  This place has the type of kindness I look for in a restaurant and bar.  Definitely recommend coming here! The attitude is outstanding!
author: Thomas W.

description:
Finally came in here a month or so ago after having it on my bookmarks for ages.

I came in on a soggy Friday afternoon during all the storms in December. My LBC buddy came in tow and we proceeded to get some drinks after a wet but custom tour of the city provided by yours truly.

I believe I got a couple of Old Fashions and they were spot on. The atmosphere was old fashiony (which seemed appropriate) with fans moved by mechanical pulleys.

My only gripe was that there a big group of tech bros that came in and seemed to be regulars. I really hope that's not the case cause I'd be more hesitant to come back.

But overall a good "newer" addition to the bar scene up here.
author: Art O.

description: My group had two negative experiences here in one night. First I ordered a drink and they brought me a completely different drink and charged me for it telling me that they don't make the type of drink I asked for because it takes too long so they simply gave me something else instead of giving me the option to select another beverage. I asked about this to see if I could have it taken off of the bill they lied and said they had taken it off and then still tried to charge us for it. Then when someone else in our party left their jacket and we called to see if it was there they were extremely rude and dismissive on the phone and offered no help and told us it wasn't there when she returned herself she was able to find the jacket which makes us think they didn't even take the time to take a quick look around.
author: Grace H.

description: Came here on a weekend trip with some friends and let me tell you it was the best place! Live jazz, great drinks, good food and amazing service! Will be back soon!
author: Christian A.

description: I loved Comstock, but went last night after not having been for a few months (I have been going for 2 years) and was very disappointed with the way I was treated. Granted my friend and I stayed until closing catching up, not only were we overcharged but the staff was SO rude to us. They reluctantly took off money from our bill which was nice but they made us feel like we were drunk fools, when we had been having such a great time catching up! I felt sad because this was a spot I took friends and family, but with how rude the bartender and manager were I don't think I will be going back. The manager even went as far as to ask me if I wanted to have him sit down so I could have a "therapy session", and I said no thank you, but that I wanted them to know as a regular this type of treatment was disheartening. I won't be going back, will have to find a new local spot where the people are nicer!
author: Taylor M.

description:
The drinks are great and the service is wonderful. I came here with my coworkers for a team happy hour and we had a great time. Despite our large group size, they accommodated us to the best of their abilities by reserving us a sitting area in the back. 

While we didn't try the food, the drinks are quite strong, and so good (I love the Southside, which is a minty and very refreshing drink!). The Happy Hour menu also offers a great selection. For a forgettably wonderful time, try the boot to the head (it's a mini boot/shot of bourbon and anchor steam)!
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Very nice bar. Great drink selection and awesome jazz music during weekday night. 

I highly recommend their specialty drink Cherry Bounce as the first drink to try. Very smooth. 

The bar tenders are on top of their game and really care about what they make.  They also have a great selection of whiskey and bourbon.
author: Xing M.

description: John, the bartender, has an amazing passion for his craft. His creativity and energy was so evident. I have 5 restaurants on the east coast and would love to have bartenders like him.
author: Robert K.

description: Came here after work for a quick drink with some friends and I would have to say this place is not bad.  It had a wide selection of food but I didn't get a chance to try it as we only stoped by for drinks.  We all had the $7 Four Roses and short Anchor Happy Hour special.  What a deal!! Will be back to try the food and explore their house crafted cocktails soon.
author: Jon L.

description: There's something indescribable about Comstock that just draws you in once you step foot into the place. The bartenders are friendly and it's fun to watch them make drinks that are seriously out of this world.  Best cocktails I've ever had!
author: Michael V.

description:
Comstock Saloon is super cool! It's huge with plenty of seating and a good Western vibe, from the decor to the music. The bartenders are friendly, and it's fun to watch them make drinks that are seriously out of this world. The popular "must-drink" thing to order is the Sazerac ($9) which has rye, sugar, Peychaud's, and absinthe. Tell me something has absinthe and I'm game.

I also love their boot-shaped shot glasses. So cute! This is definitely not your ordinary bar. There's something indescribable about Comstock that just draws you in once you step foot into the place. Grab your friends, and stop by for some strong drinks and a good time!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
For a place more known for classic cocktails, the bartenders are pretty versatile.  I got the Barkeep's Whimsy and asked the bartender for rye, citrus, tartness, and he created something pretty good with rye, lemon, mint, campari, and angostura bitters.  

I tried some of the other cocktails friends ordered, and the Pisco sour from the menu was nice and light, but nothing else blew me away.

It is nice that they have some booths there, and there are two bathrooms, both of which were clean.  On the other hand, I wouldn't make this a craft cocktail destination.
author: Marilyn H.

description: Wonderful place for drinks or dinner. I love the Friday free lunch. So much fun of you have the time. The Cherry Bounce is a fantastic cocktail. Easy to make a reservation.
author: Wendy C.

description:
This place is really outstanding. Upscale drinks, nice funky old place with a good atmosphere.

We came here because they also serve food. We wanted a drink and an appetizer. We didn't know it at first but there's two entrances. We came in on the tiled side. Small bar, nice sized kitchen and a few areas to sit. We found a nice place in the corner. Nice long booth with small table and a couple of bar seats. Loved it.

Service was good. The drinks are different but in a good way. I ordered the Cherry Bounce and was very pleasantly surprised. The BF ordered a different bourbon based drink and enjoyed it.

We also ordered the Brussels Sprouts which were very good. They had a mustard vinaigrette which really made it tasty goodness.

Watching the bartender was amazing. You could tell he really cared about what he was making. Stirring and stirring, tasting, adding and stirring some more before shaking the shit out of the drink and pouring for the waiting customer in different glasses depending on the drink. Every drink I saw him make was beautiful and although they took awhile, watching a master do his thing is great.

The only thing I didn't care for was the music. I am not a fan of Kenny Rogers and wanted to leave. I know that is so nit-picky; but I would come back and try their food. The scallops looked so good!
author: Sandra R.

description: I started coming to Comstock because I have a super crush on one of the bartenders.... But the place kept me coming back! When I first walked in, I thought it was just another fancy cocktail place that I wouldn't feel comfortable in but boy was I wrong! I've gone by myself on more than one occasion and have made new friends just from the people sitting around me. There's a good mix of regular customers and people new to the area. It's the only bar I go to in North Beach/Chinatown because it's a nice change from the crazy college type bars that I normally go to with college friends- and I feel super comfortable. The staff is friendly and remember your face when you come back. I've trusted the bartenders to make whatever they feel I would like, and I've yet to be disappointed. Lots of character in the set up, music, and even in the attire of the staff. Love it all!
author: Shannon C.

description: Great food, friendly staff, awesome drinks, amazing ambiance. What more could you ask for?
author: Stephanie L.

description:
You're not normal if you don't like the Comstock. I've lived here my whole life and the history here is just too cool. The drinks are pretty damn amazing! They can make you the old classics and some new innovative stuff too. And I don't know their name but the jazz band I heard when I was there, was KILLING IT! Like it was absolutely spectacular. I wish I knew their name. 

The drinks here are a bit pricey and this is not ordinary bar. This is a great place to come on your birthday or for a slightly special occasion.
author: Kevin D.

description:
After living in NYC for 7 years, my standards for cocktail bars are pretty high and this is the only place in SF that I've visited more than once.

Inventive cocktails. Prompt and knowledgeable servers. Big enough to always get a table but cozy enough to not feel like you're in an Applebee's. 

Definitely the best casual cocktail bar in SF.
author: Mimia J.

description: I enjoyed the food, the oysters were good.  I was disappointed with my overall experience however.  I had made a reservation in advance on open table hoping to listen to some jazz during dinner - I had read that they often have live bands play there.  They do, but my date and I were seated in the noisy bar area rather than in the nicer room where the music was being played.  I wish I had been told when booking my reservation what room we would be placed in.  In the bar the service was kind of meh - the staff seemed surprised we were getting dinner and we had various people serving us rather than just one person.  I could barely hear my date.  To their credit they offered us a table in the other room when I asked to move, but it was right next to the door on a cold night.  I'll head elsewhere next time.  Transparency with reservations is important to me - I like to know what I am going to get.
author: Max B.

description:
Sigh .......  I always feel it necessary to give credit where it is due.  But the converse of that is that some places just drop the ball, and its my solemn duty to expose these incompetents wherever they are hiding, waiting to take your money you leave offended, inconvenienced, unsatisfied and angry.   

That is what happened at Comstock.  If you want to be treated rudely, sit in a room with gloomy lighting, uncomfortable wooden benches, and wait 25 minutes for your cocktail which is average tasting, and small, then by all means; Go To Comstock.  Because that is what you will get.

Our female server (attn: Comstock Owner/Mgmt:  We were there on Friday night, about 10pm, served by an under 30 white chik with straight blonde hair pulled back in a pony tail) was SO rude, short with us, flippant and inconvenienced by our burdening patronage, that we almost felt guilty trying to be their customer.  And at the end of our 1 cocktail, we had to wait another 45 minutes to get a bill, which she refused to bring us even after literally following her around ON FOOT asking for it in person.  She was actually having a tantrum and refusing to get us a tab because, she must have known, there would NOT be a tip in it for her.  So we eventually said this to the bartender:

"Sir, we are REALLY trying not to walk out on our bill.  And we have been asking for a check for 45 minutes.  Your server is not getting it to us and refuses to even speak to us now.  Can you please give us the bill for our 3 drinks so we can just leave?"   He did. We paid.  No tip.  Adios.  Won't be back.

I highly suggest you go to any of the countless other bars within 100 yards of this place before going there.  Even if she had been awesome, the whole place is just depressing and dark, has no character.  The only cool thing about that place is their clever belt driven ceiling fan, which you will spend the entire night staring at as you wait for service.

Tootles
author: Paul R.

description:
Five stars for when my favorite bartender is working, and three stars for the rest of the time. 

This place, in general, seems a bit pretentious. I was generally not treated very nicely and have once encountered incredibly rude service. But the food is decent and the drinks are strong and taste good. 

What I love about this place is my favorite bartender James, who makes me the best drinks I could find in San Francisco. Sure, I might be paying a few more dollars than I would elsewhere, but I have always felt that the drinks James make are worth every penny. Perfect balance of alcohol content, taste, and sophistication. He is always able to make something that I love, every time, without fail. 

So in conclusion, I'm not completely sure how I feel about this place overall, but I come here almost every week for a few phenomenal drinks, and that's good enough for me.
author: Angelina M.

description:
Comstock deserves props simply for being one of the few places around that still offers live music.  From talking to the management, I got the impression this is something they strongly believe in regardless of whether it actually benefits their bottom line.  And some of the groups who play there have been doing so continuously for many years, which also says something good about the culture of this institution.

The staff is great, the cocktails are great, the food is pretty good and sometimes excellent.  It's a unique vibe in a prime location.  Sitting at the bar in the room with the big windows that face up Columbus street, sipping a Sazerac, listening to live jazz, just feels like a quintessential San Francisco experience.
author: Adan S.

description: Cherry Bounce: Bourbon, cherry brandy, lemon, Angostura, Champagne ($11). Mixed alcohol + delicious = dangerous but good.
author: Christine C.

description:
This was not my scene...

SF is stocked with old-tyme hipster joints, speak-easy types, and vintage saloons.  I am not sure about this trend...and I say trend because regular bars and modern decor will come back soon.  Stupid hipsters.  You are NOT cool, edgy, or anything but a cliche of a cliche.

The bartender thought she was something else, and carried on a very rude side conversation with a "regular"  (aka pathetic creepy old guy) while she took drink orders and tried in vain to actually be a bartender. 

The foo-foo drinks were not impressive.  I ordered a beer, big deal I guess.  

The people were a mixed bag of douchey hipster types in vintage clothes with facial hair and tattoos.  I doubt anyone had showered in about a week.  I'm also pretty sure some of the chicks had more armpit hair that I do.  This whole au natural thing ain't my bag baby...take a shower...shave and be a lady. Oh, and what in god's name is this obsession with high-rise shovel-butt pants?? Dear god...I blame Miley...and this needs to stop.  END SHOVEL BUTT NOW!

Not impressed.  Not at all...was glad to leave.
author: Scott Z.

description:
More proof that SF has more character than just about any city I know.  Go here to be transported back to the turn of the century (20th century, that is) when bars were saloons and bartenders had mustaches that curled up to a fine point.  They are, to a man (and woman), characters who nonetheless know their way around a cocktail.  Pick from the list, ask for your own or let them pick for you at their whimsy -- they won't disappoint.  I can't quite say the same thing about the menu filled with old timey (?) delights like liver or bone marrow.  Just like grandma would eat, I suppose.  About the only thing I'd be up for trying are the sliders.  

Still, I'll be back, ready for more good old fashioned fun.
author: Seth E.

description:
I had wanted to try this spot for a while, so was really happy on Saturday when I finally got a chance. The decor is impeccable and really transports you back to another time. Has kind of a speakeasy, prohibition vibe going which I adored. The service was incredible, attentive and responsive.

What was most disappointing was the actual food! I ordered the pickle platter which is basically a plate where everything on it has been pickled. The only thing I enjoyed was the pickle. Lets just say grapes and pears should never be pickled, ever. Also ordered the bucket of shrimp. For $15, I was really disappointed to only receive 6 shrimp in a huge bucket with a ton of ice. The menu should have more accurate descriptions so that customers know what they are getting. I would have never ordered that if I would have known.
author: Christine E.

description:
Our waiter was foo foo in the best way. Happy hour cocktails are strong but good. According to our waiter, all their cocktails have the same alcohol content...Joke or not, I don't know. 

Overall, a charming spot. The live music was a pleasant surprise.
author: Val K.

description: Rude staff, mediocre food. Good cocktails, but the feeling of "burdening" the waitstaff doesn't make me want to give this place a second chance.
author: Mel L.

description: Stopped in before dinner for some bevies. Thoroughly enjoyed the rye Sazerac skillfully concocted. Will be back. Thanks @lizfiandaca and @AndrewSweet for the intro.
author: Massimo F.

description: I don't get to just relax much between the three big projects that I have going, but I am so glad my friend Dasha pick this place. The staff was very attentive, and although the menu was limited the selection had something for everyone. There was beef, seafood, poultry, or vegetarian. We had several drinks, the shrimp in the bucket,  and the burgers and just provided the instructions for the chef to make it however he wants. It was delicious. The noise level is high, but it was due to a lively Wednesday evening. For a good mix of chill and lively, with a well balance attentiveness of good customer service this place is a "can't wait to go back."
author: Matthew R.

description:
Since there's been such good reviews we were expecting an overall great experience.

The food is delicious, the drinks are presented well, but average for cocktails in the city. This review is for the service. 

Sarah L was our server, and unfortunately was probably having a very bad day. She kept taking the menus away from us (because they have a shortage), but we couldn't look at the drinks or discuss what was worth getting because she literally kept taking the menus away every chance she got. I asked three times (three!) and she said only when we were ready to order we could have them. A solution might be for every table give one menu, instead of taking three away every time? 

We decided to just take photos of the menus but it still took ten minutes to even get the menu so we could take a photo. She completely forgot about an appetizer, never brought it up, gave us the check without us asking if we were finished, and also took the food menus away from us while we were eating our appetizers (before we had ordered our main courses). 

We were here for a birthday dinner and honestly the hostility was just so much it really impacted us. The food was all good but our service really affected us. Perhaps we'll go again if we're in the area but we definitely won't go back for dinner.
author: Mary N.

description:
Live music (piano, stand-up bass...) played from the upper mezzanine, sleekly groomed staff, beautiful place from another era... It's clearly the kind of place where you can unwind and get carried away by the ambiance easily. I'd go there for either an after work drink, a late night cocktail or for a date.

The food didn't make an impact on me but I would give it another go, I was paying more attention to what was in my drink and around than my plate.

Also, I went there with someone who doesn't drink alcohol. The barman once aware of it spontaneously suggested some "virgin" cocktails recipes based on my friend's taste after asking for a few hints. They were tasty, unexpected and made with as much attention to detail and passion than for an alcoholic cocktail. I think this is both respectful and professional.
author: Olivia M.

description:
7x7 100 Things to Eat in SF Before You Die

#81 Pickled Eggs at Comstock Saloon 

You have to order the Hangtown Toast: pickled eggs, oyster dressing, bacon, slaw, if you want to try the eggs.

I'll be honest, it was disappointing. Bacon was the thin limp kind and served a little too crispy for my liking. As for the slaw, it was tart and seasoned well which complimented the egg but again nothing special. 

On to the main attraction, the egg. Ummmm yeah, I did not get it. Tasted like any other hard boiled egg minus the pickled flavor. I am so confused as to what qualifies to be on 7x7's list. I clearly am not on the same page or really missing something. 

Drinks on the other hand were good but expensive. 2 drinks and 1 app I walked out spending close to $40

Overall Thoughts

I know for certain I won't be back for the pickled egg!
author: Eddie W.

description: Wanted to stop in after seeing this place on Americas best bars. Great mixed drink menu, ( a little pricy ). Try the home made chips!
author: Sean D.

description: A great place for a high quality drink and delicious food on a Saturday night.  Service was excellent: friendly, fast, and helpful.  Decent whiskey selection with a good range of ages and prices.  Had the sausage, elote, and fries.  Sausage was pretty high quality; better than I expected from a bar.  Elote was tasty and nicely spicy.  Fries were fries.  Hard to go wrong with that.  Definitely would frequent again largely because the service was top notch and place had a good vibe.
author: Nate B.

description:
The actual drinks were great but it took about 15 minutes to order because the bartender was flirting with half the bar....it was actually the WORST experience I've ever had in a bar and I live in NYC. 

I would of ordered a second round but I figured 45 minutes to order and have the drink made wasn't worth it.
author: Lauren B.

description: I'm so glad we found this place! We came here for drinks and apps during fleet week and were surprised by how good it was! They have very unique and strong cocktails and a small app menu that has great options. They also have a raw bar which looked pretty good, but a little pricey.. We ended up just having cocktails and the BBQ chips and Shishito pepper appetizers. Those were both delicious and definitely recommended. I'm hoping to try the dinner here sometime soon.
author: Harmony H.

description:
Really nice hipster bar with live music on Monday, which was interesting.  Almost as interesting as, you know, my life decisions to come to a bar on a Monday.  

They have the standard selection of $9-and-up cocktails, and a wide selection of bottled beer, ranging from $5 to $26 (dang).  Their wine menu also spans several pages of their hip, leather-bound drink menus.   I got the Black Butte Porter, which the bartender poured for me so I didn't have to embarass myself, which was nice.   Their draft beer selection is only two beers though, which surprised me.   What's a gastropub without a decent selection of pitchers to split?

My friend and I also ordered the bacon-infused potato fritters, which was yet-another name for mashed potato bites that seem to be growing enormously in popularity.  These were pretty tasty though; served piping hot with a dipping sauce that I can't quite remember anything about other than that it was good.  I'm sure the other menu items are just as tasty and freshly prepped, though.

Ambiance is clean, quiet, and dark.  They also have a line of slow-moving windmill-looking things on top keeping air circulation going as well as giving it a speakeasyish feel.  The dapper bartenders also serve to further this theme as well.  Great place for a quick drink or a intimate date.  

--

sweet: very nice ambiance, well-dressed and attentive staff 
bitter: SF prices, limited draft beer selection
author: Mike P.

description:
With so many great bars in San Francisco, I felt the need to choose Comstock as the first one I went to for cocktails.

Maybe it was due to the fact it was a block away from where I was getting dinner, but lets not try take that away from the situation. This was the first cocktail bar I ventured into on my travels out there and I'm glad I did. 

I had two cocktails. The first was the Blood and Sand, which is scotch, sweet vermouth, orange and cherry liqueur. The second was the Moonraker, made up on cognac, sutton's quinquina, peach, absinthe. 

The Blood and Sand was solid, a bit on the dry side, it wasn't as sweet as I imagined it going to be. The moonraker was really good. Served in a coupe glass, it was a nice way to start the night, that I had already started at happy hour a few hours before and continued with a six pack while getting ready. 

The food looked good, but unfortunately I did not stop to get any. I can safely say, this spot will do the job for your cocktail needs.
author: Mitch E.

description:
Bottom Line: Comstock Saloon is a solid spot for a good cocktail in the city.

The bridal party came here after the dress rehearsal to imbibe in a few drinks before heading off to the subsequent rehearsal dinner at Quince. Since I only had a drink, I can only really judge Comstock on the their beverage craftsmanship. Still, with that one drink I feel like I was able to sip on the essence that encompasses this bar: sophisticated, smooth and skilled. That on top of the friendly and knowledgeable service is all I needed to know.

I knew I had to have their Cherry Bounce cocktail as it all the ingredients I love most in it: bourbon, cherry brandy, lemon, Angostura bitters and champagne. It was love at first sip!

Loved the decor with its very old wallpaper and furnishings. Very handcrafted woodsy feel. You know, when furniture was made by hand and not by machine and sold in IKEA. I think they were trying to evoke SF circa 1906 before the earthquake ripped the town a new one.
author: Leslie D.

description:
Their 'Free Lunch' deal is one of the best kept secrets in San Francisco. Buy two adult beverages ($4-$12), get a free lunch. Available only on Fridays. I've been trying to make my way over to it for a year or so now, and it was everything I wanted it to be.

They don't mention what the special is, you just order it. On this particular occasion, the free lunch was a pretty damn gourmet chili dog with potato chips. 

Sure, you could do it on the real cheap and buy a subpar beer, but if you're going to Comstock Saloon you should order a damn cocktail. Let' not be mooches here, eh?

I recommend the Hemingway Daiquiri. Delicious & refreshing (Because you're drinking between noon and 3, right?). 

I am definitely bringing any out-of-town guests here as soon as I get the opportunity. Way to make day-drinking a classy affair, Comstock.
author: Katie S.

description: This review is only for the experience I had with our dinner reservation and table. (My other experiences in the bar have been wonderful!)  We had reservations for 6:15 and arrived at 6:15. Though there were other tables, also marked 'reserved' we were seated at the one closest to the door. You sit partially in the doorway, the wind factor is horrible, you're bumping up to the handicap door opener sign, and my chair was bumped into twice because the table juts out into the doorway. I'm not sure why it's necessary to have a table there - for an extra 2 seats. Though the other tables had 'reserved' on them, they were vacant for more than an hour. It was really an unfortunate experience and one I don't plan on reliving. I'll definitely be going elsewhere for dinner.
author: Sheryl F.

description:
How many times do I have to say I've lived in San Francisco since 1984 and am a stickler for classic customer service?

The burger was too good to have shared with a visitor. Really good bar burger! Tasty and delicate and quallity. That pickled egg was tasty and the waiter, charming.  I'll be back for the two drinks with a free meal lunch deal
author: SF T.

description: Came here for a bite and some drinks.  Place is nice with two rooms and was busy.  We had the Roasted chicken which was good.  Tried the Blood & Sands cocktail and was good as well.   Will have to come back and try some other items in their menu.
author: John B.

description: This place is ultra cozy and has an attractive interior. There are fans on the ceiling, reminiscent of plantation fans. Right as you enter, you notice the upstairs balcony with a live band playing. The band changes throughout the night, and each band has its own unique theme. The dinner menu is a bit limited and almost boring. Everyone in our group ended up ordering burgers, which weren't bad. This place is more of an after-dinner drink place. John, our server, was very chill and super fun. And there seems to be a nice selection of cocktails available.
author: Kimberly H.

description: We walked in at happy hour, got seats at the bar, had the "scofflaw," the featured bourbon-based beverage for $7 and enjoyed a delicious hamburger with fries.  Scofflaws went down so easily that we needed more.  Looking forward to returning.
author: Myles L.

description:
Featured on The Layover with Tony Bourdain
#81 on the 2011 7x7 List: Pickled egg and a Manhattan

Comstock was one of our happier discoveries on the 7x7 100 Big Eat list this year.

The happy find wasn't the pickled egg inside the Hangtown Toast ($6).  The happy find was the Manhattan ($9).

-Tasty?  The pickled egg you can tell is pickled only if you eat it by itself, but if you eat it the way the Hangtown Toast intended, which is one strip of crispy bacon with a slice of egg on top, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fL02NLRFLMQT7Pot44gxhA?select=4CPZjVcYH6OtiLTaf_Bj8w  then the pickled flavor is lost (not necessarily a bad thing).

As for the Manhattan, it was the Perfect Manhattan, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fL02NLRFLMQT7Pot44gxhA?select=yedEYQMWfIDfLfYQw2z_zQ confirmed by my Manhattan/Old Fashioned-loving hubby.   The sweet vermouth was just right.  This makes the 5th star on this review.  The 3 Brandy cherries skewered and sitting in the drink were fantastic.  These tiny cherries had the right balance of sweetness and tartness, and none of the fake chemical taste of a Maraschino cherry.  I loved these cherries.

Thankfully these awesome brandy cherries also exist in the Cherry Bounce http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fL02NLRFLMQT7Pot44gxhA?select=Xl8Odl28IEdDP4Hl1iletQ, which was Bourbon, cherry brandy, lemon, Angostura, and Champagne.  $10.  I normally associate Cherry with cough syrup but this was absolutely delicious.

We also ordered the $8 Corn Fritters.  These were delicious as well.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fL02NLRFLMQT7Pot44gxhA?select=IzT71zUxdE9z_Ll8UjZX-w

While Nacho got a second Manhattan, I got a Lagavulin 16-year (Scotch - Islay) to try.  It's peaty.  I still prefer Speyside more.  This Lagavulin was a generous pour, but at $16, I expected it to be. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fL02NLRFLMQT7Pot44gxhA?select=N3KvQAF0EJsklIgclq4GGQ

-Service:  Friendly - from the hostess to our waiter to the bus boys, they were all nice, attentive and our water glasses were always promptly filled.

-Ambiance: There's a tiny outside area but inside is best when there's a band playing.  On this particular night, a jazz trio filled the air.  What's not cool about them is that they came downstairs and hawked for money twice during their short show.  As for seating, there is the long bar, some booths and a couple of tiny table.  I didn't visit the back (which was promised to be quieter), but be assured that this place is happening.

If you happen to find yourself in the area during the day, they offer "free lunch" with a 2 drink minimum on week days.  The lunch items are light bites like sandwiches, etc.  I recommend lunch somewhere else.

-Worth the trip/try?  Definitely.  If you are new to the area, ignore Google Map's pin.  This place is north of Happy Donut/Lifemark at the Pacific/Kearny/Columbus junction.  It's more like Pacific and Columbus.  

Honestly, the Pickled Egg/Hangtown Toast itself was not worth $6 (1 sliced boiled egg on a few strips of bacon) - but if you're gonna hit all 100 things on the 7x7, then go for it.   

If you're with great company, have an appreciation of jazz music and a hankering for delicious drinks, Comstock is your place on any night.
author: Winnie L.

description: The place was great and one of the bartenders was a co owner partners he was knowledgeable and personable we will definitely be coming back when in the city
author: kenneth m.

description: One of these days Im actually going to eat here. However I keep showing up really late and boozing instead. It's funny to think that this car is technically Chinatown, though it has none of Chinatown's stereotypical trademarks. You do however have to appreciate the old world charm and their dedication to making finely crafted drinks of yore. The Manhattan and Sazerac are always great go to's but a Barkeep's Whimsy (they make something for you outta nowhere) is always a way to keep it interesting. If you dont like the tourist laden North Beach bars, wander south and get a solid one here.
author: Kim N.

description:
Who said you can't get a free lunch?

Free lunch on Fridays between 12-4 (I think), with the purchase of two 'adult beverages'.  The Friday that I came here we had a pork sausage with lentils and it was darn tasty!  Plus we bought a side of fries that were hot-crispy-melt-in-your-mouth perfection!
The first time I came here I split a burger with another patron and boy was that divine.  They also have decent drink prices, and decent prices all around when it comes to their location.
The service was pretty stellar once we got in the groove of things and they were really responsive with straws (due to wearing lipstick) and water/drink refills.
The ambiance is very, rustic-SF, much like the Irish coffee place in the marina.  The decor seems like it hasn't changed since before the prohibition, they offer live music and the bands play above the dinner guests, it's pretty cool.  The also have some non-traditional stools and fans that are pretty righteous.  The floor is also.. barber-like, which gives it a little something different/old school.
 
Overall I would come back and possible take a few visitors here as well.
author: Sara N.

description:
Quality cocktail bar. Some night have live music.

PROS
- Great cocktails
- Great services and staff
- Quality food

CONS
- Can take awhile to get orders
author: Drew P.

description:
Had dinner and drinks here on a Saturday night. 
The drinks were good (pisco punch & a margarita). The food was mixed. The appetizers were delicious but my entree(the salmon) was inedible. It was like a mix between canned tuna and salmon. Really really fishy, maybe it was old, I'm not sure. It was also really hard. Just bizarre. The rest of my group loved their entrees(burgers).
author: Alex C.

description:
Been here a couple of times since it opened. The drinks were great. Bartenders know their stuff, (was featured in Food & Wine magazine as one of the best new bars of 2014). My boyfriend loves Sazerac's and said the one the bartender made for him here was the best he has ever had.
I really liked the atmosphere here. Not pretentious. It's a great place in the area because so much of this part of town is for tourists being near Little Italy and Chinatown. If your a local or a visitor to San Francisco I'd recommend this place. It's good food and drinks while the atmosphere takes you back in time to the gold rush era.
author: Megan Z.

description:
It's hard to find a place where they know how to make a good Sazerac, and the Comstock Saloon is such a place. 

I always sit at the bar, but they have some tasty appetizers. I'm particularly fond of their crispy chicken livers with jalapeños, but it's all good -- especially after a couple Sazeracs.
author: Clay J.

description:
Historic bar with great drink options. A couple local beers and some mixed drinks that are dangerous, but good.

Have a barkeepers whimsy, but shut it down after a few - unless it's one of those nights.
author: Matthew S.

description: Great classic dive bar.  Had jazz on a Monday night. Friendly staff.  Stiff drinks. My fav part of our trip. A must see
author: Bert P.

description: Okay, here's the thing: you like drinks and such? Come here now! You think you know how a Manhattan is made? You don't know. Trust me in this. Get in here now. Don't waste your time on other places. Ask for Zach. He'll fix you up right. Do it! Now!
author: Felix M.

description: Great food (the mushroom frites were life-changing) and the music (Gaucho) was first-class. Great ambience and service. 5+++++ all the way. Will be back for sure. Thanks for a wonderful evening.
author: Alex M.

description:
Perfect place for history buffs who like to feel like they are time traveling. Amazingly delish late night food. (They serve until 12 on weeknights!) What a treat to find a five mushroom pot pie on a menu in an area of town that seems so saturated with meat heavy menus. It was the BEST thing I have eaten in a long time. The chef was smart to not give me the recipe because now I have to go back. 

I tried two cocktails, can not remember the names of them, as it was the last stop on a night of true fun birthday bar hopping. Both cocktails were great. I love a drink garnished with brandied cherries. Thank you for not serving gross maraschino cherries Comstock! I felt like I had just stepped back into 1890 walking into this place. The word saloon conjures up images of a dusty dirty rough and tumble sort of place, but the Comstock is beautiful. There is a huge vintage wooden wall piece, for lack of knowing the true name of the thing, behind the bar, which is original to San Francisco and so cool. The manager, servers and bartenders all seemed like they truly enjoyed being there. Very refreshing. I want to go back for dinner sometime and this place is definitely going on the list of places to take out of town guests!
author: Audra S.

description:
I love food and drink, and I also know that San Francisco is a big city with many places in which to indulge. So it was more than a little amazing to find out that almost everyone I know who's been to SF recently knew of this spot, and had been there. And it was even more amazing that I was privileged to go there with a  lovely friend I hadn't seen in years, on the night of the Lunar New Year Parade. Such magic everywhere....

Amidst the sparkle and pop of amateur firecrackers outside the front door, I basked in the glow of my South Side - beautiful. Fans lazily loomed far above, the band played in the balcony up on the wall, and the Scotch egg made everything right - so right - with the world. They also serve a fun version of that steakhouse staple of whipped cheese in a stoneware jar, except theirs is from Cabot and studded with bright red pimento dices and ever so sophisticated in comparison. It felt like a little neighborhood family from all over had convened in this one spot, and the feeling was like coming home except to something a little new. And amazing.

If you find yourself up amongst the red sauce, lights, and incline of North Beach, do yourself a favor and pop in. Stay a while, laugh, and walk out the door hours later a little freer knowing that even if everyone doesn't know your name, everyone knows the name of where you've been. In a good way....
author: Hannah L.

description:
This is a fun place to stop by if you want to just grab drinks and hang out with friends. It's quite lively but not to the point where it feels overly crowded. The bartenders are sweethearts and were excited when I asked them to just make me a drink to their liking! They asked what I was craving and what profile I wanted and boom, I had a delicious drink in front of me in seconds.

Amusingly, the bartenders will also make drinks that they totally think are cliche but the awesome part is that they MAKE IT BETTER. They'll put their own flavor and twist to the drinks that make that so much more unique and delicious!
author: Chloe Y.

description:
In the bygone era when your server donnes a vest and bowtie, your cocktail menu comes in a supple leather book and dinner is called "supper", Comstock Saloon takes us back to SF's Barbary Coast Period.

The imposing wood and glass bar with hard to ignore "antique" barware lends to the ambiance. The bar area could get claustrophobic when packed but the dining room is plenty spacious.

Our server was efficient and got things hopping along. He handled our group of 9 well, drinks were quick and food delivered within reasonable time.

I'd guess that their menu features traditional saloon grub, but this being SF, also has seasonal ingredients. Our smoked salmon on rye toast and housemade crackers with cream cheese and pepper jelly made for easy snacking.

Their picnic plate would appeal to any pate lover: hefty portions of pork terrine and chicken galantine with toast and pickled veggies. 

The BEEF SHANK AND BONE MARROW pot pie is every miner's dream! (If I was a miner and lived during that time) Buttery, super flaky crust with hot steam coming out from the inside. Well seasoned meat paired well with the peppery arugula side salad. 

Their short cocktail list is a tribute to classic creations. While I would've usually gone for a gin martini, I tried their South Side cocktail instead, very minty, almost like a mojito.

Comstock Saloon's comforting eats and classic cocktails make me want to put on my bustier and feathered hat to take a trip down yester year. Pardon me, but it's time for supper.
author: Janice C.

description:
Really liked their Manhattan (which is on 7x7's TTTBYD List) and drank it slow to savor each sip. The food was pretty good for a place named saloon, and the prices weren't too bad. It was surprisingly not crowded on a Wednesday, post-work, evening.

- The bone marrow beef shank pot pie (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fL02NLRFLMQT7Pot44gxhA?select=md0myPKm9KymTbDMl5umqQ) was good and while I don't like arugula, the pair went well together. 
- The picnic plate - sampler of pate-like spreads and pickled vegetables (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fL02NLRFLMQT7Pot44gxhA?select=IVKXGUGsTE5mDlHln0agFA) might be too big of a portion. 
- The cheddar crackers with a dollop of pepper jelly and cream cheese (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fL02NLRFLMQT7Pot44gxhA?select=pgcaT89WKdJKZjqKzwgIsg) was good.
- The smoked salmon on rye toast with dill sour cream (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/fL02NLRFLMQT7Pot44gxhA?select=Ft8LFzCP3e5bUjLy7cJyRg) was good for something I would normally not order.

On the bar side of this place the walkway felt too tight. But, the booths are huge and can fit eight comfortably. On the restaurant side, it feels roomy and rustic.

Note, went here after a YEE once, and again for a UYE so take that for what it's worth!
author: Peter L.

description:
Easily one of my favorite bars in San Francisco! The young bartender, I wish I remembered his name, played the saloon-y part with the long apron and big mustache. I do remember he vegan if that helps.

The drinks are top-notch and not pricey. The set up isn't exactly like in the movie Forgiven or the Looney Tunes episodes with Bugs Bunny and Yosemite Sam, but it's close enough.
author: Mihir S.

description:
So classic SF.  This is a great spot to grab a cocktail and/or a bite to eat.  Best Manhattan in San Francisco and the Sazerac will not disappoint either.  The menu has some great options, though it's hard for me to get anything other than oysters to pair with my spirit of choice.

Come here for the drinks, stay for the food, and come back for the great bartenders and cool vibes.
author: Lindsey G.

description: Come here for cocktails. One of the best Manhattans I've had. Service could have been a bit better but I'll let that slide
author: Melissa R.

description:
I didn't think I'd like a Pickled Egg...but I do.

I thought I'd enjoy the Chicken-fried Rabbit the most but I didn't.  It was way too salty - as if I sprinkled my tongue with salt before each bite.  The Griddled Rillette was pretty gosh darn delicious.

What was even tastier was the Braised Beef Shank & Bone Marrow Pot Pie.  A bit small for the price but the meat and the crust were tender.
author: Rose A.

description: This is an excellent venue for libations. The adult beverages here are effing amazing. It's old school af.
author: Adam S.

description:
Comstock Saloon was good!!  The thing I liked the most about this place was the service. My girl and I called the restaurant late and asked if we could make a reservation. We made it for 8:30. We get there just a little but late but the place was packed. We walk up expecting that we lost the table but pleasantly surprised, he walks us right back to a night table. The waitress was really nice and helpful and always was a step ahead. 

We at the crispy chicken liver stated. I really liked that. I was in the mood to try something new and it was good!  We also ate the steak which was perfectly cooked to med rare and well seasoned. The roasted chicken was juicy and it was a pretty good size portion. 

Lastly, we really liked the ambiance. The old fashion saloon type decor was fun. Staff outfits were pretty cool and the live music on the second level looking down at the customers was really cool too. Nice fun place.
author: Steve J.

description:
DATE/TIME: February 17, 2012 // 2:00 PM

PRICE: $20-$30/person
VALUE: You come to a place like this not only for the food, but also for the ambiance and the cocktails if you're a fan of whiskey.
AMBIANCE: Old-timey, very vintage. Great looking bartenders with uber cool mustaches.
CHANCE OF RETURNING: 70%

___________________________________

The bone marrow pot pie brought me to the Comstock Saloon. I was working on a start-up operating out of a charming building across the street, and our team of four had been talking about heading there for lunch for over a month. 

When we finally went, we were very impressed by the charming vintage theme and ambiance. It really felt like you had traveled back in time. I almost wanted to have a cigar with my cocktail.

Speaking of, I'm not a whiskey kind of gal.. which this place focuses heavily on. Still, the cocktail I tried was pretty good.

NOTE: Unfortunately, it seems like the bone marrow pot pie is no longer on their menu as of 3/13/13. They do update their menu rather frequently, though..
___________________________________


:::: [ THE FOOD ] ::::

* PIG IN A BISCUIT
              - [3.5/5 - Savory pulled pork in a crispy biscuit. Great for sharing.]
* BONE MARROW POT PIE
              - [3/5 - While the pot pie's crust was perfectly baked with a nice glossy golden exterior, I only wish the dish was better seasoned and that I could have at least tasted  a little bit of the bone marrow in this dish.]
* MAPLE BOURBON PUDDING
              - [4/5 - SO rich and luscious. My only regret was that I didn't order one to myself.]
author: Asha S.

description:
Visited for the first time with a group of girls. There was a great jazz trio playing above the room and their cocktails were excellent!! Prices are right!
There is a ton of great style everywhere you turn in this old saloon. Take notice of the claw foot bar stools when you stop in!
author: Heather P.

description:
Pretty poor experience on a Friday night. Waitress was a little odd and disingenuous. We were turfed off our table in the restaurant as our time was up (not told this in advance) and seated in the bar. This would have been ok but it was freezing in there and the door was wide open. After 3 requests it was finally closed. It appeared it was open for staff benefit to keep them cooler. 

The bar server was rude and up his own ass, for want of a better expression. 

The apps we ordered in restaurant were pretty good but know that the "bucket of shrimp" is in fact 5 shrimp draped over a bucket of ice. 

The scotch egg was warm and did not have the flavor of an authentic scotch egg. I know because I come from the home of scotch eggs. 

The burrata went down well. 

All in all we spent $300 + tip for 4 and came away feeling that this place is not customer focused. Just a trendy spot to go. 

Won't return.
author: Jenny G.

description:
4 stars for a the start of a great evening. A friend had us stop here for Manhattans, which were superbly made. Just sweet enough without being cloying, Manhattans aren't usually my drink of choice but this place has one of the better if not the best one I've tried. 

I did not eat the food, but drinks are important so here's my Manhattan-based review.
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
One of my favorite bars in the city. Great craft cocktails, beautiful decor, live jazz band in the evening. I loved drinking by the back bar by the open door - less crowded, breezier, and a nice view onto Columbus. 

Free lunch on Fridays with the purchase of two cocktails. 
Go for the bartender's choice once in a while, you'd be pleasantly surprised.
author: Fiona S.

description:
This is a great bar close to the Financial District.  Great drinks and live Jazz (except for Sundays). The jazz band plays in a small section upstairs - no room for more than a three piece band.  The bar had a great decor (see other reviews). 
The bartender was great. I love a good Absinthe drink and saw the Sazerac posted on the door.  However, I let the bartender select my drinks. First was an 'Arsenic and Old Lace', the second was  a 'Quartz Cocktail' and the third was a 'Bobby
Burns'. Each was distinctive, potent and great. 
I also had a pork slider...
Needless to say, I was in walking distance to my hotel which was a good thing.
author: George S.

description: This place has amazing staff. The drinks are really good and the food is amazing.  Very gay friendly. I would recommend  this place to anyone who wants a a bar different from others.
author: samuel p.

description:
The place was pretty cracking. I walked into a huge group of people all dressed up and I felt really under dressed. But that's not the point. While we were eating here for my friend's birthday on a Friday night, it took forever for the servers to take our orders, and it took them even longer to give us our beers. I think after we ordered 3 beers, it took at least 15 minutes for them to bring it to the table. We gave up on waiting for the the beers and a few of us went to the bar and got immediate service. Table service really messed up our night, and groups of servers would constantly come back to our table looking annoyed because we had more drinks on our tab.

Table service was 1/5, Bar service was 5/5.
author: Karl R.

description: This is my favorite place to enjoy the atmosphere and grab the best cocktail. Cherry Bounce- might sound silly but it is a delicious drink. Lightly sweetened, biting acidity and champagne bubbles. Plus live music upstairs! Tonight it was jazz saxophone and bass, playing happy sounds from the 1920's :)
author: Lisa K.

description: Brilliant ambience! Friendly host and bartender and wonderful love music. Didn't try their food but the drinks were yum. Martinis are to die for
author: Trisha H.

description: Decided to check out this old style Saloon before going to beach blanket babylon. I really liked the authenticity of the place, but the assortment of food and drinks wasn't overly impressive. We got very small oysters for $2.75 each and some simple wings and fries. I got the "boot to the head" with a shot of bourbon and a beer for $7 which was a solid deal. They only had one drink on the cocktail menu for happy hour though, which wasn't very exciting for our friends that like the sweet mixes. The gnocchi was good!
author: Nikita K.

description: Wanted to come here for ages but kept forgetting to reserve a table. Finally remembered last Friday. Although we were completely attracted by the aesthetic, the service & the food went from "meh" to worse. One raggedly old cocktail menu & one raggedly old dinner menu to share listlessly dropped on the table. A loooooong time between ordering cocktails and having them delivered. A slightly pathetic portion of moules frites & a cassoulet that had sausage that was tough as an old boot (not sure what that was about). My other half ordered a dessert because he's dessert mad. Whatever it was came in a glass and seemed unremarkable. We wanted this to be 5 star because it looked so nice, but it just isn't. It's actually a real shame.
author: Fi M.

description: We came here last week. Food was ok, nothing special, but drinks were cool and strong. Service was ptetty fast, out server was not very friendly or talkative, but he did not mix up any of our orders and that was great. We enjoyed the saloon atmosphere of this place. Books on the shelves next to the bar were quite interesting....
author: Pat F.

description: Good cocktails! Let the bartender decide and ask for a "trust me" cocktail
author: Marie r.

description: Impressed myself and friends visiting this historic spot. The service was genuine and friendly. The prohibition era style drinks were quality and concocted through careful execution. The slider appetizers were made from top meats, accompanied by crispy i house chips. Definitely going back!
author: Manny F.

description:
I am totally in love with this place!!  Walked in on a Saturday night after seeing Chicago the musical.  We had dinner reservations on the other side of town at Boulevard but had enough time to come in and really check this place out I've been hearing so much about.  Don't you love it when you hear about a place and you get excited about it and it ends up being what you expected.  Every Yelper should feel this way on more than one occasion.  My husband and I were greeted at the door by a very nice young woman who took us to a very nice part of the bar area where we could see everything.  We asked a cocktail questions to find the best fit and even though we had dinner reservations we went for their oysters and fried cheese balls (and excuse me for not typing the proper name for it).  What a delight it was.... the oysters were fresh, the sauces were perfectly made.  And when those fried cheese balls arrived with this creamy sauce on the bottom, I almost passed out.  Had we not had other plans we would have tried everything on their modest but delicious menu.  

I will conclude by saying for some reason we got super special love that night by the waiter who may have been the owner of the place.  He was charming, dapper...the works.  I won't announce what he did for us but his generosity and kindness will bring us back very very soon.  It's the type of place you leave feeling good and sure, I'll say it... Hip!  

PS Manhattan if you are not shy.
author: Zin M.

description:
Old Timey, Classy, not for the drunken debauchery types.  In the heart of North Beach, where there the streets overflow with restaurants and bars, this corner bar is a nice break from the standard pubs. With unique cocktails with ingredients like Pinapple Gum, marischinno liqueur, and absenth, I definitely had a tough time picking something out.  I went with a Zinnie Cocktail which had the Pinapple gum which is more like a tart syrup and it was delicious.

We tried a couple different Sherrys as well in honor of Fraiser, however, I think we'll leave those to the show.

I loved the live music upstairs band overlooking the back room, the fans on a pulley system. The band played bass and piano, perhaps a banjo or guitar in there, my memory fails, but it fit right in and added to the ambiance.

I would definitely go back. Might I add, on the night of Santa Con, there were NO Santas to be found here! And the barkeeps were all fine with that
author: Audrey L.

description:
Here's the deal: you gotta love Comstock with a Sister Wives kinda love. There are plenty of other lovers who want a piece of this handsome establishment, and that's just the way it is. You'll never have it all to yourself.

While there aren't many spots that draw me to North Beach, Comstock Saloon is one of the few. I can't resist it's charms. The atmosphere is so unique, cozy and historic (authentically? I'm not sure) that it's difficult not to pick up some old-timey feel-good vibes when you're here. 

It's popular - like waaaay - and far too small to accommodate the masses that would like to spend all night in their saloon style booths. But when it's all said and done you'll be happy you came, saw, sipped, tapped your toes, and relished in Comstock's lively golden glow.

Cocktails are fab. Seating is scarce. But don't try to fight the feeling, you want a piece of Comstock, too.
author: Nique F.

description: What a cool little bar in North Beach. Cocktails were excellent and the Atmosphere was Great. A gypsy jazz band called Gaucho was playing the night we went and it made for great side entertainment while we hung out.
author: Samantha S.

description:
Stopped by for happy hour and experienced terrible service. Finished our drinks and never did the bartender come back over to ask if we'd like to drink more (side note: well hell yes, we wanted to drink more). The place was not crowded - 4:30pm on a Wednesday and we were sitting right at the bar. We waited for 30 minutes until I decided to ask a passing waitress to request our check. 

So I thought 2 stars were appropriate for my review until I concluded that my shot of Four Roses bourbon is very diluted with water. 

Probably won't come back to this place unless I'm dragged by a group of people. There are so many other bars in the city that do such a better job.
author: Pete S.

description:
This is WAYYYYYYYY better than the pretentious Bourbon and Branch.  I don't need to procure a password via email, nor do I have to use a computerized reservation system just to enjoy a nice cocktail.  The bartenders are always nice and they do make an effort to converse with you especially on slow nights.  

The cocktails are a bit pricey, BUT: #1 you're in SF so everything is expensive and #2 the drinks are just so well crafted that you really get what you pay for. I do agree with my friend that they make THE BEST Sazeracs.  I also like their Manhattan, Cherry Bounce, AND Blood and Sand.  The Cherry Bounce is what I order the most...so I guess you can consider that my favorite drink at Comstock.

I just found out that they have food.  WHAT???!!!!  See that's what happens when you're a lush?  Your eyes hone in on the alcohol menu first.  Their food menu will be my next adventure.  I just hope that the food is just as delicious as the drinks.
author: Shirleyanne A.

description: Stayed in SF for a few nights - randomly ducked in there.  Not just live music, but great live music.  Good selection of Scotch, great service from the Bartender.  Scotch, Jazz, Beautiful people.  Goddamnit, I love San Francisco.
author: Nam L.

description:
I like that they have this bartender's whimsy (or something like that) option, last one on the cocktail menu.

Just describe what you like and they'll make something to your fancy! Then again most quality bars will do this anyway, it's just not necessarily listed on the menu. 

It was weird, the hostess recommended several things to me (this was before I realized she wasnt' our server), then I asked our actual server and she didnt recognize the drink my hostess seemed to recommend the most based on my likes/dislikes. I went with a gin based drink but should have known not to go with gin (I HATE gin & tonics) - I believe it was a Shanghai slinger? Shanghai something. I just need to be more knowledgeable of what suits my personal taste

Any which way, I still love the vintage, home-y feel of this place. And I love coming on a weeknight when it's chill and relaxed.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Everything was perfect about this saloon! The bartenders were funny, friendly, and patient about what they were doing. The Sazerak was made to perfection! Then we ordered the Rabbit appetizer...and ohmagoodness was that DELICIOUS!!!  The atmosphere is classy but not pretentious; laid back but hip. The decor is cozy with it's dark wood, low lighting, and live jazz band playing from the mezzanine.

I would go back every weekend if I lived in SF and definitely plan to return on my next visit.
author: Kimberly M.

description:
Wow, stepping into this bar was such a surprise. First, I hadn't been IN a bar in only God knows how long, so it was kinda cool to step into Comstock and feel like I'd time traveled back to the 1800's. The decor is VERY old and the bar itself is massive. I don't think photos can do it justice. At the bar, under the bar stools, if you notice there is a tile trough. It is what men used to use to piss in while still sitting at the bar. Disgusting concept if you think about that being used today, but don't worry, it's clean and it's pretty rad they preserved that and left it there. 
We went in for lunch, and I tried the pigs n blanket. They are like mini crispy pork sliders. I thought they were delicious. 
I know Comstock is known, and renowned, for their cocktails, but I don't drink hard liquor so I just stuck with a local Anchor Steam. It was delicious and I really enjoyed it. 
Glad we stopped in this little place. Totally surprising what great bar food they have. YUM!
author: Nikki H.

description:
Loved the place, the atmosphere, the live band.
I asked for a custom made cocktail with rum. Super happy with the result.
Tried the sardines toasts ($12 or $14), great taste but it's three small toasts.
Tried the burger ($14) which was good and bigger. 
Loved our waiter too, lots of character, discreet but always making sure we had everything we needed.
author: Sophie G.

description:
i really like this place! the only downside is that sometimes it gets crowded and you cant get in your drink order easily because there are just tooo manyyyy peopleee at the bar. but i guess that's the case with almost every popular bar in sf..

they make amazing manhattans and negroni's and also a few house cocktails. bartenders are good at what they do, and can make a unique concoction for you upon request. you can also come in, sit at a booth, and enjoy dinner with your drinks. the food is hearty and delicious, and really go well with the cocktails. but what food doesnt pair well with cocktails..? 

there is also live music at times. totally fun.
author: Christina L.

description:
It's like always hard to get a seat here. Albeit, it's worth a visit to try out some yummy cocktails in a old-fashioned themed bar in North Beach. Just ask your server what they recommend because this is one of those places where the bartenders should be paid more because they're actually knowledgeable about the drinks they're producing--how can they not be if dressed that way.

Try to come at a time when the band is playing on the second floor balcony (I don't know when that happens). It's just pretty cool that a random band is playing up there. It's a little balcony that serves the purpose of containing music producing groups.

This spot should be on anyone's bar-hopping agenda in North Beach.
author: Marlon T.

description:
I am editing this review based on recent experiences at (trying to get into) this place.  

Although everything I said in my original review is true, I feel I must warn potential customers that the "greeter" (tall man at the doorway) has consistently been the most negative aspect of this entire establishment.  I've been told by him (sarcastically) to both get/not get a reservation.  One time I was asked "Why would you bother getting a reservation tonight?"  and another time I was asked "Maybe you should consider getting a reservation next time (with an extremely sardonic tone)."   Whether I should or shouldn't get a reservation is beside the point - The greeter is suppose to make you feel welcome and put on a good face for the institution.  On the most recent visit, I was accompanied by a few Asian friends.  When the greeter saw them he said "Maybe you guys would be happier at Mr. Bings across the street."  The addition of a racist suggestion to an already caustic tone was enough to turn me off of this place forever.  

Unfortunately, the beautiful idea and environment that is Comstock Saloon is forever masked by the hideous face that is the greeter.  

Go to this place and try to make it beyond Cerberus.  If you can, it will be a real treat!   

Original Review:
Comstock Saloon occupies a very special place in my heart.  Walking in the doors is like walking back in time.  It has actually been open since 1907!  There are original wooden articles everywhere - a bar, alcohol rack and old-style pulley paddle fans (it is unclear whether these are made from wood or metal as they are rather high up).  However, the piece de resistance is definitely the live jazz music pouring down on you from the (slightly) hidden mezzanine.  

Live music generally begins around 7:30 PM and lasts for hours.  The performers I have seen are all spectacular.  They range from lone singers majestically accompanying themselves on the piano, to 3 and 4 piece jazz bands (with piano, string bass, Flugel instrumentation).  If you are listening to the larger bands, choose your seat location wisely.  Since the musicians are in the mezzanine, the horns tend to project directly down towards specific tables.  It can become extremely loud and prevent you from having any conversations that aren't shouting matches.  

The drink and food menu is extensive and full of quality items.  I have certainly not tried everything on the menu, but of the cocktails I would recommend Blood and Sand (Scotch, sweet vermouth, orange, and cherry liqueur) and White Lily (with absinthe and rum - very strong!).  My personal favorite appetizer is the Scotch Egg.  For those of you who do not know, this is a hard-boiled egg wrapped in sausage meat, coated in bread crumbs and baked or deep-fried.  It is a delightfully heavy British food.  The prices here are fair, but certainly not cheap.  It therefore attracts a more mature and well-dressed crowd.

The bar setting is speakeasy-like.  Since windows are in abundance here, it does not really feel like a speakeasy until after sunset when the windows seem to disappear and the dim lights inside emit a cozy glow.  At this point, you begin forgetting where you are and drift into that lull that only jazz and good drinks can bring you to.
author: James Y.

description: Went to Comstock based of Anthony Bourdain's layover ... Lived up to expectation ! Great bartender(s) who can whip anything & everything creative in a glass,  and a very classy welcoming salon. The baby corn was delicious ... Highly recommend this place !
author: Justin S.

description: A bit pricey perhaps but worth it to hear local musicians play on the bar's unique atmosphere.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Cocktails are top notch. Commitment to fresh house-made ingredients, and devotion to craftsmanship. The Pisco Punch is good, but branch out. White Lilly is tasty, the absinthe and junipero flavors really come out.  The winner for me thus far is the Barkeeps Whimsy - received a Scofflaw from this, substituting bourbon for rye whiskey (normally rye whiskey, dry vermouth, lemon juice, grenadine). Quickly ordered a second Scofflaw. 

Will report back once further intel has been gathered.
author: David G.

description:
3.5 stars, rounded up to 4 for the live music (we consider 2 to be average).

We went to Comstock for dinner and thought the space was great. We were lucky enough to have Gaucho playing that night, although being in the dining room was a bit removed from the music, as well as the hustle and bustle of the main bar.

Cocktails were delicious (Zeinie and Cherry Bounce) and well balanced (which you'd expect given that it's owned by The Absinthe Group).

We ordered 3 appetizers (pig in a biscuit, hangtown toast, and rabbit three ways), as well as the duck pot pie - a special. This was a huge amount of food and we would still have been stuffed with one fewer appetizer.

The pig in a biscuit and the duck pot pie were both fantastic. The pig in a biscuit came as three mini sliders of yummy pork patties, along with some tasty mustard and pickles.
