The duck pot pie was rich, meaty, and well seasoned, with a great flaky crust. Hangtown toast was our least favorite dish as it just felt a little boring. The toast was cold and burned around the edges, and the only interesting component was the pickled eggs. The rabbit was a solid dish, with extremely moist and delicately fried nuggets, some rabbit rillettes on toast, and a terrine (which had a somewhat springy consistency, like fish balls in pho).

Overall, worth a visit.
author: Amy D.

description: Unbelievable! Really cool vintage atmosphere. Drinks were great- my sidecar was flawless and the bartender clearly loved her job. In addition to this the food was incredible! Charted baby corn, best fries on earth, fried shishito peppers with harissa, flakey and tender wings with green chili and sriracha. Best food we had while in San Francisco hands down.
author: Christina M.

description: Super nice and welcoming Saloon here near Chinatown. A great place to hangout with friends.
author: Kim C.

description:
Stopped in for Friday happy hour.  First bar of my latest San Fran trip.  Great place to catch up with friends and begin the evening.  Tried some of the small plates and they were delicious.  The drink menu was solid and tried a few different ones and EACH one was GREAT.  The staff takes great pride in everything and the details are noticed.
   There was a young lady performing up in the loft and she was very talented.  Her music totally fit the space.

   I will definitely stop by this place the next time I am in town.  A great place for classic cocktails and great service.
author: Michael A.

description:
Good food and great drinks. Just ask the bartender to make you something rather than being specific.

Enjoy the live music but don't over expect atmosphere - it's classy, quality but not really buzzing
author: James A.

description:
I liked the ambiance of the place and the drinks! We came here after dinner in hopes to get our drink on... It was on! This place was hopping but our group of eight was accommodated quickly when they let us sit down in the dining room area. 

Then hostess who sat us was very friendly and accommodating. Our waitress, however, had the stink eye for us the entire night! Never a smile, never a friendly hi how are you, just can I take your order, ok, any thing else? I think a robot would have been better. 

I get it, it was a busy night, she probably didn't want to serve both the bar and the living room, but come on.... A bad service experience at any establishment ruins the experience entirely. 

They get three stars for a good drink menu, mediocre to subpar service, and fun atmosphere. I hope if I ever get to go back here that the service will improve.
author: Minnow N.

description:
Who needs a magical wardrobe a la CS Lewis or a special time-traveling buggy a la Woody Allen to be transported to a different era when you have this amazing spot? As soon as you step in the door you're surrounded by all sorts of old-timey goodness, from an amazing live band playing on the balcony to the carefully crafted cocktails, this feels like a throwback to the roarin' 20s... or at least how I imagine that time to be. 

I requested that the friendly bartendress create me a drink using St. Germain and she ended up handing me a very strong and tasty mix of tequila and celery bitters, which I didn't think I liked at first but ended up gulping down with gusto once I got used to the strength and unique flavor. She was totally cool about splitting our tabs, too, which I always appreciate. 

My one complaint is that it wasn't a very convenient spot for a group to just stop in and hang... the bar area is very narrow and the seats were reserved for those ordering food. We would have stayed longer but we literally couldn't move around in the tiny space available to us! 

Other than that, I fell head over heels for this charming watering hole and definitely recommend it for a retro chic evening!
author: Christina P.

description: We went in the afternoon and it wasn't busy, so I'm sure it is a different vibe at night. Being that it wasn't busy it gave us the opportunity to get some time with the bartender and tell him what we liked.  He made a couple of cocktails from the menu with a bit of twist to fit what we were looking.  I love places that take the time to listen and actually care what you like too.  Too bad we couldn't be there when it was busier but sometimes it is nice to have the place and staff to yourself. Oh yeah...and the cocktails were great!
author: Jim G.

description:
I'm purely rating the food. The drink menu was awesome. 

We came for dinner and sat in the back dining room. The ambiance was nice. Very dark and old looking. Very cool. 

It was busy for a Saturday night. 

Our food was good but not great. The gnocchi wasn't like a traditional pasta. It had meat and spinach and mushrooms and was a little dry. It kind of felt like something harvested out of the forest. 

I'm not sure I'd come back for dinner but definitely for drinks.
author: Cara C.

description:
We (my husband and I) came here last week on our quest to try 52 new places in 52 weeks. 

"That's where the San Francisco Brewing company used to be right?" asked my husband when I asked him to meet me and two of my coworkers here after work on a Friday. And indeed it is, but it hardly resembles it's former self. To be honest, it felt like we stepped straight into Casablanca (or at least that is how I felt). 

There were a few booths that said reserved and nowhere to sit at the bar when we walked in, but when we asked the waitress if there was anyway we could at a table she was happy to oblige. The service was a little bit slow, but that is just because they take the time to really make one-of-a-kind cocktails. My colleagues had the Cherry Bounce (delish), i had the John Collins (surprise, surprise), and the hubs had a simple Old Fashioned. Since it was the day before the Kentucky Derby we may have also had a Mint Julep : )

Not cheap, so not the best venue for after work drinks, but a great date spot. I would come back!
author: Melissa N.

description:
While I did like their Fried Oyster & Ham Po' Boy and their Wedge Salad w/ crispy Pork Belly...the Beef Shank & Bone Marrow Pot Pie has got to be the most memorable dish here.  And it went very well with the wild arugula side salad w/ lemon dressing. The flavor and succulence of bone marrow enveloped in a delightful flaky crust...is all I ever need from this swanky looking place, along with a fine Blood & Sand or Manhattan again.  

On all occasions I've been here, they've been consistent with friendly but slow service.  At least I had more time to be fascinated by their interesting atmosphere.  
I wouldn't mind coming back.  back into time. and soon.
author: Bobby L.

description: Poorly made drinks and management with a horrible demeanor. She should either be retrained or get out of the biz cause she is clueless.
author: David H.

description:
Once in a blue moon do I find as awesome a place as this, because it's a three-in-one punch. They are both a restaurant and a bar (in side-by-side rooms), with live music offered to everyone from an upstairs band.

I've come here on multiple occasions with different intentions: once for the delectable dinner, and others for just the bar. And, it is inappropriate to say "just the bar," because their bartenders are superb. Order the Barkeep's Whimsy, where they will craft a cocktail they predict you desire!

What is particularly fantastic is the decor of the entire location. Everything there, from the wallpaper and furniture to the suspenders and vests attired by waiters and bartenders, either replicates or authenticates the look of "old town SF," circa the Gold Rush. As Comstock Saloon is already situated in a historic location more than a century old, there is plenty of history as is.

This place hasn't seen the last of me!
author: Garett T.

description: Love the drinks and the friendly service..had three rounds before the bar had to absolutely close
author: Varsha V.

description:
There's something charming about the atmosphere here-- with old-timey music, an almost steampunk air-circulating contraption on the ceiling, and a tiled trough of dubious purpose running along the base of the bar.  But unfortunately, the food is disappointing (potato croquette) or passable at best (rabbit poutine), and the cocktails are nothing special.

The next time a craft cocktail bartender tells me enthusiastically that her favorite whiskey drink is the sazerac, I may walk out.  And it's not that they aren't pleasant to drink, but if this is the best they can do, I can do better at home.
author: William B.

description: Inventive cocktails, live jazz, and a beautiful historic building. We stopped by for a cocktail and the menu was so interesting I had a hard time choosing. So I went with my old standby the Manhattan. It was perfect. We enjoyed the jazz. The space is small and it got crowded as the evening wore on.
author: Allison H.

description:
This place is a step back in time if I've ever seen one. Instantly after walking in the door I felt like I was on the holodeck of the Starship Enterprise. Why? Because they pay attention to the details. From the 1920's-ish interior decor to the signature cocktails to the quirky ceiling fans, everything is a perfect expression of the mood they want you to feel. Take a seat on a couch in the back and you'll wish you had an opium pipe and an absinthe in your hand. 

I've only been here once but it was awfully crowded. I think a recent recommendation by Anthony Bourdain put this place on the map for a lot of folks. Once you visit you'll see why people keep coming back.
author: Alex L.

description: This is a cute little bar! Had an old school feel to it. I liked it a lot. It was a great spot to have a drink after walking around all over the city while visiting!
author: Summer S.

description: We honestly forget the drinks...because our bucket of shrimp should have been called a bucket of ice with shrimp garnish. Maybe we are used to east-coast shelfish, but the taste was off and shrimp cocktail is what it is--A few giant shrimp that kick your ass in taste. We ate dinner at a place that hit us up for 3 bucks a bacon date and 4$ for half an egg and have no issue with the cost to the taste and experience . This place had a miss-able vibe and I think they ran out of salt after making the sprouts tonight.
author: jenn p.

description:
PLEASE DON'T PATRON THIS PLACE UNTIL MANAGEMENT TAKES CARE OF THEIR STAFF.  There are plenty of other places to visit.  TERRIBLE EXPERIENCE!

We were here last night, and were hanging out outside about to leave.  One of the members in our group was smoking and the bartender comes out and tells us "you can't smoke here."  He then adds "I know you don't speak english, but you can't smoke next to the building."  Mind you, this is on the borderline of Chinatown and this was completely unprovoked.  We then went back in to find a manager to point out that bartender.  The manager offered us a drink, but I'd prefer the termination of this individual from the staff.  This is ridiculous, especially in San Francisco.
author: Travis L.

description: This has been my happy hour spot for 15+ years (back in SF Brew Co. days) and went here at night for the first time in many years. Our original waiter was a complete asshat, but JB the manager, came to the rescue. He got us a seat, and made our out-of-town guests love one of the most classic bars in SF. Thank you, JB!
author: Scott C.

description:
A Bourdain recommendation and came extremely crowded. So everyone agrees, this place is pretty damn cool. The Live Band in the balcony, like the icing on the classic cake. Cocktails none the less. 

The scenery, the menu, the cocktails and crowd. It's the experience and you get it when you order the sipper of your choice. I had a drink I thought called the Country Life, yet we mighta switched at that time, the other being just as tasty.

Either way, classy cocktails done right. Order up and hit the road like Bourdain in the Layover. Cause it's like that and that's the way it is. Huh,
author: Rebekah T.

description: Yummy!! Very cool drinks!! On Friday they have a deal where you buy 2 drinks and get a free lunch. We  stumbled on that one... Serendipity. BBQ Chicken leg and salad yum.
author: Cecilia D.

description:
Me and the lady came here for a special evening. This was our first time here and it fell on a Sunday night. Still, they had live music, a piano player and singer, in the upper level, which was great. The bar is nice and has a slight old-timey feel. There was only one bar tender so service was a tad slow, but, he was very good at mixing drinks. A bit of a show for each one and he seemed to take pride in it. Lots of interesting things on the cocktail menu. Although the beer selection was not memorable.

We also had reservations that night for dinner. When I asked the bar tender who to speak to, the host seemed to just appear out of nowhere and even knew who I was. He already had a 'reserved' tag on our table. And they easily transferred the bar tab to the table.

The menu for dinner wasn't super exciting. Not a ton of variety, but good enough considering the overall experience. I had the sausage polenta dish while she had the half-chicken. Both very good, but not blow-away. I recall more seafood options. The quality was there. A bit pricey, but hey, this is North Beach SF so that's to be expected.

The kicker was the excellent customer service. Everyone from the bar tender to the host to the server was so nice and accommodating. We felt very welcomed and not rushed like at some other places. I can't speak for other days of the week, but at least for a Sunday this was a very pleasant experience overall. We'd definitely consider going back even though it's a bit of a trek.

Also! The menu indicates that this restaurant gives all of their staff full benefits so for me the extra price is worth it. I'm all-in for local places that take care of their employees!
author: Adam B.

description:
Had a terrible experience last night at comstock.  As a friend and I were smoking outside, a staff member of comstock, came out to notify us - 

"You can't smoke so close to our patio area... I know you don't speak english but you have to move down the block to smoke" 

I know you don't speak english? 

Stay away from this place....poor experience here, so many more alternatives.
author: Thomas L.

description: Came here many years ago and thought it was great. Came here again recently, and it was just ok. Probably because they didn't have my preferred drink of choice and a lot of their "craft cocktails" are just regular cocktails.  It was really busy, but for some reason their bar on both sides only had 1 bartender. Took forever to get the drinks, but the place did kind of die down by 9pm.
author: Lisa T.

description:
This place is always on the top list of unique SF bars and it did not disappoint.

The server was friendly and seated us quickly. They have daily  4-7pm happy hour specials and my, I believe, $6 shot of something dark and good plus an amber beer was a steal! Everyone else ordered some cool happy hour drinks and some nice $10 cocktails. The ambience is nice and clean and I like the funny signs outside. 

Will be back to drink!
author: Chuck N.

description:
Comstock Saloon offers a pleasurable experience. Head to the bar for a prohibition-inspired ambiance with a live band on some nights tucked upstairs- and order one of their delicious, artisanal cocktails. They are known for their Manhattan and it's made 7X7's list multiple times! 

The room next door offers a more quiet, sit-down/dining experience if you want to come here for a full-on dinner. Great for a date spot. Or, sit at the bar if you want to admire and watch them hand-craft your cocktails!

They also have small plates/shareable plates like their pickled eggs, which are creative and quite tasty. Apparently they also offer free lunch on Friday with the commitment of 2 cocktail drinks, per person.
author: Veronica S.

description:
Service-good service
Live music
Pretty good selection of drinks
I liked the loud/live music and dim lights. It was a good place for casual drinks w friends. Def no complaints.
author: Anudari K.

description:
Comstock Saloon is a great example of a bar succeeding on the strength of their cocktails and not by how many shelves of bottles they have.  Comstock actually has a comparatively sparse amount of liquor but they work with what they have to make some pretty awesome drinks.  They also have some interesting bites on their menu (First time I had a pickled egg!) to help with the drinks.

The ambiance is pretty cool too.  It really makes you feel like you are in some sort of saloon and there is totally a balcony with a piano player.  They definitely got the atmosphere right here.

Didn't have too much else drink-wise other than the basic whiskey cocktails but they were all well-made and pricing was not really an issue.  Definitely adding this to some sort of awesome bar list.
author: Chris C.

description:
Solid cocktail bar. Probably my new favorite in San Francisco, in fact. 

On a crazy busy Friday night my friends and I were greeted warmly by a server. It was so packed she could barely reach out booth through the crowd and managed to make her job look effortless and easy and she waded through the room, took (separate) orders from our large 10 person group, and smiled and laughed at our drunken jokes.

Great selection of spirits at the bar, the food (Scotch eggs!) was awesome, and the cocktail menu was enticing. Since it was packed I opted for a scotch neat but fully intend to come back and try many, many more items both off the food and cocktail menu. Thanks, SF!
author: Katy H.

description: The Comstock is a cool bar with live jazz music.  The specialty drinks weren't too impressive - perhaps I haven't discovered my favorite yet.  They serve food, but we only went for drinks.  I'd totally go back and would recommend it!  This place was also named as one of the best by Esquire.  They have a show called "Best Bars in America" and they selected and filmed here.  I had already been to the place prior to filming, but since the show aired, I learned more about the bar.  Now I just need to try their food.
author: Shaun W.

description:
the half off snacks for happy hour and fantastic drinks and awesome decor.  Gone once, gone twice, the third time will be a charm

EDIT:
They took the happy hour away, didn't notify us, so we weren't too pleased when we left....the flavor of the pretzel and other snacks changed...too bad.  Used to be my go to when I could, but not so anymore.
author: Candice H.

description:
Killer burger! 

Went for dinner there last night. Ordered four oysters to start (2 per person), their beet salad (5s) and finally the hamburger. We shared the salad and burger and it was plenty to eat. But the servings weren't so big that one hungry person couldn't handle it.

Great service, though we waited a bit between every stage of the process. I personally love it when there's enough time to finish a course before the next one comes out. If you're not in a hurry & in good company, you will love this, too!

We sat outside in a little cubby lol, but we chose to sit there. I think ppl just sit there to smoke or drink a beer, but it was nice cozy on a SF night (chilly wind, but we love that kind of temperature).


Five stars for over all dining experience.
author: LV B.

description:
Good cocktails! Nice burger, amazing fried chicken liver.
Th bourbon pudding is to die for...

One star deducted because the service was VERY VERY SLOW.. esp the drinks..the bar wasn't even crowded
author: P D.

description:
I am in love with this place! Came here while barhopping on New Years Eve and I was amazed. It's kind of a speak easy type of place where they have old school fans rotating on the ceilings. They had a live jazz band playing and even a flapper type of girl dancing and singing. There was also this very beautiful woman playing the piano. 

I like that this place allows you to bring in a large party and be loud. Some speak easy bars don't allow large parties or loud noise because they want the ambiance to be true to the time, which is understandable. Comstock is a great place to have dinner, drinks, and listen to some great music.
author: Cathie N.

description:
Very nice and relax place to hang out at.

I came here with my boyfriend on last Saturday night, it was so crowded when we arrived at around 9pm; we got a table because we were going to eat something, but too bad their kitchen was too busy that night and all the entree were sold out, only could order some snacks. 

We order two glass-cups of Scotch, seated in the dinning area, the place isn't big but the decoration makes it neat.

The hostess was very friendly, she smiles all the time; I didn't like our waiter too much though, he didn't seem too patient when we were asking him if they can put the big ice cub in our scotch instead of putting a few (because too many ice cubs make the scotch melt into water faster), he said that's the biggest they have - which is not true because I saw them at the bar area and other customers were drinking their scotch with one big ice cub (he was just too lazy to get us that). Besides the ice cub, he seemed super busy talking to other female customers and chilled at the bar area where the female customers were, he didn't even take our payment, we left our credit card with the bill for so long, he was just at another table talking to a lady - one star off. 

Luckily the hostess came by to take care of our bill. 

Anyway, overall a very nice bar to chill at; just wish the next time we go there we wouldn't get the same water.
author: Sammy C.

description:
Came here with friends on a Friday night (with a reservation) and was seated in a booth. LOVE LOVE LOVE the space! It's beautiful, makes me feel as if I'm in the 20s. Love the live set (a jazz band played on the well lit upper floor) -- come prepared with cash in order to tip... unfortunately no one in my party had any :(  

Although I'm not much of a cocktail person, they have a great cocktail selection. Definitely a place to bring my girlfriends to when they visit. However I thought the food menu was just OK. it's probably seasonal so I didn't see some items I was interested in ordering after having checked reviews/photos on Yelp (eg, the bone marrow beef shank pot pie). So I opted fo the pigs in a biscuit -- yes the biscuits were just the right amount of buttery and the pork crispy, but the accompaniments weren't amazing (pickled salad and side of dijon-like mustard that I didn't think went well with the pork or biscuit) and the pork was oozing with grease down my fingers after every bite.

Overall, a great experience. Would highly recommend and will definitely be coming back! Thanks to my friends for introducing me to such a gem of a bar!
author: Siv L.

description:
I love this place! 

My Valentine's day dinner was here, and the food does not disappoint! 

We both ordered the pre-fixe menu, which was such an awesome deal! We tried the following:

Appetizer:
Asparagus salad w/ egg and aged ham - Simple, tasty
Mushroom bisque with roasted mushrooms and truffle - you'll love this, if you love mushrooms!

Entree:
Scallops - Tender! Good portion too!
Chicken - Deboned and stuffed - OMG, so tender! It was the best chicken I ever had! And the skin was nice and crispy!

Dessert:
Bourbon pudding - The banana cake in this was such a good combo with the bourbon
Chocolate parfait - yummm! soo creamy!!

Also tried the corn fritters, which were good also!

The transition from appetizers to entrees was extremely long, but they did make up for it by offering us a complimentary Rabbit 3 way Appetizer.  This was cooked well also!

We also tried the Cherry Sour and Sazerac.  They def put a lot of effort into their drinks and they were delicious!

Overall, Comstock saloon is nice and swanky! Live music on certain days too! :]
author: Tramy V.

description: Walked in for a late lunch/pre dinner fix. Dunch? Linner? Former, latter, your choice.  We were immediately greeted & seated. We started off with couple a drinks, the brandied cherries on the cherry bounce were so boozy & tasty. The bartender was very accommodating and friendly. We ordered the pobrecitos (oyster sliders), scotch egg (bit on the salty side), crispy chicken livers (good lawd, so good), chicken sandwich & the comstock burger (cooked spot on medium rare). I can't give enough praise to the lady bartender who also took our order. She was amazing and so goodnatured. The decor is very charming & all around it's a great watering hole for classic cocktails.
author: Kero S.

description: Best spot I've ever been for drinks. Old school bar setup. Classy but not pretentious. Background music was oldies. Crowd was older. Not a "bro" in the place, which was nice. Bartenders are polite, very knowledgeable, and can be as creative or traditional as you please should you not know what to order. The prices were reasonable for the quality and quantity of liquor in the cocktails.
author: Heath H.

description: We came in and really did not want to leave.  It was happy hour!   Service and drinks qere a cut above.
author: Gregory W.

description: This place as two great looking bars excellent cocktail and good food but the barmaid had some kind of a chip on her shoulder.
author: Wesley P.

description:
Word of caution. 
Two words actually.

Public. Transit.

Driving here is a no-no.

Let us begin:
Take note of your surroundings: it's hard enough to park your Vespa in NoBe, let alone something with doors.

Let us end:
You find yourself sliding down in your chair-banquette-stool, live music rocking you almost out of your seat, surrounded by Barbary Coast era decor and talented craft barkeep.

Pick your poison.

And leave your four wheeled friend at home;
the manhattan means business.
author: Alissa A.

description:
Bless them for their Honky Tonk Sundays: $6 for a shot and beer (decent stuff too, like bourbon and Anchor Steam), $6 for their derby cocktail, and 2 for 1 snacks. I got their derby and my friend got the shot and beer, so we can't say much of the cocktails . It seems like their bartenders must know their stuff though, because you have the option to leave it up to them to create you something.

My friend exclaimed, "oh how cute!" as we walked in, and I'm awed by the fact that it survived the great fire in San Francisco so long ago. It's a solid option if you're hoping for something stronger than wine in North Beach.
author: Cat N.

description:
This place is just OKAY.....
The  skirt steak was good, the corn fritters and crispy pork in a biscuit was just okay. Service was good and fast , we got seated right away on a Friday evening which I was surprised.
IF you want to have a nice dinner, go to the back, dining area and get seated and enjoy your dinner.  When you get in,  you see the bar right away which is dark and gets packed easily so getting a table here would be hard. 
There's alot of better places than this joint. I don't think I would come back for food since there wasn't  really anything worth coming back for.
Parking is also hard around here.
author: Claudine V.

description: Strong drinks and decent bites. Cocktails aren't as delicious as any of Future Bars' ventures (Bourbon and Branch, Rickhouse, Local Edition, etc.), but they have food!  I've been here thrice.  The food could be better, but in terms of menu variety and creativity, I give them an A for effort.  I like the vibe and the staff are nice.  A good place to get a solid drink before you barhop lesser bars.
author: Erika C.

description: Lovely servers, great service! My pinot noir was awesome. Food wise, my date's burger ($17!) was lackluster at best and I was actually pretty disappointed with my beet salad. Overall I would say this is an excellent place for a sexy cozy drink but would not recommend for dining. The live jazz band that they have at 8 pm was also a really nice touch!
author: Audrey S.

description: I'd been here many times but there was always too much of a wait for a seat but this time, happy hour, we waltzed right in. The derby was the hh special and it was really well-done and refreshing. Food was kinda pricey but it looked delicious. Will have to come back another night for that. The service was great and attentive too, we were checked on pretty frequently. Lots of character to the place without seeming like they're trying too hard.
author: Vivian H.

description:
I stopped in after checking out city lights one afternoon, and little did I suspect that by ordering a shot of high end Scotch and a mixed drink would I qualify for a free British lunch.  Because I had ignored the handy sign on the sidewalk. Bangers and mash, which tasted much better than their reputation or nomenclature would suggest. 
Do you like wonderful bourbon and like to talk about it with the bartender, festooned in bow - tied splendor?  This place must be on your list in SF.
author: Bob K.

description:
Directions:

1. Check it out... 
2. No really... Check it out.
3. Why aren't you listening to me... 
4. Do you know how good a Blood and Sand tastes? It tastes like Freedom.
author: Nathan B.

description:
We sat at the monkey bar, just minutes before it filled up.  Our bartender was super personable and made great Manhattans...too bad I was drinking greyhounds.  The grapefruit juice was terribly bitter and sour which made me think it was very old, the date on the bottle confirmed that.

The atmosphere was great, I tried my first scotch egg and after making the switch to Manhattans, I had a great evening.  I'll be back.
author: Spenser T.

description: Retro bar with stiff stiff drinks. $6 specials during happy hour was an oh to easy to drink mixture of rye. I had to grab a pimento cheese plate to I could walk out of there with dignity after two cocktails. I didn't have a chance to sample the oysters but would like to on another visit. There cocktails are shaken with love and care and the whole place has a cool speakeasy feel. Service around 4pm on a weekday was fast and affable.
author: Elisabeth B.

description: Warm, cozy bar reminiscent of earlier days. Good drinks served by friendly staff. This Sunday night featured an incredible musical act called Ms. Katy. Wow! What a big, easy, sultry voice! Great set list of her beautiful voice accompanied by her tickling the ivories. Perfect nightcap!
author: Eric A.

description:
Stopped by Comstock Saloon with my favorite girl with curls after a night of holiday party hopping.  We needed some substance to soak up some of the alcoholic libations in which we partook.  The beef shank & bone marrow pot-pie, arugula salad sounded like just the thing to settle down our tummies.  I guess the crust did the trick, but it was the saddest excuse for a pot-pie ever.  Pot-pies should have some savory gravy soupy stuff to complement succulent chunks of meats and vegetables.  There was no soup or gravy.  It was SO dry.

The only thing saving Comstock Saloon from 1 star after the disappointing pot-pie was the friendly efficiency of the hostess, and the clever skill of the bartender.  Next time, if I do stop by, it will just be for a drink.
author: Christina L.

description: Comstock is fantastic. I had the best Manhattan I've ever had outside of Manhattan, and for free no less, because they made one by mistake! I sat at the bar with a large group of people post a wedding rehearsal dinner, and watched the bartenders consistently make good strong balanced cocktails. They also have a bartenders choice that many of my friends opted for, the bartenders--despite being busy and crowded--listened to the likes and dislikes of their customers which left everyone very satisfied. In addition, this fully shiny wooden speakeasy bar really transports you back with a great combo band playing above in a balcony that overlooks the bar. The piano player/singer plus upright bass player were truly great. If I lived in San Fran, Id be here all the time.
author: A Z.

description:
I have been to Comstock many times and I must say they have decent cocktails and a fun saloon ambiance with delicious bites. Customer service tends to run a little slow so do not go here if you are looking for speedy service that gets you in and out.  Also...you will get treated much better if you say you are having food rather than just drinks.

I did want to yelp about the rude/awkward experience on 4/8/15 at around 9pm.  We arrived and asked for a table for the two of us.  There was a booth that just opened up and we were hoping to get it.  There was no wait, just us on a Tuesday night, and it looked like our wishes would be granted.  As the hostess approached she pointed to a table for two right by the door.  I asked her if we could have the booth instead because we didn't want to sit by the entrance door.  Her response was something along the lines of: "...but the door doesn't open very often and it is not very cold for it to be an issue."  Two things wrong here: 1) She assumed I was going to be cold when the issue was it was a squishy spot 2) There was a booth and no wait so why not a booth for us?  I looked at her and said, "So you're answer is 'no,' we cannot have a booth?"  She insisted that the table was fine, which we would have taken if there was a large party that needed it, but there was no one on the waitlist, just us.  The hostess then made an unhappy face and asked if we were just having drinks.  We advised we wanted have a meal with drinks.  This was when things shifted in our favor.  She happily sat us in that booth.  So lesson is: they don't really want to do much for you if you are just having drinks...but if you let them know you are having a a meal...customer service will increase by 100%.

I'm glad customer service got better when we said we were ordering food as our bill came out to about $125 for two people and at that price range, I believe good customer service  should come with it, right?
author: Tara K.

description:
The best food, cocktails and the friendliest staff, managers and owners!
I've been playing jazz there for 3 years and they have always been so sweet!
author: Caroline C.

description:
Nice venue. The waiter was very friendly and attentive.

They had a live band upstairs playing...they were okay. A girl walked around asking for donations for them, and when we declined, she made a snide comment. Other than that, I enjoyed myself.
author: Margaret R.

description: Was greeted immediately, food comes out right away. There was a very talented jazz band playing live. Servers are so friendly and they make this place a great experience. My water was never even half empty, our waiter and server checked us on frequently. Great for groups, dates, just a night out on the town. Definitely one of my favorite places in SF.
author: Jane H.

description: Charming, upscale bar with old-fashioned, Wild West decor in the shadow of the Transamerica Pyramid. Perhaps a bit hipster. Fancy cocktails, good oysters and pickled eggs, and friendly service. I'd like to go back and sit at the bar in the back room.
author: P S.

description:
An awesome watering hole in North Beach with live jazz and bartenders who make an excellent Manhattan and Sazerac.  My first encounter with a Blood & Sand here was a most pleasant one with firm maple and peat from the scotch brightened by acidity from some orange.

The ambiance brings you straight back to the old days with a classic saloon vibe and surprisingly manageable noise levels on a Saturday night.  My friends and I kicked back at one of the tables near the front and great times were had all around.
author: Eric F.

description:
Great San Francisco saloon with loads of history and decor to match.

The bartender Jeff was most impressive and made one unique drink with vinegar and some special chocolate concoction....man, it was tasty. The partner loved it. Real talent, this one has. So, sidle yourself up to the bar and enjoy the drinks and soak in the history.
author: May T.

description: We came here to check out the band Gaucho. The bar has a great old school atmosphere.  The band provided a feeling of relief getting to the end of a long Monday night with a solid drink in hand. For a Monday night it's a perfect escape bar and we will be back.
author: Theresa N.

description:
Four solid stars.  The food is good; the drinks are great.  Friendly staff, fantastic bartenders, what more do you need?.

I've had the barkeep's whimsy a few times, and I've been very happy (the bartender decides what drink to make).

The place might seem a bit fancy at first, but is casual enough to feel welcomed and comfortable.
author: Justin M.

description:
The food was pretty good and the drinks and ambiance were nice. The service initially left me feeling like we weren't entirely welcome, which was disappointing, although by the end of our visit we appeared to win over our waitress and our experience improved from there.

One weird thing -- the server and host kept taking all the menus from us.  They have really unusual food/drinks so it was taking us a little while to figure out our order, and every few minutes someone would pop over and try to take the menus, even though we kept telling them we were still working out what we wanted. We ended up getting 5+ drinks and two appetizers, so we certainly weren't wasting their time or table space.

If I worked there, I'd want to encourage customers to browse. We had originally planned on ordering apps/meals for everyone, only when they kept trying to take the menus from us we finally decided to only order enough food to hold us over to the next place, where we took our time and chose what we wanted.

Glad we had the experience, though next time I'm in town we will probably try some other places.
author: Carlene G.

description:
Braised Beef Shank and Bone Marrow Pot Pie.

I would drive from LA to have this for dinner.  The Manhattan's are also awesome.


.....that's it.
author: Ryan K.

description:
Darbys all the way! Love the cocktails here and the vibe is pretty damn awesome. Saturday nights involve a good jazz band and its the best thing to unwind.

Its loud in here, so don't expect to come in with friends and have a conversation. However, be assured, you'll have a GREAT time!
author: Akshaya M.

description: Comstock is a gorgeous gem.  My Honey and I found this place after walking uncountable blocks searching cool place to hang, we're so glad made a stop here. We came for a drink, we're both had Bourbon Crusta. It was great. All the barenders are very knowledgeable about drinks. We did again another stop on the next day here before heading home, New York.
author: Bonjel N.

description: Awful service on New Year Eve!!! Extremely rude bartenders! They didn't announce closing time and than said finish your cocktail, which I bought a minute ago and grabbed it from my hands not letting me to finish it!
author: Kosta M.

description: I stumbled onto this place with my beau one New Year's Eve shortly after they opened and was completely charmed by it. The old time saloon thing in the beautiful historical building is recreated beautifully and you can see why it was used for this in the first place. Great music coming from a balcony above the diners, beautiful and right decor, and excellent food. I remember chicken livers from a visit past standing out. This time a mushroom pot pie and a roast chicken smothered in spring vegetables were impeccable. I had a great time all over again! With my beau again
author: Shelley M.

description:
Tip: make a reservation! This place was packed for a Sunday night. There was a DJ and it felt like I was at Disneyland with the theme. The pot pie was very disappointing because it was so dry and not creamy... $20!! The mac n cheese was a yummier version of Kraft. The chicken and waffles were delish.

Cocktails are a must and they have a lot of old man drinks of gin and whisky! The waiter was very classy and knowledgeable. Biscuits were amazing!
author: Joleen Q.

description:
Whoever coined the phrase, "There's no such thing as a free lunch," has clearly never been to Comstock Saloon!

Every Friday, they offer a delicious meal on the house with the purchase of two drinks. And I do mean an honest-to-goodness meal. This is not some sad deli sandwich thrown together carelessly. It is chef's whim, however, so there's only one option per week. 

On this particular Friday, my girlfriend and I were delighted to try the "bunny in a bun" which is a cute name for what turned out to be a rabbit salad, lightly dressed with currants and served on a toasted brioche bun, with a frisee salad on the side. If you've never had rabbit, just know that it doesn't really taste like chicken (our waiter described it as being more similar to dark meat turkey, which makes sense to me). And most importantly, this was a really excellent sandwich. If they offered this on the regular lunch menu, I'd totally order it again!

I also thoroughly enjoyed the special house cocktails ... I started with cherry bounce (the brandy soaked cherries are a delightful garnish) and followed up with the shotgun wedding (very minty & refreshing).

Service was impeccable and our waiter made excellent recommendations as well. All in all, Comstock Saloon offers a great deal when you consider the quality of the meal and drinks, but it's not an everyday lunch spot either unless you're taking advantage of a company expense account...or indulge part in 2-cocktail lunches on the regular ;) But absolutely worth the splurge for a special lunch to wind down the week!
author: Jenny N.

description: Great cocktails.  Staff was friendly and we got an amazing education on Absinthe from the owner.  Interior design was nice and fitting with the saloon theme from their name.  Would definitely go back again for drinks.
author: Colin M.

description:
Left Comstock Saloon last night in pure bliss. We stopped in after dinner for a nightcap, and little did we know, dessert and the entire experience was divine.  I can't wait to come back for dinner.

We sat at the bar and enjoyed two cocktails, we let the bartender choose our drinks which worked out well.  We ended up with the Pisco Punch and the Blood & Sand, both very refreshing and tasty.   

We split the Bourbon Pudding which left me scraping the sides of the dish.  My only issue was the carmel seemed to harden and was hard to chew, but it wouldn't stop me from ordering another one. 

I'm chomping at the bit to make it in for dinner!
author: Brianna M.

description:
My friend saw Bourdain's layover show and wanted to check out Comstock. Even though I was on a 21 day cleanse, my curiosity was piqued so our game plan was to stay for a drink and revisit when the cleanse was over.

First time isn't always the best-We walked up and found seats at the bar. No wait is pretty sweet. Comstock has a whimsical atmosphere, live jazz musicians and bartenders in suspenders. While my friends tasted various concoctions that the bartender whipped up on the fly, I sat there with my pot of herbal tea. Lesson learned, never ever order herbal tea at a bar cause I was super duper sober as everyone had a merry old time! 

Second time is the charm-this time, detox begone. We greeted our bartender with delight (or I did) and she proceeded to create drinks for us. Definitely try the shotgun wedding, it's refreshingly good. The crowd is mellow and there is quaint fireplace in the back.

Overall-chill vibe, live performances on the second floor, friendly courteous bartenders, strong flavorful drinks, and big clean bathrooms without a long wait.
author: Sophie C.

description:
Listen, don't come here. That way, I'll always have a table I can get to without waiting. Drinks are excellent, the bourbon pudding was spot on, and did I mention the drinks. Also, the drinks are good. 

So, stay away.
author: Dave W.

description: Awesome food even better atmosphere. Old time feel. I would definitely recommend trying if you get a chance.
author: Chris W.

description:
5 stars for impeccable, very fast service, being able to bring menus/take orders and then leave you alone until your glass needs to be refreshed, being surprisingly full on a Monday night (who would have thought?!), fun decor/atmosphere, and a cool band. 
HOWEVER - minus points for:
the band is super loud if you're sitting in the wrong part. i didn't know that they were going to play, so it was a bit weird when all of a sudden i found myself yelling across the table to continue our casual date conversation. the band also walks around asking for tips after, which is just awkward. this is not the church passed collection basket.
author: Shanna C.

description:
I'm a young guy in the market for first date spots, and sometimes second date spots too...if I'm lucky!

Comstock Saloon has the ammunition for both! The first thing you notice about this place, is it's truly a Western style saloon made for the modern man and woman. The employees are dressed in Steampunk, the furniture is antique, and the drinks are unique-ish. They pay homage to prohibition era cocktails, which is cool and makes it easy to choose. It's all very fun!

This time, I was on a platonic date with a gal pal and we got nice and buzzed at the bar. The place had great vibes and awesome Western style live music in one of those old fashioned elevated boxes. For a Tuesday, it was one of the hippest spots in the neighborhood, and it's perfect for service industry folks!

I may have been intoxicated...by my experience there, but I think the bartender offered me tequila from the tap. I respectfully declined and ordered the pretzel off the snacks list. The spicy mustard and chunky cheese made it the perfect nosh to get me back in the game!

Overall, we had a great time at Comstock. I will certainly be back with a hot date if they keep those awesome propeller-looking ceiling fans turning!
author: Cory N.

description:
Went here for a casual drink on a Tuesday night and was pleasantly surprised by how great the vibe is at Comstock! There was a live jazz band playing on the second level (right above our table). Service was fantastic. 

I got the cherry bounce. Yum! Will definitely be back.
author: Vivian N.

description:
One of my most loved bars in San Francisco.

Low lighting, old school ceiling fans which inspire images of an old school, steam punk world. 

Actually, the whole bar kind of has a steam punk feeling to it, the bar tenders dress in old timey clothes, think suspenders, think bowties, and the jazz band playing in the background helps to set the mood.

Drinks are incredible. Do yourself a favor and order one of their specialty drinks, you won't regret it.

Only downside, with many bars here in the city, is it is very small. Which means that if you plan on visiting here with a larger group, it might be a little packed.

But makes an AWESOME date spot. Seriously men, she will text you the next day if you take her here.
author: Jenny U.

description: This place is something else (in a good way). DJ spinning 'retro-country' (is that even a thing?), solid snacks, better than average drink selection, super friendly service... What's not to like?
author: Carlos E.

description: Crowd here is sometimes a bit older than some of the places in the area, which means it's a little more civilized. Good quality drinks and bar food in a nice setting. This would be a good place to meet for a date or catch up with friends after work.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
Came here for cocktails with a friend after seeing a play by 42nd St. Moon at the Eureka Theatre. We walked in and it was exactly what we were hoping for: good ambiance, live music, unique and classic decor, and a spot where we could sit at a table and enjoy our drinks and talk. We sat in the little room next to the bar, perfect for hearing the music but able to hear each other too.

Cocktails had were as follows
Saint's Buck: Perfect. Everything I was hoping for, would definitely order it again.
Hop Toad: Not quite what we expected. Didn't taste the rum at all, I think maybe some extra bitters jumped in or something..
Sidecar: Hard to mess a sidecar up, and it definitely did not disappoint. Delicious.
French 75: Tasty, though my friend would have preferred it a little more French and a little less 75.

We also tried the pig in a biscuit, which was three biscuits with little pork patties in them. They were nice and savory, though we couldn't quite figure out what the patties were made of..

Everyone working there was fun and welcoming. We stayed 'til closing and enjoyed every minute. We will definitely be back. :)
author: Kari E.

description:
easily and infinitely the best cocktails in san francisco.  reminded me of my favourite prohibition-era lounges in san diego.  been looking for a place like this in a historical part of the city (:

Comstock is a great for large and small groups.  I've been here with 20+ people, and I've been here with 2 people.  there's enough seating / standing room for whatever type of group you want.  

it gets difficult ordering at the bar sometimes because the drinks take quite a while to make, but they're worth it!   if you don't want to wait at a bar, sit at one of the booths or couches to get service from one of the waitresses walking around - they're a lot faster!

chat up some tourists if you want to kill time while waiting because there WILL be tourists.  the bartenders are also great to talk to if they're not busy.  they know a thing or two or a million about drinks... unlike some bartenders at bourbon & branch or local edition that I've talked to...

definitely coming back.  I've been thinking about renting out this place for my 25th birthday...
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Our new favorite bar in SF. The cocktails are terrific, the atmosphere friendly and fun, the music great, and excellent food. What's not to like? Try the Martinez cocktail (or any other) and the mushroom pot pie - fabulous. There's also some Bourbon custardy dessert that is to die for. A little rich, surprise.

This is billed as located in Chinatown. It's actually on the North Beach-Chinatown border.
author: Susan B.

description:
Trekked over to this establishment inspired by Bourdain's visit during his stay in the city.  Being a whiskey drinker, I initially intended just to grab some drinks and perhaps maybe a quick appetizer.  I ended up doing the reverse.

My friends and I decided to have a sit down meal.  Luckily for us they were able to accomodate a group of 7 without any reservations.  I quickly ordered their happy hour special consisting of a whiskey shot with a beer on the side for only $6.  The menu was small which is actually a good thing sometimes.  It allows the restaurant to focus on what it does well.  This was proven on this occasion.

I split the shrimp & oyster po'boy entree along with a breakfast biscuit dish with a pork patty reminiscent of scrapple.  The po'boy was reasonably priced at $15 for a quality sandwich.  The biscuit dish only had three minuscule slider sized sandwiches which was good but much smaller than expected.  

I think it's worth a second visit, next time concentrating more on the cocktails.
author: Stephen V.

description: Staff is very rude and stuck up. Tried this place two different times and same thing. Drinks are over priced. There's better places to go where they make you feel welcome.
author: Mike M.

description: This place plays music loud and late. I live right above it and they have no respect for the people that live near them. They should be more courteous of the people that surround them. This is a community and they obviously don't care about the people around d them. It makes you wonder how much they care about their customers.
author: Chris S.

description:
Such a wonderful find north of SF Chinatown, amid such a plethora of solid bar choices for those fancy nights out on the town! Comstock has that 1920s flair, with a live jazz band playing on the 2nd floor balcony, and a large bar filled with all sorts of liquors and drinks. The layout of the place is a bit odd, as it's split in half: on one side it's a lively bar section, and the other is more of a "quieter" restaurant section. Granted, you can order food on the bar side, but it can get really crowded during the evening with everyone wanting their drinks before delighting in conversation and fesetivities!

I came here with a couple of friends, and we were lucky to find an open table that seated all of us. They have a pretty good list of beers and mixed drinks, and our waiter recommended we tell her what we liked...so the bartender could surprise us. I went for a Belgium beer, but one of my friends went for the surprise. Needless to say, the bartender surely delivered!

Coming here for the first time, I really have to tip my hat to the musicians that evening: Citizen's Jazz! Such amazing jazz play, creating such a lively atmosphere! Apparently they have gigs all over the SF region, and I'm not surprised why...they're really good!

Well, I'm definitely keeping Comstock on my list of favorite bars in the SF area. Great drinks + lively ambiance + good friends = an amazing night!
author: Kevin J.

description:
Great place - I love the atmosphere and the cherry drink (cherry bounce maybe) I had was fantastic.

However, the wait staff was rude - kind of like Dick's Last Resort (not that bad, but along those lines). We couldn't tell if they were doing on purpose or we just happened to get two bad servers. One friend has a glutten allergy and the waiter was very condescending to her.

I would go again but only if the service is friendlier.
author: Colin FX G.

description:
Serendipity struck a few months ago in the form of Comstock. I had just finished my binge marathon of Deadwood when I read about a new throwback bar on the Barbary Coast.  I was ready to party like it was 1847, and I did not have to travel to frontier country to do so.

Unfortunately there weren't any Calamity Jane types here, but the vibe was mellow and I loved that there is a piano player nestled in a small nook upstairs, and I think he bore a slight resemblance to Wild Bill Hickcock. The restored bar is stunning; actually the interior is impeccable, and much more inviting than the ruffian Gem Saloon.

The cocktails, while artisan crafted and beautiful, offer the potency that you need after a long day of gunslinging and bounty hunting. The sazerac was probably the best I've had outside the Big Easy, and wow, the handlebar mustachioed bartender did not skimp on the hooch. A novelty for me was the Hop Toad, a combination of Jamaican rum, apricot brandy, lime, and bitters that is reputed to be a San Francisco original from the turn of the century.

I probably should have tried some of the food, as I needed it and it made me salivate, especially the bone marrow. I'll don my Calamity Jane sass and come back for more!
author: Joanna M.

description:
I give 1 star only because 0 was not an option. I came here with my boyfriend and his family for NYE dinner. They had only a prix fixe menu for the night. It was so fixed that you couldn't even order the ribeye on the menu to your liking.  Every course was very very small (with the exception of the main course) and each course took a minimum of 30 minutes to come out. Our dinner took over 2 hours from the moment we sat down at our table to the moment we finished dessert and received our bill. 

However, the worst part of the whole meal was when we complained to the manager as to how slow the meal took and how we wanted to leave in the middle of the meal (paying of course for what we have ate). Instead of being understanding and trying to provide good customer service, the manager scalded me and told me I was in the wrong. I have never had someone be so rude and abrupt with me!!!  Out of everything that evening he was the one who ruined my meal and my appetite. 

Needless to say I will never be eating here again.  Not because of the slowness of the meal, but solely because of the way I was treated as a paying customer by the manager.
author: Rose Z.

description: I stop at this bar a few times a month on my walk home from FiDi.  The bar has great saloon vibe and decor.  Impeccable service with a smile, amazing drinks (bartenders really know their spirits), live jazz music on certain evenings, and the the lamb meatballs are a must try!  This is a chill saloon on the Chinatown/North beach Columbus ave strip where locals and tourist mingle whilst sipping finely crafted cocktails.
author: Justina L.

description:
Came in on a Monday night so we didn't need a reservation. The place is decorated really well and has a great ambience, feels like a nice cozy place to grab a drink and something to eat. 

We ordered a few appetizers and an entree to split. The tater tots were nice and the pork sliders on biscuits were great as well. Just a heads up though - the sliders came out right off the stove and when I took a bite, really hot oil/juices squirted out and kind of scalded my hand, so maybe let the sliders sit for a bit before you take a bite. Despite the too hot juices, the sliders were delicious. 

In addition to the two appetizers we got the duck pot pie, which was scrumptious. It was a great hearty dish but with just the right portion size so we didn't feel uncomfortably full despite the two starchy/meaty appetizers we'd gotten. We ate every bite of everything we ordered!

For drinks we tried the Pisco Punch and the Cherry Bounce, both of which were great. My favorite was the Bartenders Choice, where the bartender mixes you a drink of his choosing. Unfortunately I don't remember what was in it. They also had some live music going which was great.

This is a great place to come with a date or a few friends to have a drink and some good, quality (but not fussy) food. Perfect for a midweek pick me up but also great for a weekend.
author: Yishian Y.

description: I went to this saloon, with a group of 10+ people, for an after party work event and one of the female servers who works there came up to us and was incredibly hostile and rude. We had been there for a matter of 5 minutes and we were being polite and just wanted to stop by and get some drinks, but the moment she approached us she was so unwelcoming and had no etiquette of any kind so we left. After leaving we went to another saloon up the street where the server was incredibly nice and treated us with the respect that every patron deserves. Too bad the service was so bad at Comstock because we are a bunch of business professionals in the area and we were hoping to make this one of our after work spots. Thank goodness we still have the amazing place up the street.
author: Letisha C.

description:
I met my gf Priya here for lunch..and was delighted by the food! 

We both ordered off the Prix Fixe menu- 

We both got he pork and hominy soup, I got the mushroom and asparagus panini and she got the oyster po'boy. Our plan was to share. 

The soup was slow cooked to perfection--big chunky pieces of pulled pork, hominy, and sprinkled with some picked cabbage. The panini was okay, but the po'boy was out of this world. The big pieces of oyster were fried with light cornmeal batter. Dressed with ketchup and a Delicious cole slaw. It was worth the calories splurge. I had to rush back to work so we ended up taking our dessert to go-Boubon pudding. I didn't get to try it but am sure it was Delicious! 

Everyone in the Fidi should come here for lunch!
author: Mimi T.

description: Great place for a drink. I had a glass of wine. My friend has a cocktail. She won. Stop by and have one of their friendly bar tenders spin something up for you.
author: Julie K.

description:
The Good: Lovely decor/atmosphere, great roast chicken, attentive bus staff (our water glasses were always full), reasonably priced.  

The Bad: Everything from a glass of wine, to a cocktail, to a plate of oysters, to a hamburger took much too long: 10-15mins for a drink, close to an hour between courses. The place is crowded and insanely loud, making it hard to get anyone's attention (except the great bus people who seem to be everywhere).  The food was decent, but not great (except for the fab roast chicken), not really worth the wait.   After 2+hrs we were dying to get out of there, making the finale all the more frustrating. As we were waiting for our bill (I had to literally reach out of the booth and grab a server who wasn't ours as he walked by) the nice hostess came over and asked if we needed anything else because she needed our table.  Uh...are you serious?  We had to wait a ridiculous amount of time for everything and then we were asked to hurry up and go. Give me a break. 

The Ugly: Is it a bar or a restaurant? A tall, gruff gentleman (manager?) told many of us, as we tried to fight the crowd to get to our table, that it is a restaurant.  I understand that they serve food, but if you're going to *insist* that you're a "restaurant" then there needs to be a MUCH greater focus on customer enjoyment/comfort. 
We were not allowed to keep food menus at the table because they "are paper and they'll get ruined". And though the cocktail menus are bound ("in leather, so please be careful") we couldn't keep one of them either because there were not enough to go around. Huh?   
The live music is a nice touch and very good but the volume level is *ridiculous* for a meal (we were screaming at each other).  As was the fact that one of musicians came to our table, plopped down a big tip jar and stood there until we put money into it.  It was bizarre and awkward and not what I'm looking for at dinner. We asked him if it was possible to turn down the volume and I could swear it actually got louder.  It's also unfortunate that staff members (ala tall, gruff guy) clap extremely loudly at the end of each song and give patrons the stink eye if they don't also. So we're supposed to stop our conversations to acknowledge the band every few minutes? 
Once again, I am at a restaurant or at a bar/club? Everything about the place, including the level and type of customer focus/service, makes it feel like a bar. 

So, if you're looking for a lovely, lively, loud bar that serves decent food and cocktails (and you're not in a rush) then I'd recommend Comstock.  If you're looking for a restaurant experience I'd suggest you go elsewhere.
author: Ellen H.

description: My favorite place to start out in North Beach. Great cocktails, great food, great ambiance, excellent patrons, and all under the watchful eye of the Emperor.
author: J. W.

description: Am I getting jaded??  Have I lived in San Francisco too long?  Something about this place... it felt just a little too showy for my taste.  You know how you can go into a person's home and just be able to tell that it was decorated by a professional, and it can come off as being a little too contrived?  Well, that's the way I felt walking in here.  It just strikes me as being too themey.  Granted, an expensive theme bar, but still.  In my Yelp book, it is A-OK.
author: Chloe M.

description:
DRINK:
1.) Bartender's Whimsey! - I don't remember what he concocted for me exactly but it was a whiskey based drink and it was pretty strong yet delish! Great choice, bartender.

They do have food here which I was eyeing- but will probably get a pot pie next time if anything. Didn't see much I really wanted to eat though. But I do love the atmosphere enough to come back and enjoy :D

SERVICE:
pleasant bartenders ;P


ATMOSPHERE:
So cuuute. love this place. Live music every day at 8pm, makes me think I ought to be handed a cork gun to shoot at the salooon items like at a carnival. lol. Old belt propelled fans on the top, and generally old feel. In the divide of where North Beach, Chinatown, Fidi, and Broadway all meet so the neighborhood is a very interesting place to meander around too :)
author: Angela L.

description: Very disappointed in this place. We walked in at 5pm on a Friday and they were slow. Service was horrendous. Our server was very rude and ignored us for 15 minutes so we got up and left.  Won't be going back.
author: Kaitlin S.

description: Waiter was extremely rude last night and told our group to "shut the f*** up." I don't care if we were being loud, that's not how you talk to people. We left him a poor tip for his rudeness and he then chased us down the street when we left. Definitely never going back after having been here a few time.
author: Patrick W.

description:
Bartenders with personality who make great drinks & don't mind that the customers are just chilling at the bar and slowly sipping on their drinks? Plus, awesome decor and a pretty cool mix of regulars, tourists, and individuals who are there to spend some time eating/drinking/reading by themselves? Love. 

Rather small, but awesome. We didn't make a reservation or have a wait. Went during a weekday and it was a calm crowd of small groups or individuals. Wish I could remember more so that I could rave about the place (its been awhile since i was there), but it wouldve been an injustice if i didnt write a review simply to say DEFINITELY GIVE COMSTOCK A TRY and give it four stars. (when, upon my return, i try the food and its mouthwatering, comstock will certainly be receiving five stars).
author: Stephanie H.

description: There was a big sign out front advertising Cold A** Beers. They only had two on tap. Worse beer I've ever had. 7 buck Anchor Steam was flat and stale. Not even a pint. Wife had house wine, 10 bucks for a three ounce pour. Would never come back. Wish I had walked past it.
author: Scott F.

description:
I came here to meet two old friends, within hours of getting off a plane from my current hometown of London. I hadn't had a real meal in about a day, and I was running on empty energy-wise, but I was still distracted by my dissatisfaction with the food. It could be that my tastebuds were off after all the travel, but one of my dining companions shared similar thoughts without my prompting.

The brasserie-style elegance and the confidently comforting service hit its marks, saving this review from being two stars, but leading me to expect similar attention to the execution of the menu. We shared a solid sardine starter, with a satisfying balance of fishiness and tartness. The pretzel, apparently famous, failed to impress me--I'm a fan of anything doughy, but I didn't get why this dough was good enough to make into its own dish. I love avocado, but the bread in the "Alligator Pear" toast was so charred as to taste irrevocably burnt. 

I'd forgive these starter slight missteps for a good oyster po' boy--indeed, I'd forgive a lot of things for a crusty loaf overloaded with crisp lettuce and fat oysters. Instead, I got a plate of salt, from which I eventually just picked out the few shriveled (and oversalted) oysters and left the rest. I know I'm more sensitive to salt than most, but I couldn't handle this--even the salad tasted salty to me. 

Comstock Saloon, for all its charms, has left me bitter.
author: Alice S.

description:
The moment you walk into this spot you're transported into another time. You half expect a wells fargo stage coach to pass the windows of this bar up. When you look and see a bus pass by then you're reminded that you're not in the 1800's San Francisco anymore and perhaps you should stop calling that Asian fella a Chinaman. 

Dude, chinaman is not the preferred nomenclature.

The bartenders have a specific uniform here that really goes on to sell the theme and the era just right. You look up and see those old fashion fans working on a small motor and you just get pulled into it further. 

And if you haven't been convinced that you traveled in time, the menu and the drinks they serve, especially how they hand craft those mixed drinks will just push you through that immersion wall and contemplate finding a settlement to go gold mining after this next drink. 

They do have a happy hour that I highly recommend hitting up. Prices are fairly cheap and for S.F., it's a pretty decent bargain. You're also treated to some really social conversation from your bartender as the joint isn't completely filled. It helps that they'll mix you a fairly potent drink to get your late afternoon going just right.
author: Javier J.

description: Great wooden bar with live music and a knowlegeable barman! Had an excellent cocktail from the menu and tasted my first, deliciuos, Pisco Punch!
author: Marc N.

description: Meh...it was good..not great. If I was walking by and hungry or thirsty I would stop here again. So if you're standing out front reading this rest assured the place is clean and decent. I only had a burger and beer and my husband had fish with succotash which was just ok. A very small portion though for the $$. The warm olive app was surprisingly good. Good place to people watch.
author: j K.

description: Great bar/restaurant keeping with the turn-of-the-century style. Awesome cocktails, artfully prepared & reasonably priced for the work needed to create and spirits used to produce. I didn't have anything to eat, but the bar menu looked awesome too. We'll definitely be back :-)
author: David C.

description:
On a street filled with touristy Italian restaurants that all serve just about the same generic menu you find the Comstock Saloon. Old booths. A host that greets you and assists in finding you a seat at the bar or one of the private booths. The bartenders are skilled. They make a great cocktails. Fun to watch them make it if you are at the bar. 

I had the sazerac which is my go to drink and it was very well done.

Great place for quality cocktails and good conversation in a place that is upscale without feeling upscale.
author: John T.

description: Yummy, handmade old fashions! They just don't use solid ice cubes...they're hollow. :(
author: Audrey C.

description:
My first time at Comstock was your average San Franciscan Friday night.

When we arrived (still early), there was a live jazz band playing upstairs. They added to the very cool, hip vibe - a little more casual and a whole lot less exclusive than Bourbon and Branch.

I've noticed that other reviewers have said this is a good place for groups. I think this might depend on the time of night. There's a big area with various forms of seating toward the back. However, the rest of the bar is booths that fit maybe 4 people per side. We came with a rather large group of around 15, and this made seating difficult. We ended up squishing 5 people per side of the booth, and everyone else stood around the end. Regardless of the ruckus we caused, our waiter was quite pleasant and took our orders very quickly. He remained attentive and witty throughout the night.

The bartenders themselves knew how to make a great drink. Try the Saint's Buck - it looks like a girly drink (yes, it has ginger beer), but it's actually quite strong. The brandy adds a bite. Three of us in our party tried the Manhattan - it was smooth and worthy of its fame.

My favorite part of the night was ordering my Pimm's cup! For $10, you get a beer mug full of Pimm's, soda, and an extra shot of gin. The garnishes were over-the-top. The entire group thought it looked great. It tasted pretty good as well.

The crowd was a little bit older than your typical North Beach night scene. It seems like a great place to meet a few friends for drinks, or maybe start out your night.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
I do not know how Wed has become the "Let's go to the city!" night but alas recently that's the way it goes. There's just something about hump day that gets people in the mood to... oh I digressed... back to the review... 

We were at a not to be mentioned club and it was loud, the patrons were annoying to say the least. I feel like I have to be in the mood for loud obnoxious dance music nowadays, so I decided to consult my trusty Yelp bookmarks for something a little more low key. 

And off we were to this saloon in the Financial District. A friend had said this was a good place to take someone for conversation, drinks and a decent bite to eat.

Upon seeing the sign, it was like "YES" I want to be here. Fine typography on a old fashioned wooden sign. Simple and understated.

The bar was moderately full with a relaxed but older crowd, luckily there was a booth open. We sad down and I ordered a Pisco Punch, I actually forgot what concoction PY ordered, but remembered that it was tasty. Lighting low and and old fashioned leaf fan contraption lazily spun along the ceiling. The classic candle sconce that lit our table was just so right. 

We also split both desserts which can be served all day. Maple bourbon pudding, shortbread and chocolate and pecan tart, coffee cream. The bourbon pudding was sublime for my tastes as I love bourbon. 

There was also an area with Victorian chaises in the corner near a fireplace. The bathroom had medicine bags to hold the toilet paper. Really perfect details. People might find this place a little boring, but I liked it. I don't need it to be popping, I just want to spend some quiet time talking with the people that make me smile.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Place is way too small to let all people, who really wants to spend their time, come in.. 
But if you got into it - you're lucky! It's worth it!
Amazing cocktails, cozy/warm atmosphere, good live music - it'll be the best decision to take your girlfriend/bestie to :)
author: Olga B.

description:
Have been here twice, for birthday dinners both times.  There is a lot to like about this place.

First of all, drinks are solid.  I am a diehard beer guy so it takes a bit of effort for me to get a cocktail instead, but I figure when in Rome, right?  So I got the Barkeeper's Whimsy and they whipped me up this awesome drink...forget all the ingredients, but it definitely had bourbon, ginger beer, and mint.  One of the tastiest drinks I've had in a while.

The appetizers are all astounding.  The rabbit three ways is by far my favorite...so good, and worth the splurge.  Easily sharable.  The mashed potato tots are also excellent.

The entrees have been good, but I've never been blown away by them like I have with the drinks and appetizers.  Might be the type of place to come with a date and split a couple apps and drinks at the bar.

Really, really solid little spot.
author: James S.

description:
First Impressions: Very nice little place near the Financial District. Nice service, great looking bar, and fast drinks. 

Service: I met up with my wife and her company at the place for a couple of after work drinks. The service was attentive and helpful. We were kind of a rowdy bunch, but they were nice enough to squish the 11-13 of us into the place. 

Drinks/food: The drink special of the night was a shot of Burbon(can't remember which one) and a half pint of Anchor Steam. For a guy who doesn't like Burbon, this was some smooooooooth shot. I got the house burger which was juicy and all of the right spices to make it tasty. Overall I was impressed with the quality of the food and drink here. I wish I had had a chance to get some of their specialty drinks(but it was a work function).

Overall: 4.0 stars. great food and drinks. Good service. I hope to try some of their Old Fashioned drinks next time.
author: Chris D.

description:
This review is only for the bar. 

Came here on a Thursday night after eating at The House (which I recommend). A friend and I were walking by and heard live jazz from within which drew us in. Stood at the bar (there were no stools left) and ordered a Manhattan and a Pisco Sour. I'm used to to being asked how I want my Manhattan made and with which whiskey but the bartender skipped that and just made me one straight up. I asked him to then pour it on the rocks. He obliged and was very pleasant about it. 

Unless you sit at the bar, the space around it is sort of limited as the waiters have to walk back and forth through there. 

Besides that, the live music, lighting, and strong drinks make this place a great spot to chill. Very charming and I would definitely come back and give their food a try based on my limited experience there.
author: Matt O.

description: They only have one type of oysters which were very fresh but small. Bartenders know what they are doing and the ambiance is nice. It's a nice place to go stop by after work and spend some time with friends for happy hour.
author: Gokhan T.

description:
Amazing cocktails.  Best Sazerac in the city (better than Bourbon and Branch, Alembic or the back bar at Rickhouse...which we also just happened to be at this same weekend).

What? Don't judge.  We just needed to make absolutely sure.

And the live music Friday perfect fit the scene.

I only wish this place had more room to move/socialize.

As such, it remains a better place to "take" a date than to necessarily "meet" one.

OR a place to start the night with your wingmen and map our your 'game' plan.
author: Mike V.

description:
Been here many times and the drinks are obviously some of the best in the area. However, the kitchen ain't no joke either. A friend of mine was the chef for a while and he really knocked the menu out of the park. Some of my favorites were the 
Cheddar-mustard crackers with pepper jelly, Duck liver mousse with pickled cherry-ramp relish, Pig in a biscuit (crispy pork, homemade biscuits, cole slaw), The rabbit 3-way (celery salad & pepper vinegar chicken-fried, crispy rillette toast, terrine). All good things must come to an end however, and I've heard the menu will be changing with the change in chef. Fingers crossed!
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Great cocktails!

Nice atmosphere.  Gets really packed, but the band playing on the upstairs stage makes it worth it.  Plan to be crowded unless you have reservations or get here early.

Haven't tried food here.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Your jalapeno corn fritters saved you, Comstock Saloon.

Otherwise you would've had 1 measly star.  And I would've had to badmouth you all over town, but I can't.  Because of your fritters.

Coworkers and I were hungry and wanted a drink after work on a Friday.  We walked to Enrico's only to find that there was a private event going on, and that they wouldn't be open til 8:30.  8:30!!  It was only 5:30, and we wanted fuud.  Stat.

So we walked around the corner and saw a few empty tables at Comstock Saloon, a place none of us had ever been.  We were seated right away after telling the host that we were expecting 4-6 people (there were only 2 of us at first).  He said sure, and then gave us a table for 4, telling us that he could add on chairs later.  Happy hour drink special was $6 for a beer and shot, but they only had 3 choices.

The two of us ordered drinks: a South Side (like a very minty mojito) for her and a Pisco Punch for me.  We were joined shortly by two others, and one had a Sierra Nevada and the other a Grey Goose Pineapple.  All the drinks (besides the beer) were really, really, REALLY strong.  Ick.  We're no strangers to alcohol, but none of us could handle my Pisco Punch (which, when made correctly, is very delicious).  Even the Grey Goose Pineapple was primarily vodka.

When another person showed up, we pulled a chair from the neighboring table, which was empty.  A few minutes later, the host came back to tell us that we couldn't just start pulling chairs because there would be none for the other table.  Um, okay.. like you have no other chairs for the invisible people?  Awesome.
