We decided to order the jalapeno corn fritters, and there were about 6 in each order.  Fried to perfection and drizzled with lime juice, they were heavenly with the way-too-strong drinks.  Two of my coworkers ordered another drink, and after they didn't show up for 20 minutes, we asked a different waiter, who was bringing a drink for someone else, where ours were.  He asked us when we ordered it, to which we responded, "20 minutes ago."

"They're coming out."
"Can you please check on it for us?  It's been 20 minutes and we haven't gotten the drinks."
"Once we put it in the computer it's made."
"Well, we feel like this is a valid concern - we have been waiting 20 minutes for two drinks."
"Look.  There are 10 of us bartenders and we're trying to make drinks for 50 people."

And with that, he walked away.  Excuse me??  No, you are not trying to make drinks for 50 people ALL AT ONCE because the tables aren't even filled up.  And what is WITH THE ATTITUDE?

We decided to order another thing of fritters, plus the pig in a biscuit, and the Picnic Plate, which consisted of toasted bread, some ham, a bean salad, "cole slaw," a small scoop of pate, and three cherries.  Luckily these came out pretty quickly.

After the two drinks finally arrived, we noticed that one of them was in a smaller glass than the other one, yet they were charging the same price.  Another coworker ordered another drink, and again it took more than 15 minutes, and we had to flag down another waiter to get the status check.

The host came back and told us that we couldn't keep pulling chairs (there were 6 of us now), even though the waitress gave us an extra one.  We told him that there was no one at the other table, and that one of us would be leaving soon, so the other table could have the chair back.  The host kept giving us attitude about not taking another chair.  LIKE YOU DON'T HAVE ANY OTHER CHAIRS, SRSLY?

The picnic plate was probably the worst thing I had in a long time (next to the time I found dead moths in my box of cereal that had been opened for a few months).  The bread slices were small, the ham was overly cured and tasted like a way-too-salty prosciutto, and the cole slaw was pretty much a very sour, salty cabbage.  The bean salad lacked flavor, and seriously, three cherries?  I didn't bother eating them.

I peaced out of here before the bill arrived (don't worry, I paid my share!) and decided that I would never, ever come back, except maybe to order some fritters to-go.  NONE of us could finish my drink because it was so awful - way WAY too strong.  Everyone else's drinks were overly strong too, but not as strong as mine.  I hate leaving anywhere unsatisfied to that extent, because in this case, it wasn't just the drinks and some of the food that sucked, it was the service too.

Completely and utterly disappointing for such a cute little place.
author: Tori S.

description: Cool spot to have a drink! We went in during happy hour and had a Boot to the Head and a Derby. Both were awesome! I loved the dark, old-time interior.
author: Irma D.

description:
Classy joint with an old San Francisco feel.  Came here for a drink before heading elsewhere to dinner, but when I saw the food/plates people were ordering, I sort of wished we would just stay put and have dinner there.  

As usual I was running late, and my friend had ordered me a vodka drink.  Upon my first sip, I asked him what this lovely concoction was... he said he just told the bartender to whip up something tasty (I'm sure he used more descriptive adjectives, and the end result was delicious).  I love it when bartenders make custom drinks.  

Love the vibe here.
author: Sarah F.

description:
I've been meaning to come here ever since I heard about the bone marrow pot pie. Unfortunately, my poor planning resulted in never getting to eat a proper dinner here, and instead indulging in drinks and a post-dinner picnic plate. I have no regrets. The pot pie will just have to wait until next time.

Their drinks are well mixed, but a bit pricey. Some of the drinks are Bourbon and Branch prices, and while the ambiance was good, it wasn't Bourbon and Branch by a long shot. It was just a hair shy of the quality of 15 Romolo's cocktails, actually, so I would consider these a little overpriced.

Their picnic plate was just what the doctor ordered. I don't remember what I'd had to eat that night, but I'm pretty sure it was enough for dinner. I don't know why I suddenly decided that my contribution to a picnic plate with meats and pickles was necessary, but I'm sure glad I decided that. It was well worth the $15, and made me feel like a million bucks. 

I would like to come back, if only to get the bone marrow pot pie!
author: Angeline P.

description:
Great Happy Hour or Pre-Gaming spot. At least that is why we stopped  here. There were 6 of us and we basically had every small plate on the menu

My three Favs were:
Pigs in biscuit
Hangtown Toast and the cheddar crackers.

Great spot...great for a small group of friends...Enjoy
author: Ronnie B.

description:
Rye-whiskey Old Fashioned and Manhattans. 
Poured very strong, the way it should be.
Good formula.
author: Derek N.

description: Drinks and bartenders are great, the jazz music gives it something extra, but sometimes staff can be rude or can't be bothered. However, the drinks are so good, I can't seem to stop coming back!
author: Alison Y.

description: This place fills up fast so I  can see where other reviews are coming from, but I've never had bad experiences with the service when it's not during peak hours
author: Will H.

description: I'm a big fan of Comstock. Cool ambiance, great cocktails, good food, and nice service. It's not quite five stars due to a few minor nitpicks (there are a few misses on the food menu, the service can be a little bit slower than desired), but it's definitely a good date spot or a cool stop-in on a crawl through nightlife spots in North Beach.
author: Daniel K.

description:
You know those times when you're looking for one place, only to find something 1000x better?  That's what happened one night.  Looking for the Bubble Lounge, we found Comstock Saloon.

I thought this bar was a total novelty.  Like c'mon, it's Western themed!  They went all out -- from the Indian totems to the curio cabinets, these nifty spinning fans, and more, the decorations spoke for themselves.  The live band playing in the overhang won my heart.  I can't remember the band's name for the life of me, all I know is that I had a great time!

My boyfriend and I sat at the bar for a few hours.  I ordered a tall mug of draft beer while my boyfriend decided to go all-out-cowboy aka bring on the Four Roses whiskey.  The whiskey was served in a boot-shaped shot glass.  HOW AWESOME is that?  We sipped, conversed, and laughed all night.

Our bartender, Jeff, made sure that we never went thirsty.  He even answered my curious questions about bartending practices.  I pretty much learned all that I need to know about bartending in that one night.  At one point, my boyfriend decided to try Jeff's specialty mixed drink (containing spices, hot sauce, and other ingredients that we guessed).  Ah Jeff, you do not let us down.  :)  

Drinks are pricey here, but if that's the price for live music, Western themed ambiance, and a friendly bartender, I'll pay it.
author: Kathleen W.

description: pretty good sized pours and decent pricing.  I like it :)  Wasn't tooooo crowded, especially for a Friday, but then again we were there around 730 8pm.  Not a bad place for a stiff whiskey drink :)
author: Kyle I.

description:
Perfect bar ranked #1 to impress your out of town guests, ... Settle into the parlor to munch on saloon themed bar bites and gaze up at the steam punk-esque bar fans that vaguely resemble ship rudders. Best of all enjoy the free live music that wafts down from the mezzanine, graciously provided by live jazz singers, piano players and acapella quartets.

Read more http://asmalltrip.com/v/1-week/7-san-francisco-bars-to-impress-your-out-of-town-guests
author: Grant G.

description: Stopped in here for a late dinner on Saturday evening around 1030p. We didn't have a reservation, but thought we'd see how long the wait would be. We were in luck and got seated right away. We decided to order the pig biscuits. Delicious, though a little small for $13.00. Cocktails were strong, but tasty and you really could order only one and be satisfied. Love that. My husband ordered the chicken which he said was very tasty and it was also unbelievably moist. I ordered the pork spare ribs which were AMAZING! Loved listening to the live band. The décor and service was impeccable. I couldn't believe we walked away with only an $85.00 bill. Well worth it and I would have paid more. :)
author: Missy W.

description: I'm a huge fan of Comstock.  Great decor and ambiance (good for dates), and delicious, unique food.  Great bar and cocktail menu.  They often have live music.  The restaurant has two sections; the main seating area with the larger bar is nice, but the second section off to the side with the smaller bar is great for people-watching and feels more comfy.
author: Brian T.

description:
Came in to wait for our dinner reservations elsewhere and loved the vibe, the live music in the alcove above the dining room. Great carved wood bar made in 1907. Had a rum cocktail and the bf had a southside cocktail which was really a mojito made with gin and how can that be bad? 

Friendly and competent bartenders. What's not to like?
author: Thalia F.

description: The drinks were good enough, but nothing special. What really stands out about Comstock is the terrible service. Our mustachioed, spectacled bartender was pretentious and rude. Perhaps this gentleman is a world class sommelier or mixologist and I failed to recognize his resplendent nature or maybe he was just a pompous ass, because I can't figure out why he put on such airs. Get over yourself, pal.
author: Ela P.

description:
I have tried to have a cocktail a few times, and the bar staff are always a bit rude and never really got the impression they wanted my business. But since I live near I still wanted to check out the place, so I finally made a diner reservation for 4. 

Even with reservations the front desk are not rude, but definitely not accommodating. We sat and thought we had a great table (more on that later). The waiter sauntered over, and seemed drunk and even made an off handed joke about another staff member. Awkward.

We ordered, drinks came, food arrived, and all of those were very delicious but the wobbly waiter was no where to be found. And.... then.... the staff exodus and clean up for the night started at the end of our meal, and thru the dining room.

They walked thru the dining room several times each, and the best part was the street door stays open for the chilly air to blow into the dining room, where we thought we had a cozy table. Since the everyone was cleaning, smoking and exiting the wide open door was perfect for them.... and down right too chilly to finish our dinner.

I shut the wide open door 4 times in 15 minutes, and after placing my jacket on in the dining room I was done with this place. The dining room was half empty all night, and now I know why. CHECK PLEASE.

I can't recommend because the staff at Comstock are broken, bitter and rude.
author: Al A.

description:
I came here with my friends one night for some drinks and thought the place was pretty nice and chill! Also, this will always be the place I had my first Old Fashioned =) I actually really enjoyed it too, it was citris-y and not overpowering.  Would try to come back when next time!

Word of advise, if you want to get a booth, come a little early. Gets pretty pack on the weekends.
author: Mimi P.

description:
They do make bars like this anymore more... oh wait, they do, as Comstock is modern, alcohol-soaked proof! The saloon is a throwback to the Barbary Coast (it's named in honor of  the Comstock Lode), and that's reflected in everything from the decor (is that a piano up top?) to the cocktails and fare. 

Take, for instance, my recent visit this Saturday, when a pal and I enjoyed a classic martini made with ever-loving perfection by Jeff Hollinger. Yes, that's the guy who made Absinthe famous, and he's now turned up as a co-partner in this establishment. Translation: You want a serious drink. Step inside, son!

While we didn't sit down for a full meal, we snacked, and if our cheddar crackers with pepper jelly and pickled eggs on rye toast were any indication, the food could quite possibly parallel the drinks, which believe you me, is no small achievement.

Next time, look for me at the bar, or perhaps tucked away in a booth, waiting for my own mining fortunes to pay off.
author: Nish N.

description:
While walking to breakfast at Mama's we noticed the groovy Comstock Saloon. I instructed CP not to look at the menu because we already had dinner plans. But, I messed up, I looked at the menu.... and it sounded oh so good. And, since it was so close to our hotel, I was immediately sucked in. 

Thank goodness because this place was totally worth it! We stopped in around six for the happy hour derby cocktail. It was very yummy and only $6. Plus, on an empty stomach, it was super strong. The bartender was very funny. We decided to be safe over sorry and made reservations for a few hours later. Then we left.

Once we were reseated (not at the bar but in the back room where it is quieter) for dinner we really started digging into the menu. Everything sounded awesome but we eventually settled on the corn fritters for an appetizer and the salmon for dinner. Plus another round of drinks!

Our waitress was very pleasant and efficient. She brought everything to us in a timely manner. Even though I super burned my tongue on the corn fritters they were totally worth it. So yummy. The salmon was perfectly prepared. Not over cooked at all and wholly sumptuous. We rounded out our meal with the absolutely amazing bourbon pudding. It has a little banana cake in the bottom and a strong bourbon taste. I was in heaven. I want to dive head first into a pool of this pudding. It was perfect.

Even though I had not expected to have dinner here I was so glad we did. The music, the staff, the great food and drinks... everything was even better then I could have hoped for. We stumbled upon the best place around!
author: Tai F.

description: Great drinks and snacks.  They had prompt service to boot.  Knocked off one star bc the bar area really doesn't smell good- reminded me of a college bar.
author: Madhuri K.

description: Very rude staff who think highly of themselves. Though the food was good I will never return based on how they treated a friend.
author: Natalie C.

description:
I love California cuisine.  I love the fresh food, the light cuisine, the subtle textures and delicacies.  But can't shake the idea that we have all gotten a little silly now that we are eating foams and jellies and calling it a meal.  I think we have wandered into the absurd.

Comstock to the rescue.

Pickled figs and bacon.

Bone marrow pot pie

Game hen stuffed with chorizo 

It is the anti-California cuisine in the heart of California.  I love it.  No, I can't eat bone marrow pot pie and my stomach turns a little thinking of hen stuffed with chorizo, but I have braved the fritters, figs and some of their desserts.  They are all fabulous!  Fabulous.  

Once a vegetarian, I will vouch for every veggie option they have.  Baked beans, alligator toast, beet sandwiches - everything is prepared with the same care as their regular menu.  All are succulent and rich, sans animal.

I feel like I rarely get to try new food these days, but EVERY time I come Comstock, I am delighted by new flavors.  EVERY time, my mouth rejoices.

Side note: I had my baby shower here.  Yes, I am that girl.
author: Hayley W.

description: Expert bartender named, Matt. Very efficient, friendly, professional and with the right amount of warmth and attentiveness. He made a delicious Manhattan ($10) and three other drinks that were specifically made per our request of what we liked, didn't like and he created them (Barkeeps Whimsy, each $12). It was really a treat to watch him do his magic. The food looked pretty tasty too. Although Matt was busy, as he was the only bartender at the bar, he took time to chat with us without feeling rushed. He was very composed in his manner, dressed well with suspenders and a bow tie (not clip on). He told us a little bit about the history, the beautiful wood bar that we sat at is still the original from 1907. It's fascinating sitting at the bar, reveling in the craziness of how many men from that time sat there and pissed in the very seat I was sitting on. Cheers (from a boot ;).
author: Mayana P.

description:
Comstock Saloon is the perfect setting for a night out on the town, if you don't want to deal with your typical crowded bars and bad music. We came in around 9 on a Saturday and had a group of 3. We preferred a table, so we went across the street and waited for about a half hour till they called us when a table opened. The hostess was really friendly and accommodating.  

We stayed for about 3 hours and loved the bourbon drinks we tried. The classic manhattan, delish. We ordered two drinks not on the menu that our server suggested when he found out we are all bourdon drinkers. Both were great and when more friends joined up with us they got them too. 

The only semi-negative was for how incredibly loud the jazz band was. The music was really good, and set the mood, but we had a hard time even talking over it. It might be the location of our table, which was right below the band, which had to do with it too.
author: Natalie N.

description:
One thing I wish Rickhouse did was serve food. Well, my wishes have come true...somewhat.  The dark dreery lighiting, the smell of whiskey in the air, the bartenders in suspenders, you would have thought you were in Rickhouse, but nope, its Comstock Saloon.  No, Comstock is not Rickhouse, but its a good alternative.  The drinks are strong and prepared well.  I can trust that when I order an Old Fashion or a Manhattan that it will be up to my standards. 

What sets Comstock apart though is that its also serves food.  Its not modeled after a prohibition whiskey lair, but rather an old school saloon of an era when the west was still wild!  They even have a piano upstairs that gets good use.  The mood makes you want to drink, and drink something strong.  The staff is good, some being more exceptional than others.  But the highlight is the "All Day Fare" menu.  Everything from pickeled eggs, to poutine in a beef gravy, to the beef shank and bone marrow pot pie scream "Eat Me!"  And did just that. 

It will never take the place of Rickhouse for me, but those times when you just delicious bites with your drinks at your happy hour, or anytime really, this is the place to go!!!
author: Veasna H.

description:
It may be a 4 star If it weren't for:  1. Our neighbors sloppily making out with each other and sticking their tongue down their throats at 6pm.  2. It being so incredibly crowded! We were seated in the corner table and felt the spillover effects of the crowded bar.  Literally.  People spilling over their jeans had their butts right at our face level.  And of course, standing right in front of us.  

We started off our dinner with south side cocktail and a glass of pinot.  Good wine by the glass, and cocktail done right. 

One of my favorite things at a party is pigs in the blanket.  Meat fat + butter fat all wrapped around? Yes please! Although the biscuit and pork patty looked standoffish with its dry look and rough appeal, the combination of the pickles (ask for extra), grainy mustard with the fat+fat 'slider' was truly decadent and moist.  I only had one but it was a good amount of warmup fat for the bone marrow pie.. or so I thought. 

I don't remember the last time I had a pot pie, but seeing that it had bone marrow, one of my favorite fats, I had to try it.  The shell was the perfect burnt and flaky buttery crust, and although the inside had good big chucks of steak, that's all it really was.  Not the pot pie with cream or goo, just a hunk 'o steak with a thin crust around it.  I could see the parts where the bone marrow was neatly placed onto, but frankly the tiny strands weren't enough.  In the end, I ended up realizing I should have ordered more food. 

I got the strawberry shortcake, well done but nothing exceptional. 

So aside from having drunken exhibitionists, ridiculously high decibels and butts in our faces, I would say the food was pretty good.  It's simple, hearty, and fun.
author: Hannah W.

description:
This is why I go out in SF!

Bar is preserved for its pre-prohibition look, including some intense ceiling fans that look like belt-driven shovels (but are actually palm leaves), the great Emperor Norton perched above the topshelf ensuring your quality intoxication, and the only remaining bar urinal in the city running along the footrests of the bar (those were certainly the days!)

The chicken-fried rabbit appetizer was very interesting and the corn fritters were amazingly delicious. Old fashioned specialty drinks along the line of what you'd get at B&B or Rickhouse. Priced to match. (Saint's Buck is a very tasty, yet not too sugary concoction)

Expect to spend lots of money. 3 appetizers, 3 drinks each = 105 for 2 people. Absolutely worth it.

And the live band playing on the small mezzanine is a very nice touch.

Bring your suit and top-hat.
author: David D.

description: This a a great bar on the border of North Beach and the Financial District. Cocktails are fresh and not overpriced (obviously not cheap, this is San Francisco), the atmosphere is cozy and and intimate, and the decor gives it an old timey but not too hipster feel. It's got a nice mix of traditional bar style tables as well as booths in the back section. I went on a Sunday night and there was a pianist performing. Great spot for dates or just a few drinks after work.
author: Conner N.

description:
It was awesome being able to just stop into Comstock Saloon on a Saturday night for drinks - no wait! Perhaps it was because it was Easter weekend, but regardless, the service was prompt and the drinks flowed quickly. I loved the cute saloon like atmosphere and the clean bathrooms.

3.5 stars because the drinks were pretty good, but not impressive or anywhere near the caliber, variety, or innovation of Bourbon and Branch. Unfortunately, I'd have to admit drinks aren't as tasty as The Alembic, Beretta, and Bourbon, but the prices are much more reasonable here (Alembic charges you an arm and a leg!).

While this place isn't my favorite place for drinks, it IS my favorite place to get a drink without having to fight for a chair or table (e.g. Beretta, Bourbon, Rickhouse....).
author: Jess C.

description:
The 19th century decor made me feel like I could have worn my saloon-girl or Edwardian costume and be part of the vintage theme. It made me wonder how people were like during the days of Barbary Coast. I absolutely loved the old-fashion ambiance. 
They have a pretty impressive cocktail list. I can't remember which one my date ordered...  I think he got something-mule, but I continued to drink my usual... red wine. The live Jazz band was as fantastic as the live music we heard at the Fillmore Jazz festival.  We did not dine here, so my review is based on the over-all vibe of the bar... very cool!
author: Myra M.

description:
A friend and I met for dinner one night while I was in San Fran for work. I was pleasantly surprised to see the 'Michelin Recommended' sign outside the window as we walked in. The space is really nice and classy. We didn't have a reservation but luckily a table was open at the bar. 

I normally don't order cocktails but tried the Blood & Sand and it was delicious. I wasn't sure about ordering a scotch drink that was mixed with vermouth, but it was really good and had a smoky taste to it. 

For dinner we split the Hang town toast and The rabbit 3-ways. Both were excellent but I would highly recommend trying the rabbit. We also split the Braised beef shank & bone marrow pot pie which was awesome. The meat was extremely tender and the pot pie was golden brown and flaky. It was the best thing I had there and might be the best thing I had while in San Francisco.  

Our server was great and I really liked this place. I will definitely be back the next time I am in town.
author: Pratik S.

description:
Well-crafted cocktails in a non-pretentious bar with excellent, experience service. Heard good things about the food here, so we came for a late dinner. The salad was exemplary - who would have thought escarole hearts, pickled grapes, goat cheese, and walnuts would make such an exquisite salad? The chicken-fried rabbit with celery salad was also to-die-for good. 

P.S. I could drink Comstock Saloon's South Side Cocktails (gin, lemon, sugar, mint, seltzer) all night long...........
author: Angie C.

description:
We walked up at 3:57 and were simply reading the menu and the employee outside putting up signs told us "weren't open for business until 4:00". We walked around the block and returned at 4:10. He rolled his eyes and walked in back. 

The décor is gorgeous. I loved the old wood, the fans, the framed art...eye candy galore. This is the type of place I would hang out in for hours if it were in my hometown. 

We chose our drinks (I started with the John Collins, my husband had red wine...both delicious) while listening to one waitress explain to the head bartender that she needed to either throw up or be let off early due to a late night out and the bartender talked about how excited she was to have given her notice. 

We ordered the chips and ranch which was probably not the BEST choice (stale chips) and the olives (nice little kick to them).

The bartender made a batch of drinks for other patrons and it was under my nose and smelled wonderful. I asked what it was and she muttered and rambled it off. My fault that I didn't ask her to repeat it. (She'd taken our menus).  I just said "Great...I'll take one".

Due to the poor service all around, we left. We'd planned on having dinner here, but the attitude was just too much. The place was PACKED...so obviously they aren't hurting. 

I hope we were an exception and not the rule of how one is regularly treated at Comstock. My husband and I had just talked about how service in the SF area seems to have gotten better & better over the last 4-5 years. 

Again...drinks and wine were wonderful....service was abysmal. We honestly thought we were being Punked.
author: Amy H.

description: A busy cocktail bar, that is comfortable for tourists as well as walk-ins. I stopped by late around 9:45pm on a Sunday and the place...after a few moments of waiting I was able to get a small table. I had the south side cocktail, a whiskey concoction which was the bar tenders choice, and a scotch on the rocks...all were brought quickly and were freshly prepared. I also had their hot chicken, which was a great pub dish, with some light spices cooked into the batter, with fresh cherry tomatoes sweet pickles and croutons. It was great. The ambiance is speakeasy and whimsical and I can't wait to go there once again to try some other dishes, and drinks. It's in the busy part of north beach, so it's a great place for a fun night out!
author: Ojas V.

description:
(See pics)

We came here after dinner to check out this new place as I had walked by it quite a few times and was intrigued.

Such a busy evening on the opening evening! Dark, stained glass, tile and stone style flooring with a few bartenders making drinks one by one, each taking about 5 to 10 minutes for precision and dedication while they enjoyed themselves with flowing conversations with customers.

I had Sazerac and it was a fairly strong drink for me. I also tried out a bit of John Collins and it was nice. I did not know much about cocktails but liked my drink!

There are 2 sections. The main area has tall booths that can fit up to 6 people closely or 4 very leisurely. There are also a couple Victorian seats with a nice fireplace on the side, as well as a small loft upstairs. The other side is more tables and bamboo / wooden chairs that you can get a bigger group and assemble the furniture together. 

Overall, the service was good and attentive. I do like the turning on the side lamps just up 1 notch when they were closing. It's less intruding than turning on the bright lights that most bars do!

This will be a great place if you want to chill and get a stiff drink.
author: T L.

description:
Is it possible for the drinks, service, atmosphere, music or food at Comstock to get any better?  The simple answer is NO.  There's simply no room for improvement here. That said, to guarantee a perfect experience, I recommend the following:  First, sit in the front room in a booth (which can easily fit up to 6 people) or at the bar.  Second, order the rabbit dish. Repeat often. 

Last night's menu also included other tasty items including a flank steak dish served as a deconstructed taco complete with tortillas, green salsa, avocado and beans.  It was delicious.  I also tried the gnocchi dish which came with English peas, radishes and mushrooms.  This was also enjoyable.   

In short, I've been here before and I'll come again.
I'm a regular here.  You should be too.
author: Jamie A.

description: Review is on the BAR - Had one cocktail there.  Super good.  Uses absinthe and lots lemon peels for interesting and classic effects.
author: Jim T.

description:
Thanks to Mad Men's website recipes for old school cocktails, I completely addicted to Bitters now. I was delighted to find out that, at Comstock, both bamboo and hop toad cocktails use bitters, and both of them were complex and delicious. We went on ordered several food items from the menu including lamb riblets, rabbit, and stir-fry pawns. Great news is that the food didn't let us down either, me and my friend cleaned the plates completely. 

Bonus: the history of this place, the WC label (:-D),  the fast service, and friendly waiters.
author: Neena W.

description:
A late night dining option in North Beach that doesn't involve garlic kitsch, menu pushers more aggressive then the dudes outside strip clubs or patrons that look like East Bay Snookis.  The food is typical gastropub which means nothing is really typical except the concept of fancifying bar food with innovative techniques and seasonal specialties.  As expected, the mixology is pretty nice and you don't need to use any stupid password at the door.

Fried Beans: When they're in season, everyone in San Francisco seems to use the fava bean.  Deep fried was a novel concept, but just a mediocre bar snack.  Reminded me of a wasabi pea except without the wasabi and way bigger.

Cheddar Crackers, Pepper Jelly: Definitely no Cheez-It here!  More like a cheddar frico with a tad more flour to make it fall on the cracker side.  Totally cheesy.  The mild soft white cheese with the pepper jelly (think like what you dip Thai spring rolls in) made for a fun dipping experience, though I could definitely eat the crackers alone.

Pig in a Biscuit: Three pulled pork sliders on buttery biscuit rounds.  The fat from the pork and from the biscuits was a little overwhelming and would have been better if cut with vinegar or something spicy.  Despite that, still more interesting than a BBQ laden pork slider on some boring bun.

Chicken-Fried Rabbit: I felt like Jessica Simpson when I ordered this - "Is it chicken or is it rabbit?"  It was rabbit that tasted a bit like chicken karaage since it was very must like chewy and juicy dark meat.  Bread and deep fry anything and it won't be half bad.  Nice bar snack, but really didn't let the rabbit shine.

House-Corned Brisket: A full corned beef supper treated like a charcuterie plate.  Bite sized everything (corned beef, cabbage, potatoes) with rye crostini to assemble your snack and then smear grainy mustard on top.  The corned beef was firm, yet tender though doesn't compare with old time favorites like Tommy's Joynt.  I personally like that it was snack size because the proper meal is often gut wrenching, though I can imagine some folks would feel gypped.  

Beef Shank & Bone Marrow Pot Pie: Like one of those flaky handheld Australian meat and gravy pies.  There were no bones to extract marrow from so it must have been integrated into the mix.  Extremely savory and salty pie filling.  Too intense for one person alone, so glad I was sharing.

Shortcake: Was hoping for the maple bourbon pudding, but they weren't serving it when I was there (despite being listed on the menu).  This dish was worthwhile due to the fluffiness of the bread.  It was a pleasant departure from the chalky scone-like standard.  Of course the macerated berries and fresh whipped cream are always appreciated.
author: Adam B.

description:
One of my favorite places for a drink or to eat! 

I have been to Comstock a couple of times now and each time, the service has been outstanding, the food has been declious, and the decor+ ambiance has been enjoyable. The people who created Comstock really had a vision I think and it all works!! I felt like i had taken a step back in time. The waiters and bartenders were all dressed up like the old'en days. its pretty neat.

 A simple delicious small (but everything on there is good) menu, yummy (sometimes really strong) drinks, really delicious coffee (french press), old fashion saloon style decor. Its dark but appriopriate for the style.

Food-
1. The picked eggs - On the 7x7 list and well deserved. Its on the small side. only 2 pieces of egg, but it has bacon and this sauce on it that makes for wonderful tasting bites.
2. Potatoes with cheese curd - It's like a poutine and very good! Wayfares might be better by an itch (not much!)
3. Beef pot pie - awesome! I get it everytime. Comes with a salad to offset the meat.
4. The bourbon bread pudding - One of the tastiest desserts i've had in a long time. 

Brava Comstock!! I'm so glad I work nearby because if I'm having a bad day at work, I know where I'm headed!
author: Cicely T.

description:
When calling to mind the Comstock Saloon only one word comes to mind...

Love.

Love is what i felt on my birthday weekend stumbling upon the Comstock (not drunk, that came later....) quite by surprise even though i'd been referred to it at least a dozen times by people that know from good.

Love is what i felt when the bartender (cannot remember his name, The Man is much better at that but he's tall, formidable, shaved head with a wicked sweet smile) ensured that he attended to this gal like a woman who's having a birthday... all while feeding the awesome energy flow of the entire establishment.  

Love is what I felt when The Man asked the greeter if we could use a booth behind us to order food and even though that same table was technically taken, she allowed us to use it until the name on the reservation showed up, with such a sweet kindness that we wished we had made reservations here instead.

Love is the artful and downright attractive food that arrived, in tasting portions, well explained by the server who not only made me feel comfortable about the food I was about to experience (Rabbit three way and Hangtown Toast ... holy moly so good!!!!) that I was probably more excited than the chef upon trying it.... (did i say holy moly so good?  cause i really want you to remember that) 

Love is the vibe of the Comstock.

Love is Cherry Bounce.

Love will keep us together.  

See you soon Comstock.  and a great big gracias, danke, merci, for such a REAL GOOD time!

Edited to add that The Man reminded me that the Gentleman Bartender's name is Dave.  THANK YOU DAVE!!!!
author: Rachel C.

description:
I LOVE this place!  I had it bookmarked on my computer for a while because I was originally thinking of taking a bachelorette party there, but decided against it.  I started dating this guy who lived a few blocks away and had him take me one night.  I can't get over how good the Pisco Punch was!  

Classy, old fashioned decor, they had a band playing, and the drinks were great.  We were seated at the bar, and our bartender seemed to know almost half of the people who came in.  We chatted with our neighbors next to us and everyone was friendly.  The door man even came up to us at the end of the room to tell us about two seats that had opened up.  Very nice!
author: Veronica P.

description: My favorite happy hour in the city.  A boot and a beer is the way to go for sure!  Otherwise, you can put your future in the hands of the bartender and order a Whimsy!
author: Eric N.

description: Must go!! Great old school atmosphere especially when the band is playing. If you're at the bar.... ASK FOR MATT!!! He is hands down the best bartender ever!! Once you see him in action you'll know what I'm talking about!
author: Merlino T.

description: fun place. old school beers
author: Doug T.

description:
I love that, in addition to fabulous cocktails and live music, you can get also get GOOD FOOD here! 

And, you can choose what kind of night you want to have here. Here's a buzzy, crowded bar area if you enjoy the hustle and bustle, and want to be close to the music. There's also a more low-key section where you can enjoy a meal or conversation in peace. 

And, I love the location--at the intersection of the Financial District, Chinatown and North Beach, so it's easily walkable to/from your next stop for the night. Comstock really does give you a little bit of everything.
author: Eeeeestar T.

description: Loved the live music and sitting at the bar was really a great experience. The bartenders were friendly, experienced, knowledgeable yet let you have your own conversation. I would totally go back again! (Only had drinks so can't speak to the food, but the atmosphere was top notch). I will say that the musicians coming around for money was a little bit of a turn off (is there a better way?) but they were good and up in the balcony so I understand a little.
author: Becca F.

description:
Was visiting a friend in the city and they brought me to this gem. This is a very nice bar with my kind of drinks. Sazerac was delish and they don't put stupid cherries in their Old Fashioned. Shame we didn't get there sooner to try out some of the food. Thanks to whomever didn't keep their reservation because we got to take your booth when the place was packed. Really dig the fans. Did not dig the music. It did not go with the decor but the crowd seemed to not mind. 

The prices seemed right for the type of drink and they are well made. According to the reserved sign we took off the table, they apparently have reservations, which might be a good idea because it was packed and there did seem to be some large groups.
author: Alex F.

description:
Cocktails, cocktails, cocktails! 

I'm always on the prowl to find this city's best cocktail spots and I can safely say Comstock is the creme de la creme of handcrafted artisan cocktails. 

And of course, feeling like I'm being transported to the Barbary Coast prohibition period doesn't hurt either. The ambiance is absolutely transcending and I love it! 

I recommend the South Side if you're into something sweet and refreshing and the Sazerac if you're into something a bit more robust and bold. But seriously, I doubt you can go wrong with anything on their menu. 

Bonus: They have a pianist performing on most nights!
author: Priya S.

description:
The point: Historically relevant bar with phenomenally talented bartenders. Definitely worth going :D !

This is my favorite bar in North Beach, & the bartenders are true professionals. Get the Bartender's Whimsey; you will not be disappointed.
author: Becca M.

description:
Highly highly recommend this place for both food and drink.  I have previously been here for their bar scene, which can really be a totally separate review.  Their drinks are made by some of the best bartenders in the city and if you do not find anything on their cocktail menu that inspires you, then go for the barkeeps whimsy where they will create a cocktail for you based on what spirits/tastes you prefer.  I have yet to receive a bad drink here.  Yet...I digress from the main review from the meal...

Snacks: Do not miss the BBQ chips with Ranch.  I know....you are thinking why pay for something that you probably have at home and can eat on the couch.  I even gave my husband a questionable look when he ordered it and I will repeat what he told me "Trust me".  These are made from scratch chips with just a sprinkling of BBQ seasoning and O.M.G. the Ranch.  It is thick, creamy, and perfectly balanced.  I would smear that on toast, my steak, eggs, pretty much anything.  It was to die for.

Apps: We ordered the green salad with sweet herbs, fried grits, and buttermilk lime dressing.  Hands down the best part of this salad is the fried grits.  They more resemble small croutons and are delicious.  The buttermilk lime dressing gave the salad a nice tang.
We also ordered the corn fritters with jalapenos which were o.k. by themselves however when eaten all together with the jalapenos and dipped in the accompanying pepper dip they were excellent.

Main courses:  The husband ordered their steak which he said was cooked to perfection at medium rare.  They served it with heirloom tomatoes that had sat there and soaked up the juices of the steak.  Those were phenomenal and I think they should create an appetizer from just those being marinated in steak drippings.
I had the chicken pot pie which was filling and tasty.  I could have gone for a more flakier crust, however it was a cold evening and it hit the spot.

Service:  Impeccable.  Our waiter was friendly, informative, and attentive.  

Atmosphere: I love the cozy dining room and the saloon feel to the place.  It is a hideaway where you can run and have a moment of peace after a busy day with a good meal and cocktail.

Overall this place is great.  If we lived closer i.e. in the city and didn't have to fight for parking in North Beach, we would be there more often.  Whether it is for a quick night cap or a sit-down meal, you really can't go wrong at Comstock.
author: Jennifer W.

description: If your idea of a nice outing is to be served a sublime cocktail or Irish coffee paired with a generous helping of pretentious effrontery, this is your place! I have been close to ten times--each of these containing a "what the fuck was that?" moment. To be fair, most of these involved the tall, young Mr. Belvedere look alike who acts as a Manager and truly consistently manages to spoil even the most hearty good times. Why do I keep coming back? The drinks are really that good, and I refuse to let anyone run me out of a joint because they have never managed to pull that stick out of their ass from eighth grade.
author: andy h.

description:
Comstock Saloon had a very old "Barbary Coast" feel about it.

I liked the statue of Emperor Norton atop the bar.

I was pleased to try a few cocktails and snacks.  

I had homemade BBQ chips with ranch dressing and also homemade crackers with pepper jelly and cream cheese.  Also, I had a Bamboo cocktail and a Sazerac. 

I would go with what they're offering here.  The service was fantastic.
author: Carrie P.

description:
It's late, your car is back near AT&T Stadium, you're in the middle of Chinatown, and you could really use a drink.  And if you happen to be near the Comstock Saloon, then respite is right around the corner, right Zach?  This is a fantastic bar to wash away the exploits of the day and cleanse the palette with fantastic mixology.  One does not simply live forever without having a few cocktails here.

I can't speak for the food as I didn't have the chance to try any, but that's only because the drinks floored me (as they did you Zach).  There are plenty of drinks to choose from, but indecision is where it's at.  I highly recommend the Bartender's Whimzy - a roll of the alcoholic dice, wouldn't you agree Zach?  The bartender mixes up whetever they feel like for you, and no experiment has resulted in failure.  Quite the opposite.  The talent is put where your tongue is, and each round is money well spent.

There are many great bars in San Francisco, but Comstock is exceptional in the realm.  Make it a point to stop in and have a drink or five, and get lit with some great drinks, right Zach?
author: Francis M.

description:
Small little bar. Came here for Friday's happy hour so that's the only thing I'm reviewing

[+] cute little boot glass for a shot
[+] two local brews of beer--one from SF, one from berkeley
[+] sexy black aston dbs parked outside when I was there.... yes, this is a plus!

[+/-] beer + a shot for $6, the beer is normally $5.50
[+/-] corn fritters were interesting, 10 pieces for $5; it has a nice crispy outside but a lot lighter/softer than expected as you bite into it; they were good but not mind-blowing
[+/-] derby's cocktail for $6; way too citrus-y for me. but if you like a tart-like drink w/ a hint of mint, try this out!
author: Sandy T.

description: So, my boyfriend took me for the first time and I have to say I was quite impressed. The bar itself has a cool rock-star feel to it as soon as you walk in. It's dark but the high ceilings, the nice ambience inside and the jazz music on the background is quite relaxing upon entrance. My go-to drink? "South Side Cocktail" - Gin, lemon, sugar, mint, seltzer. Simple, plain for some but oh - so - yum. I have only been here 2x but I always want to come back for more. My bf always orders the Scottish eggs. He enjoys them every time. We also had the meatballs. It was alright. We plan to come back this weekend so I am hoping to try their entrees. The Comstock Burger is trying to call my name. Ha. The other thing I enjoy here is the live Jazz band that plays upstairs on their 2nd floor. My bf's friend plays his saxophone there at times. The band plays incredible songs that make your entire experience quite fun and relaxed. I definitely recommend that you try this place. Cocktails range from $8 - $12. Trust me.. You will come back here again after you try their drinks. And notice their bartenders' outfits. Pretty hot, I say.. Bow ties!
author: Anna Y.

description:
I was here for all of 15 minutes, but the customer service really stood out. The bartender was precise, and the manager was welcoming. A bottle of cider put my friend back $34, but it was damn good cider.

I'd go back to try the food because it smelled really good, and the music was eclectic and decent. Good atmosphere, good service, can't ask for much more..
author: Nikki G.

description:
Arrived here last night about 10 p.m and plenty of seats, quiet, but it seemed like the managers/owners were filling in as wait staff?  The two of them alternated waiting on us, back and forth, with long waits  between , yet all the food we ordered arrived at once!

Cocktails were great.  Food was good (average).  Live music superb 

Hang town toast, corn fritters, pineapple toast, blueberry compote.

Walked from My Fair Lady play at the SF Playhouse, which was five stars!
author: Foodlover B.

description: Great place. Awesome drinks but a little confusing when entering there are two entrances I came in the wrong one LOL the staff member who was very busy kind of showed me towards the bar side and then disappeared. Great old fashion btw just a odd start to my experience. Maybe a sign on the door that is not the proper entrance?
author: Big B.

description:
Stopped in on an early Thursday evening.  Very clean with nice decor including the oldest bar in the city and the most awesome ceiling fan.
Food & Bev:  Chose two Anchor Steam beers and the beet salad.  The salad was excellent.  While we ate we were regaled with tales of the Emperor of SF, Norton the First by our bartender and a local resident just stopping in for a beer.
Cost:   $26.14
author: Jo G.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for awhile and finally got to yesterday night.  It's got the Rickhouse/Bourban & Branch vibe, but with food!  Drinks were well made and the food looked/smelled delicious.  I only tried the chips and corn fritters since it was past dinnertime for me, but my friends got the po-boy and pot pie.  Pot pie looked especially good on a cold night and they said the po-boy satisfied their cravings.  The live jazz band upstairs was also a nice touch.

I plan to come back for dinner...hopefully sometime soon :)
author: Jane N.

description:
The drinks at Comstock are definitely 4/5-star worthy...! I always appreciate a bar that can make a delicious old fashion; if you enjoy this particular cocktail as much as I do you understand that this is actually hard to come by. Rye and Mr. Lews are particularly good at making them as well...I digress. 

Great, vibrant scene after work, brimming to the edges with a variety of folks. It seems to always be busy so if you're looking to sit down and have a more relaxing time, you can make reservations on Open Table like we did. We were ushered back to a little booth right in the middle of their bustling bar. Easy-peasy!

The food was good, although not entirely 4-star worthy. The pretzel and pig in a biscuit was delightful but I probably could have done without the corn fritters. They were a little on the dry side. 

See you again soon, Comstock. Have a few old fashions ready for me upon my arrival.
author: Julia N.

description:
This place is great. My friend who is living in the area took me here for a few drinks. We got there early and found two seats towards the back. Everything is pretty intimate and the music and atmosphere are pretty lively. The decor, the feel, and everything including the waitstaff's outfits are completely on point with their saloon theme. I had a Pisco Punch and an absinthe drink. My friend had two whiskey cocktails that were really nice. If in doubt, ask your server. They are extremely knowledgeable and really friendly.  

Don't forget to look up at the ceiling to check out some cool fans.
author: Jasmin D.

description:
Meh. Roasted chicken-ok but blah. Drinks are really good. Pretzel is really good too. Dinner was just ok. 
I had "America's Cup" & an "Old Fashioned". Strong drinks which I like.
author: C A.

description:
As a cocktail lounge/bar this place is very nice - 4 stars. Very nice drinks and a hip, nostalgic atmosphere. Warm, amber lighting and eclectic decor.

As a restaurant, it's subpar - 2 stars. The service is ok but over-attentive to the point of discomfort. Our plates taken away while we were still chewing and the check was brought to us without even asking if we wanted anything else (we were looking to have dessert and another round but no longer felt welcome). The food is ok but overpriced and nothing special.
author: Leo C.

description:
Oh Comstock Saloon, I love you, but last night was a disappointment.

When some friends recently asked for my opinion on Sazeracs in the city I immediately suggested they hit up the Comstock Saloon for some proper preparation. In fact, I tout their Sazerac solutions on the regular, even more so now that I've recently deemed Rye's mixture a bit too sweet to the tooth for my taste. However, I know now that a good thing taken with a little extra sugar trumps primped perfection served with the veiled vinegar of prejudice any day. 

I am a semi-regular at this vintage piss-trough of a bar (the vintage piss-trough being a good thing) and I even know a few of the staff by name though I'm sure they'd be hard put to remember mine if they can't even recall the names of the music-makers that nightly imbibe the joint with a jaunty, jazz-age vibe. No matter; faces and names are not the beef at stake here. My quarrel stems from personnel who find it necessary to remind patrons to tip the waitstaff for their toils. Really? No, freaking duh. 

But it IS tacky to address this issue, no? I do hate to bring it up but here it comes; you started it.

We left a $12 tip for a $54 not because you or anyone else reminded us to do so but because that's what you do. 

Sure, Americans may find their culture lacking in certain aspects, especially when compared to the rich dynasties and sophisticated histories of nations abroad, but dammit do we ever have our culture of tipping and proper cocktail crafting on lock-down. If my party of Sazerac-curious friends I brought in last night were assumed by staff to have "discovered" the place in an as seen on TV feature then we couldn't help but conversely assume that the staff appraised our less than FiDi-after-five attire (dress-code?) to be appropriate for streetside seating, not to mention, again, that tacky little reminder concerning service compensation. Blech. 

The overall unspoken vibe at Comstock last night rang derisive, and I'm embittered by the voiced affront that suggested our party as part of wave of second-class flotsam washed ashore via Fisherman's Wharf. Hardly. Swallowing this bitter pill won't be easy now that I have even less local friends and co-workers to share my Comstock esteem with.
author: Kelly O.

description: I had been meaning to come here for a while and finally made it last night. This place is really something special, it is like stepping into a western saloon. The ambiance/decor is just awesome, rich mahogany and all the waiters looked the part. Everyone was extremely nice and the drinks mixed to perfection. I had the half chicken, little ham had the scotch eggs and fried green tomatoes. I really recommend this place, there is a reason GQ ranked it as one of the top cocktail bars in America
author: Ben K.

description:
Located in the former San Francisco Brewing Co. building (RIP), this Barbary Coast-themed joint - owned by the dudes behind Absinthe - is a classy North Beach addition. If you're in the mood for vintage cocktails served in gorgeous stemware, old timey piano tunes, mustachioed servers, and, er, bone marrow pot pie (drool!) this is the place. 

Warm days for me are spent at one of the sidewalk tables, mint julip in hand; and cold nights, basking in a booth inside the dimly lit dining room with a sazarac and a plate of chicken-fried rabbit.

This may not be the Gold Rush era, but this place sure feels like a bonanza!
author: Christina S.

description:
Now when it comes to alcohol...I do know a few things.  Not quite as much as my brother but I've had my share of drinks.  Now I remember growing when this place was the SF Brewery.  Of course, I never went in but I do remember it.

This place now belongs up there as one the better saloons to visit.  Up there almost with Bourbon and Branch.  These guys really know how to create a cocktail...and I do mean create!!!  not just make.  From the care of chilling the glasses with large ice to coating the inner glass with apertif.  These guys know how really serve alcohol.

The surroundings remind of an old classic bar / saloon.  Loud...yes.  But you expect that at bar.  The patrons range from a tall older guy who looks like the cleaner kept version of Willy Nelson to Asian preppies.  Sitting at the edge of Old Chinatown and North Beach, I guess this makes logical sense!!

So yes.  Try this place out if you really like your drink the proper way!!
author: Cary L.

description: Go to the bar and try the BAR KEEPS WHIMSY.  This allows the bar tender to handcraft a cocktail based on your specific likes, completely tailored to you.  Mine was an excellent mix of gin,  orange liquor, bitters, orange rind, and topped with a quick flame from the orange rind!!!!  It was just as incredible to watch it being made, as it was delicious!!!!  When in San Francisco, do yourself a favor, visit the Comstock Saloon!!
author: Kevin T.

description: Like most cities with money, San Francisco is crammed full of hip little bars with swank atmosphere and fancy craft cocktails.  But if you're gonna go that route, you better commit, and the Comstock does, which is why I fell in love with it.  It's in a nicely restored old building (check out the floors!), and it really doses the ambience; it's also bitter than it looks with plentiful seating in the back, and is surprisingly affordable -- we got a free lunch, a very fine oyster po' boy, with our purchase of two cocktails.  The proof is in the drinking, of course, and here the Comstock comes through with guns blazing.  Every cocktail we tried was terrific, and the Moonraker is probably the best thing I've had in years, interesting in concept and flawless in execution.  My only regret is that we didn't spend more time here.
author: Leonard P.

description:
What a great place to go for a cocktail. The guys from Absinthe really know how to make a classic drink come alive.  The old school Barbary Coast feel and the live trio playing over head sets a nice ambiance with music  that is not too loud to carry on a conversation.  The wood work and booths are amazing and big enough to fit quite a few people.  The bar is long and seats quite a few guests. Suprisingly the food was very tasty as well.  Loved the Crackers & Jelly.  

Overall, this place is a go-to for a delicious cocktail in a relaxed atmosphere.
author: melissa l.

description:
Yelp is right on here with the 4 stars.  Dynamite location/ambiance.  Old bar with a spittoon trough built in to the floor behind the rail.  I had been Here when it was some mediocre brewery...
Went on a Sunday for Honky Tonk Sunday.  I wanted to try the everything but settled on the Chicken & waffles.  It was passable, but tasted like it'd been brined for a Chinese restaurant before frying, if that makes sense.  Cocktails are the Main event here. If you can get a bartender like I had (Karri), subject yourself to the Barkeep's Whimsy and be prepares to sit a spell.
author: Zach T.

description: What a classy place! I came here on a Wednesday night to celebrate with my friends and we had the best time ! There are two separate rooms and at the time we got there they had live jazz music playing(9:30pm). Make sure to have reservations ahead of time since this place was quite packed for a Wednesday night! I will definitely be returning for many more great times !!
author: Reet R.

description: I only came here for a drink, but the appeal of this place's history and such was lost on me.  In Comstock's defense, I am not a big fan of the classic cocktail.
author: Jeremy G.

description: Kind of bummed it was featured as one of the best bars in America bc it's already so busy, but we do love coming here. Friendly staff, good food, and while the music is sometimes too loud, we love it.
author: Heather M.

description: Great drinks, staff was lovely and attentive. The bar itself is pretty damn cool and has that great old timey vibe. The food was a hit and miss. The sardine toast was very tasty. The beet salad was yummy too. We also ordered marin miyagis that came out at room temp (boo!) and the side of lamb meatballs that were left uneaten because they were unacceptably salty. The other BIG bummer (those meatballs being the biggest)  was the crowd that hugged up against the bar. Loud obnoxious tourists that drowned out the mediocre rag time band that was doing their best up in the rafters. Too bad this bar doesn't exist on a road less traveled.
author: Angela M.

description:
Came across Comstock while bar hopping with my boyfriend and our friends. There's not much seating here, but we managed to find two bar stools up front. We only had one drink here and moved onto the next bar. 

We probably would have stayed longer had there been any tables available. We had fun though. I liked the old fashioned look and feel to this place. I'd come back here again for another drink or two sometime.
author: Veronica L.

description:
Food and drinks are delicious, service was well. Loved the  live jazz band. 
I am from LA and I was excited to try this place out when I visited San Francisco this weekend. Glad I did!
author: Vanessa N.

description: Best Old Fashioned!!! Actually, great overall drink menu, and delicious food. Not to mention the awesome ambiance. At the top of my list for a fun night out in San Francisco.
author: Kristin N.

description:
I came here for dinner on the recommendation from a friend.

Loved the ambiance... Old West feel with really cool fans above the bar. What a great space!

We had the Rabbit 3-Way appetizer, the beef shank pot pie & the Cioppino. Dessert was the banana burbon pudding. For drinks we both had the Blood & Sand.

Rabbit 3-way: Love the concept. Fried rabbit nuggets, rabbit terrine & rabbit rillette. Execution was not as great as the concept. Seemed dry, over-salted and not especially exciting.

Beef Shank Pot Pie: Boyfriend enjoyed this but said the bottom of the pie crust was soggy.

Cioppino: The sauce in this was outstanding. Spicy & flavorful. However, they were very skimpy on the seafood: I counted 4 mussels, 3 small chunks of fish and a lump of crabmeat. I don't know about you but when I order cioppino, I expect to see the entire SEA up in that bowl. Served with a sourdough crostini which was a nice touch.

Burbon Pudding: Delicious! This was the highlight of the meal.

Blood & Sand: What I expected but not very strong.

Overall I enjoyed the meal, but with a $100 tab for 2 people I expect to be blown away. Probably won't return here for dinner but would come for "Free Lunch Fridays" where you get a free meal if you buy two adult beverages.
author: Tala D.

description:
I loved Comstock!  The atmosphere is very "Prohibition".  Dim lights, dark woods, and small sitting areas.  I also love the big booths.  

We reserved the back area for our party, and we were catered to like VIP's all the way!  The service could not have been better!  We had people coming and going all night, and the waitress did not miss a beat!  Even with the whole check debacle...they don't do split checks (always a huge annoyance), but it was handled and ended up working out!  

We started out with a few appetizers including the "pig in a biscuit", pretzel with mustard and cheddar mayo, and corn hominy fritters!  All delicious and just the right amount to share!  The Saints Buck cocktail ended up being my drink of choice and was perfect and refreshing!  I also tried the Cherry Bounce which also was great, but sweet, and if you are in for the long haul...a little too much if you ask me.  Cocktail are going to run you about 10$ a piece, but it isnt just a rum and coke here...you are getting a great drink and usually an even better pour. 

The space gets VERY crowded.  So if you are looking for a quiet place for some drinks, this isn't it!  But at the same time, it's no club...just enjoy the great jazzy music and drink yourself into a fancy cocktail stupor.
author: Claire G.

description: My friends and I came here while barhopping on New Years Eve. The place has nice decor like they have old school fans rotating on the ceilings. The music was like something from the 1920s. They had a live jazz band playing and even a flapper type of girl dancing and singing. I felt like I was at the bar and Gatsby was going to show up. The service was friendly and the bartenders really try to get to know you. The food at Comstock looked delicious. Comstock is a great place to have dinner, drinks, and listen to some great music.
author: Jason L.

description: I came here on Friday to Saturday March 28-29. I ordered multiple drinks from the bartender working that night, including multiple "dealer's choice" drinks. Every single one was amazing. In particular, the bartender served me a Hotel Nacional that I thought was better than any other Hotel Nacional I've ever had. I am a regular at Smuggler's Cove. I believe it is one of the best bars in the world, and easily the best bar I have ever been to. This Hotel Nacional beat Smuggler's Cove's. Highly recommend this bar!
author: Reade B.

description: Wanted to like this place so bad! The interior is fun and different, the piano up on the mezzanine, and the cool menu....but the staff and the food ruined everything. I was there with a reservation for 10 people (the restaurant has NO business accepting a res for 10, there's no where to put a party that size) the manager was a complete idiot and moved us from the dining room bc he didn't set the table with the correct number...then only allotted us 2 tiny bar tables which would normally fit 2/3 people each. We ended up with 10 people huddled around 2 small tables. Some ended up eating on their laps. We spent a ton of money and the food was mediocre. The manager caused many other issues I don't feel like writing about..all and all, NEVER going back, non of us will.
author: Casey H.

description: Awesome place...great place to hang out. ....good for large groups...  want a place that is too cozy this is it... love it... large selection of drinks... some good food too...... not too pricey and not too cheap either
author: Kevin J.

description:
I'd been anxiously awaiting the chance to belly up to the bar at Comstock. I finally got my chance and can't wait to go back!

I love the atmosphere and old-timey feel. What made it even more cool was other patrons were dressed up all costumey and such. 

The drinks are great; really professionally made and delicious. My Hop Toad Cocktail hit the spot!

It's not your typical bar in SF, but having recently walked the Barbary Coast trail, it was a great additional trek back in time. A unique experience for sure!
author: Greg S.

description:
Cool place. A little packed, but nothing too bad. 
Had a jazz band playing in the upstairs area. Very cool.
author: Rich P.

description: Really cool bar. Nice bartender, good live music and interesting drinks. Cool to see the old bar from 1907 too! Definitely would recommend!
author: Katie B.

description: Zach the bar-back that works at this place is a total jackass. We walked in and sat at the bar, and next to us sitting in the window were what appeared to be antique bar tools. Picking them up was apparently a mistake, as Zach immediately scolded me, took the bar tools, and huffed that they were used in drinks and now he would have to wash them. Poor customer service, the worst I have ever seen!
author: Ashley R.

description: Had dinner here our last night of vacation. Shared the Housemade Beer Sausage - cheddar-mustard sauce and beignets as a starter. The savory beignets were the standout. The sausage and cheddar-mustard sauce were flavorful - but the beignets put the dish over the top. My husband had the Dry Aged Ribeye - mushrooms, spring onion, oatnut crumb, and seared foie gras. I had the Day Boat Scallops - cauliflower, lemon relish, and pea shoots. My husband's meal was well executed. Despite being very specific that I wanted my scallops over cooked - so that they were cooked all the way through, not seared, they came out simply seared. I did send them back and they came out the way I requested the second time. The atmosphere is great - lovely old saloon. A live jazz quartet was playing the night we were there. Service was attentive but slow - perhaps purposefully so, but I would have preferred a brisker pace. If you are in a hurry this might not be the best choice - but if you like a relaxed pace, you will enjoy the experience and the food.
author: Maryann F.

description: The Barkeep's Whimsy is an excellent choice for those who are adventurous with their drinks. The bartender today knows his drinks and made my girlfriend and I two very different, very spectacular drinks. A blended scotch drink that is delicious, smoky, and not overpowering? Yes, please.
author: Schad D.

description:
Great atmosphere and a killer location wedged in between Chinatown/North Beach & FiDi. Nice to see a bartender put some skill into making classic cocktails.

*Would be 5 stars if they would shuck some oysters on Sundays. Nary a bi-valve to be found in N Beach on a Sunday afternoon and that is just criminal.....
author: Josh B.

description: Seated right away on a Saturday night. Friendly service and a cool vibe. Their cocktails were tasty, and I definitely appreciated the vegetarian option! The mushroom pot pie was flaky and buttery on the outside and hot and creamy on the inside. Mmm.
author: Emily T.

description:
Came here for drinks with old friends and we were lucky to get a booth to spend a raucous evening in!  Our waiter was excellent and played along like a champ with all of our little foibles, which would probably infuriate any less patience or sporting waitstaff.  The food was a bit off and overpriced for what we got , I actually can't even recall what we ate (cheddar crackers with pepper jelly?) but the drinks were EXCELLENT.  My lovely ladyfriends had the foresight to order me a Moscow mule in advance of my arrival, it was one of the better mules I've had in my life, clearly made with care (as was the Pimm's Cup I had later, yes I am that predictable).  The Barkeep's Whimsy is delish no matter what you get--we ordered several iterations and each was delightful.

The jazz band playing up on the balcony was great and perfectly befitting the setting, which some other patrons were disrespectful of.  Like many cocktail-oriented establishments in SF, Comstock is heavy on the history, class, and taste: not a place you come to get wasted before your club night.  

Local history buffs, keep your eyes peeled for the tasty morsels of decor and ambiance around the Saloon, like the cast plaque memorializing Emperor Norton over the bar and the funny tiled channel under it.  Comstock, is that an old urinal or part of a pre-1906 street gutter??  Curious minds inquire!!
author: Karen R.

description: OK. I wanted to check in from Comstock when We were there but We were having too much fun. I recommend you sit at the bar. By the end of the night you will feel like part of the family. I know I Did.
author: Patricia H.

description:
Live music. Go earlier in the day. 

Ask your bartender to get you a ginger based cocktail.
author: Abhi M.

description: Wonderful location for drinks. Some of the best in north beach'. Be sure to order the bartender whimsy and have a taste profile ready. Either other cocktails you like or taste in drink. The bar tenders are super fun and will treat you right!
author: Lauren B.

description: Comstock service, live bands, restaurant and bar, all deserving of five stars, I'd give it 100 stars if I could. It was absolutely amazing, and their Sezerac (absinthe cocktail) is to die for!
author: Manuel L.

description: This place is pretty much awesome.  I highly recommend allowing the bartenders to make you a beverage of their choice.  Just tell the your mood, your likes and dislikes and an amazing cocktail appears.  Add in some live jazz in the background and you have a relaxing evening of libations ahead of you.
author: Theo S.

description: Wahoo! Awesome place. Live jazz music on second floor while you sip bottles of wine and cocktails on ground floor. Came here on a Saturday night after dinner, got a booth for drinks only no problem!
author: Marilyn S.

description: I'm digging the saloon. The corn fritters were tasty, pulled pork biscuits admittedly a little smaller than I thought and mildly disappointing, and the cherry bounce refreshing. And I liked that it was during the week and it wasn't slammed like some of the other bars in Financial District/North Beach. I think I'll be back again soon...
author: Mel G.

description:
Great space. Great fun. Great drinks. 

A modern bourbon and branch with more space and light..

Great for groups!!
author: Hannah K.

description:
Everything is amazing especially the Scotch egg salad. But the Cioppino WITH dungeness crab $22 had NO visible lumps of
Crab. VERY disappointing. This IS San Francisco after all. The amount of crab in the Cioppino, I estimate, weighs less than 2 grams.
author: DANIEL T.

description:
Comstock can abuse my wallet whenever she wants, enough said. Came here on St. Patty's Day, when our group somehow managed to get a table. I didn't get a chance to try their cocktails, which sounded delicious, but their food was extremely good.

My recommendations:

-Oyster po'boy with ham - hands down one of the best sandwiches I've ever tasted! Perfect little balls of oyester-ey goodness exploding in your mouth with every bite, wrapped with ham and aioli. If that image was too much for you, then you should probably not order the Oyster po'boy.

- Artichoke soup w goat cheese - very good flavor in this soup, with an interesting goat cheese and crouton mixed in. Simple yet surprisingly good choice.

- Gnocchi w asparagus was good but a bit overpriced for the portion they give you.
author: David P.

description: This place is awesome. Drinks are killer and the food is great. It's always way too busy at the bar but if you can steal a sit it's fun to hang. Also the host there (I'm not sure his name but he's been there for years) is such a nice and accommodating gentleman. He really helps you out with whatever you need. Props to you sir.
author: Jebidiah P.

description:
Comstock gets very crowded very quickly. It's on the outskirts of North Beach so there's available street parking and its walking distance to anything useful.

We got here around 5:30 on a Friday and it was packed. There was a little table outside with service so we grabbed it. The interior is beautiful - sleek and modern and a fireplace if you and your group can get there early enough. Luckily it was an incredibly warm day in the city, so the table outside was perfect.

Our waitress was incredibly nice and efficient, even with an overly packed bar, my drink was never empty. There is a food menu, which unfortunately I didn't try, but I'm definitely going back for it. Anyone who has the balls to put bone marrow on their menu knows their good.
author: Analisa S.

description: Stumbled across this place after eating at the House of Nanking. We wanted a cocktail and Comstock hit the spot. We sat at the bar and Claire was our bartender. She was amazing. She knew what to do, how to do it and how to make it look smooth and easy. Drinks were awesome. Since we already had dinner, we ordered a desert; Butterscotch pudding. Save your money. It was too thin and watery for my liking. The drinks were definitely worth every penny. The place is sophisticated and classy without being stuffy and snobbish. Will definitely go back.
author: J S.

description:
Very into Comstock. We came here the weekend of the North Beach Festival...walked by and couldn't resist coming in as it exuded awesomeness. 

Two seats right in front of the bar, old world San Fran feel with amazing glassware. So thin and light, it's elegant and without a doubt one of their best features. The weightless gimlet or martini that makes it easier to sling back. The bartenders are pretty much a blast from the past with expertise on old world style drinks that make you think saloons, gun fights and gold mixed with a bit of New York. I'd recommend to just letting them go for it and give you their drink of whimsy.

Oh, did I mention that they do Beefeater as their well gin? Oh yes, cloud nine for Ms. Alita M.
author: Alita M.

description:
Pretty hip, mixologist spot!

Drinks are done to the nines here and the servers are very engaging and sociable!

Good vibes all around!
author: C M.

description:
Reviewing drinks only.

This place is just cool, you don't see bars like this anymore.  Came in for a quick drink, whats not to love here, great atmosphere and friendly people.  Food menu is limited during the day, just some small snacks so we didn't eat.
author: Steven H.

description: What an amazing experience! Managed to snag a late dinner reservation and I was shocked to find an amazing live band playing!! Definitely will be a regular here.
author: Anne F.

description:
Consistently good food, drinks, service, and music. Great for a date, drinks with friends, or a place to bring parents. The drinks are superb and here. Plenty of whiskey/bourbon options and very few sugary/syrupy options--my kind of cocktail menu! Appetizers are unique and good for sharing. Please do yourself a favor and get. the. pretzels. You will not regret it! The warm olives don't disappoint either! 

Love the live music up in the balcony area. (Though, don't plan on carrying on a conversation once it starts). I've seen a good variety of music here. Solo guitarist, jazz band, and one that I can only describe as folksy-hipster. :) Make a reservation and ask for one of the booths by the bar.
author: Alison S.

description:
Comstock has some great old-school spirit-based cocktails.  I had my first Blood and Sand here, and it has since become one of my favorite old-school cocktails, since it's one of the few made from Scotch.

They also make a damn fine sazerac and vesper (stirred, not shaken).
I can't get enough of the revival of the original cocktail craft and the new mixology.

They also have some great food to go with your drink.  Most notably, some delicious housemade pickles, and a bone marrow pot pie.  BONE MARROW POT PIE.  One may have heard of sucking the marrow of life from Walt Whitman... but Comstock has extracted the marrow for you and baked it into a rich and hearty pot pie.  They just make it too easy to enjoy life :).

YAAWWWWPPPP
author: Fong L.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!!!  So too have the folks I've brought and told about the place!  Even when the bartender doesn't have a vest and a cool throwback handlebar mustache the place attracts and has a staff of cool friendly and good looking people (me excluded for modesty's sake). Always enjoy GREAT COCKTAILS made with passion and good conversation often with strangers!  Love when someone is on the upstairs piano, and missed it this last visit!  = (     
They only offer one cocktail for Happy Hour The DERBY $6 (Rye based cocktail) and it always makes my friends and I HAPPY!  And if the first one doesn't the second one does for certain! They also have great snacks (The fritters, olives and pretzel were great this last visit) and happy hour deals!
Come in here when you want MORE THAN A BEER AND A SHOT or SOMETHING SPECIAL!!! Might I suggest if I were so bold, try a Corpse Reviver Two .
CHEERS!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Sean M.

description:
Still decent drinks.  But had terrible service at the bar.

Previous visit:
Blood and sand was awesome, other drinks were good. Food was decent, not great.
author: Amjad S.

description: I just went for a quick drink, but the decor is very cool and drinks are tasty. I got the pisco punch which was good, but I tried my grandmother's South Sider and it was amazing. I wish I had gotten that instead--it has mint, which I usually don't like--but was really great. My mom's prosecco was flat, but once I told the server, she brought a new (bubbly) glass right away.
author: Meredith E.

description: I have only been for drinks. They always seem to have live music and a really cool vibe.
author: Danny B.

description:
Classy and cool place.

The staff are super friendly, and the place has a great vibe. 

But I had check the menu on-line before I made reservations, and was excited to try a few things, but when we were there they had a different menu, and none of the things we wanted to try we're on the menu.

We did have some starters, which were good, and a few cocktails.  The house cocktails were unique, but my wife did not like the drinks. 

So had I been able to try some of the items I had expected to find on the menu I would have been happier.  A bit pricy for the food we did get. 

For now a great place to hang out, but not sure for dining?
author: Ahmad B.
