description: I love the cocktails here. Happy hour is alright. Ambiance is great, live music and a throw back to 1920's decor, I love.
author: Kristan B.

description:
Do you ever have that longing for a bar/lounge you visited in another city and wished there was one just like it in your city?

Well, Comstock Saloon is one of those places I wish was in Miami.

The vibes in this saloon are real chill and an absolute perfect place to go for drinks with friends. Absolutely, 100% it elicits that 1800's saloon feel and it rocks.

Now onto the star of the show......THE BARTENDERS!

These Comstock bartenders are true mixologist. If you do not like anything on the cocktail menu or just do not know what you want, they can concoct something for you.

All you need to say are the flavors you want and off they go. The magic begins and poof an awesome drink appears before you. I had gone with the magic words. 

Light.....Fresh....Citrus.....

Out came one of the best drinks I have ever tasted in my life.

Seriously, if a fantastic cocktail is what you want, Comstock Saloon is an absolute must.
author: Richard K.

description:
This place has so much character! I love it!!

I love the old saloon feel. Great ambiance and usually pretty packed. Great for a drink while in North Beach. 

Try one of their cocktails. Pretty yummy.
author: Christina C.

description:
It's a classy place comprised of a separate bar and dining area connected by a narrow hallway.  It's a throwback to gas lit times where real men wore mustaches and sometimes the women did, too.  

The San Francisco bar scene never ceases to amaze me with their legit drinks and knowledgeable bartenders.  I'm used to swilling light beers, Long Islands, and variations of college cocktails (off brand soda + middle shelf liquor) in DC but in SF you gotta be too legit to quit.

Having said that, there are lots of starchy appetizers to soak up the strong drinks, but I found the fritters bland and the Alligator Toast less so.  The fritters tasted just frittered though, that's a plus.  And the service is very good.  Everything here is meant to ease you into a night of adult beverages and conversation.

The bar area seems to fill up much faster than the dining room, so much so that servers have to exit through the front door and re-enter through the other front door to deliver appetizers to buzzed guests.  There is a tricky ghost door on the dining room side that has an old-timey 'use other door' sign for patrons, which didn't stop wave after wave of folks from trying to open said non-functioning door. I was trying to save them some dignity by not looking but it's very distracting in an amusing way. 

It's hard to give this place a full 5 stars though because our experience was detracted by a very large group of...aspiring bankers?  Drunk yuppies are universally gauche, regardless of what coast I'm on.  The staff did try to manage the crowd by asking them to disperse (aka hit the road) but it took the whole party a very long time to file out and we received no apologies but the table next to us did.  Protip: if you have more than 12 people in your party, this is not the best place to Moët it up.

I'll have to return and experience it yuppie free to give my full review!
author: Czarina B.

description:
Excellent staff and service at this bar.

Enjoyed the cocktail menu of well constructed, palatable drinks.

They don't overdo the bitters/amaro thing that every other bar seems to be doing in San Fran.

And, a fantastic female bartender. Five god damn stars for that.
author: Ell A.

description: The Scotch Eggs are great as are the lamb meatballs. Don't miss the 1907 built bar. Why does yelp requor e more words? Let's see how this goes
author: Logan E.

description:
I originally thought this was a dive because I had never been here before, but Comstock is pretty A-OK in my book.  I came here for a date, and once you get inside, it's like a whole different world that has a NY pub feel with a bit of class. They have good cocktails and some good small bites. We ordered the hangtown toast (SO bomb!) and the pigs in a biscuit (also bom!). We took a while to order, but the staff were very attentive to make sure we had what we wanted. 

Overall, it's a sweet spot that I had originally overlooked, but I'll definitely be coming back!
author: Taylor L.
Brian J.

description:
What a bust!!!!

The quality of their good is decent and the ambience is excellent. 
However, the food is a bit overpriced and presentation is sloppy. A 5 year old can do better plating..... 

We've asked our waiter to cook the steak a bit more as it was almost rare in the center and he brought the dish back with a burnt piece of meat on it. (and probably spit on it too).

In this economy, it's been awhile since I've experience such horrible service. He kept suggesting other items for us to order and once he realized we are not getting another round, he never came back to our table. 

The server name reads Dre on our bill and we couldn't verify it as he never came back.
author: Maggie C.

description:
In my bar hopping all over this country, this is my favorite whisky watering hole of all time.  If I had a personal whiskey dousing rod mine would point to this place like a compass to the north star. In my most recent visit to SF I ended up here every night they were open and one of the saddest parts about leaving town was not being able to come back to this place. 

The white shirt and suspender adorned bar staff here is very knowledgeable and totally legit at making precision classic cocktails. My litmus test is asking for an old fashioned the proper way without the modern era abomination of muddled fruit salad shite. Every bartender that served me delivered an oldie exactly how they should be.  

The inside is cozy and when present the live jazz band upstairs creates a relaxing atmosphere. On weekends it was always packed during prime hours. Most of the time I was able to snag a seat at the bar by waiting 15 minutes or so.  I can imagine after a recent appearance on Bourdain's Layover the attendance has increased so you may not be so lucky. 

The drinks are fabulous. The rotating menu of small plates I sampled were all delicious. The bartenders are incredible friendly. Every night I was here I ended up in pleasant conversations with total strangers. Everything is just about perfect and if you are a fan of craft drinks this is a must stop.
author: Ryan O.

description:
The steak was grilled to perfection.  My tomato salad was meh.  I didn't get an opportunity to taste the appetizers at the table my companions partook in but I didn't hear any complaints.

Thanks to the server for recommending the pisco punch cocktail.  Tasted like a liquor-infused super tarty lemonade.

Desserts were different but good.  I enjoyed both the bourbon pudding and the lemon verbena namelaka.

Service was prompt, courteous and attentive.  Our water glasses were never empty for long.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
Super fun bar/restaurant. We decided to focus on snacks and apps and it was a wise choice. LOVE LOVE LOVE the warm pretzel, was reminded that crackers (albeit homemade) cream cheese and pepper jelly was a great foil for cocktails and loved the potato balls.

Had the pork sliders and found them too greasy for me and not that great but you can't have everything right?

Interesting salad with a quince puree at the base - odd but good. 

I'll come back - next time I can pry myself out of the Mission.
author: holly B.

description: Came here after hitting up 15 Romolo. This is really chill bar. It was around 11:30pm on a Saturday night when we came and there were maybe 15-20 people. The decor is very interesting, the drinks unique, and bartenders very nice. If you're looking for a place to have a conversation with good cocktails, Comstock is a great place for that.
author: Sherry L.

description: It was the duck pot pie that brought us in. We liked the space and had seats in the back corner by the stove. It was warm and cozy. I enjoyed a glass of wine and the husband had a fine whisky. The pot pie failed to impress, but it ended up being a great choice for cocktails.
author: Kellee K.

description: Awesome place. Cool vibe. Good Food.  Great drinks.  Nice People ;)
author: Jordan S.

description:
First off, this review is only for drinks.

Having said that, I'm not quite sure when I will be back.  My first and only experience there sucked!

We came in, grabbed a table, and proceeded to look over the menu.  After this, we waited for about 15 mins for someone to come take our order (did I mention there must have been only 10-12 people here?).  From the time we put in our drink order it took literally about 40 minutes to get a drink, in between which we were given several apologies and told they were understaffed on a HUGE weekend for them.  The North Beach festival.  Makes no sense!  Why ask ONE person to come in when you know the streets are going to be crowded.  And even at that, the place was not even anywhere near being full of guests.

Anyhow, our drinks came 40 mins later and were made wrong.  She tried to pull a fast one on me but I've had tons of pisco sours before.  When I brought it to our server's attention she said "I know what it is, he forgot to put the pineapple gum stuff in it, I was watching him make it".  So if you saw him make it wrong, why would you bring it to us?  It literally tasted like Lysol or something you use to clean your bathroom with.  Ugh...

Such a shame, I was really looking forward to bringing my friends here and having a few afternoon cocktails.  I'm sure this is not what you would typically encounter here (I hope not), and our drinks were comped though.  TG!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I fell in love with Comstock Saloon the first 10 seconds when I walked into this old- western themed saloon on a Wednesday evening. There was a live band playing light jazz on the balcony high above. The music and the low-lit ambiance beautifully set the tone of the saloon: class, sophistication, lots of character, and fun. Best of all, it is a place that really knows their cocktails. Classics like the Szerac and Sidecar are made to perfection. Mmmmm to the Blood and Sand. Again, these bartenders really know what they are doing.  

Comstock Saloon has now become my North Beach haven for cocktail chemistry.
author: Peter T.

description: Waited 30 minutes for our drink and the server comes over and asks what we ordered,  we walked out, they think that they are creating the Mona Lisa. Awful place. I would not go there.
author: Rick E.

description:
You can't really go wrong with a place with saloon in the title.  That being said this was a fun spot to hop into for drinks. We grabbed a booth and were offered drinks promptly. 
 The manhattan was the truth!  Next time I'll have to get here earlier before last call and sit at the bar. The bar seems like the place to be.
author: Janette W.

description:
Fun, lively atmosphere. For jazz performances, the band is waaaaaaay up high. For jazz enthusiasts, this may not be ideal. For everyone else, it'll be a thrill.

Great ambiance. Pretentious? Maybe a little bit.

Beautiful decor. Somewhat friendly staff. Definitely worth checking out if around North Beach.

Got friends or family visiting the city? Take 'em here. They should enjoy the drinks, wine pairings, and vibe. It's definitely a treat.
author: Drea B.

description: An old saloon with some great history that has adjusted to the need to make great cocktails to a discerning clientele.  Too many old saloons make old drinks.  Not the Comstock.  The bartenders here know what they're doing and take great care in making the best cocktails.  They actually have 2 bars...the old wood bar that seats about 9-10, and the smaller bar on the other side in a space that used to be a barber shop.  They call that bar the "monkey bar".  Not sure why.  Both bars operate transparently, so wherever you can get a seat, go for it.  So...the drinks are first class, what about the food?  No clue.  I didn't eat here, just had drinks both before and after dinner.  However I saw a lot of the food come out and it all looked good.  The tables for eating were crowded on a Wednesday night so whatever that tells you.  If you're looking for some booze history in San Fran, the Comstock is not to be missed.
author: David P.

description: Went in for lunch on a Friday, the place had a fun energy.  Ordered a couple of bites, meatballs and scotch egg.  Two of my favorite things to eat.  The scotch egg was pretty tasty, a little too spicy which masked some of the other great flavors but enjoyable.  The meatballs were pretty good also but maybe with a little tweaking could've been really awesome, they were slightly bland but still enjoyable.  Price point was good.  The bartender came over to drops the drinks off and was on point.  Polite, concise and friendly.  Nice job bra! I'd give 4 stars but our server was rude.  And made me feel like a piece of you know:/ I had to leave early to go to my restaurant job so I asked if I could split my cheque, for two small dishes it shouldn't have been too challenging but she informed me that they don't split cheques.  So I asked if I could just pay a set amount on our cheque, she said no, and then told me she was too busy to help me.  Telling a customer who wants to pay for their food that you're too busy to help them is probably a sign that you shouldn't be working in the industry.  Why should I be humiliated in front of my guests for wanting to pay? Sorry for wanting to use this futuristic and inconvenient technology known as a credit card.  I had some cash on me but I had to ask to have change, which wasn't received well.  Next time I'll try and sit at the bar.  Cheers to you bartender:)
author: Mr S.

description:
It's old-timey San Francisco meets "There Will Be Blood" meets wild, wealthy west. And it's not too far to walk from work for lunch or a drink with a FiDi pal.

There wasn't anyone else in here when I first came in for lunch, so it's hard for me to gauge what it feels like to be in here on a busy evening. But I loved the atmosphere, even with just a friend and a hubby in there to start.

Lunch is a gut-buster if ever there was one. Roasted pork belly sandwich with some spicy sauce on it. Cool-looking (and tasting) potato chips and arugula salad on the side. Loved it, but had to hand the rest to my garbage disposals to finish it. A bit of my friend's chicken-fried rabbit was pretty good once you get over the bunny thing. My mister's "picnic plate" of meat, cheese, mustard, and select veggies was good and very picnicky, as promised. On that note, I didn't think this was very everyday fare, so that will probably affect how many times I came back to eat.

The pisco sour and maple bourbon cake were perfect. Definitely coming back for more of the famous drinks, if not to eat that regularly.
author: Tara R.

description:
Although closed during the day time, Comstock is an eyecatcher - sleekly slate on the outside with saloon era decor on the inside. I've been eyeing this place for month for its attractive historical quality and finally got to go for happy hour with C.

Sadly, their happy hour offerings are not extensive - only one cocktail available for $6 and beer/shots for $6 with 2 for 1 snacks (NOT appetizers). Despite that, the bar/first room was packed around Thursday 5:30, and there was a steady stream of patrons coming in after us. We both got the Derby cocktail since that was the only one discounted - I don't remember the liquor in it, but it had a nice mixture of mint and lemon, which I liked, and the drink itself was strong, which I also liked.

C is completeing the 7x7 Big Eat 2012 list, and since the pickled egg was on list, we tried the House Toast that has pickled egg and bacon with a slaw on the side. The toast itself was a good mix of flavor - the smoky bacon was a welcomed contrast to the pickled egg. The slaw had a strong celery taste, which I personally liked. It was a nice happy hour appetizer before our dinner, but the dish wasn't paritcularly to our taste. We both agreed that it was unique in itself, but not something we would salivate over. 

Though I wasn't particularly WOW'd this first time around, I would come back to try their dinner menu and to enjoy the live piano man (he was sensational, i kept looking up at the little upstairs piano alcove just to admire him) and the back-in-time feel.
author: Jen L.

description:
My SF trips have lead me to many eating and drinking establishments.  Luckily this time I ended up at Comstock. 

My first visit was a daytime pick me up.  I had walked by and it looked like it was a hip place.  My second walk past led me inside.  The bar is exquisite and ornate and reminds me of one of my Boston faves (Stoddard's).  I like the old fashioned propeller fans too.  It was real low-key with only a few patrons.  I sidled up to the bar and got their Happy Hour special beer and shot (Trumer and Genever) for $6.  The beer wasn't full sized, but thats OK.  Not the greatest service, but not too bad.

The next time we rolled through on a Friday night.  There was a much livelier vibe this time around, accentuated by a great ole timey piano player.  We scored seats at the bar right away. Both of us tucked into the MOST DELICIOUS COCKTAIL a Cherry Bounce.  We also got some pepper jelly and crackers which was just OK.  Service was terrible though so we left.

Seriously, the vibe and the Cherry Bounce are the reasons enough for 4 stars and a return visit.
author: Katherine D.

description:
The atmosphere, bartender's attire, and the live band really help give off the feeling of an old western saloon.  They have a nice list of cocktails and beer, but I strong suggest ordering the Bartender's Whimsey.  They are very creative and will make you a quality drink based in one of your favorite liquors.  They are so good, the bartender convinced my friend (who doesn't like whiskey) to let her make a whiskey drink.  My friend really enjoyed it.

Bottom Line: Good place to hang out and get some quality creative drinks and hang out with friends enjoying a bit of music. Check it out!
author: Jonathan M.

description: I love the live music and the way the waiters and bartenders are dressed here. The cocktails are good. I finally ate here and got the steak.. delicious.  It had this awesome spicy sauce with it and my meat was cooked perfect at medium rare. Meat was tender. Friends got the burger and also enjoyed it. The only thing lacking is the attention they gave us.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Damn good cocktails, great service, enough said.
author: Dilly M.

description:
It seems redundant to wax astonished at how GREAT the cocktails here are, but Comstock has been my benchmark for perfect drink mixing since I first came here a year and a half ago. 

They play delightful music (especially the live music) and the food is magnificent. So glad I tried the beef bone marrow pot pie, which is absolutely worth all the hype.

I'd come here much more often if I could. :)
author: Christina M.

description: Great ambience, crowd and drinks. Unique for the area and popular enough to know without being a crowd. The food maintains the premise and could be a draw independent from the main attractions.
author: Chris B.

description: Food was good. I'm not a fan of mushrooms, but I loved the mushroom pot pie! Scottish egg was also delicious! And there was live "honky tonk jazz," which was fun and made it feel like an old timey saloon. BUT, being that it is a saloon, I have to give this place only 3 stars because the drinks were rather mild. I was hoping for more darker spirit drinks, other than a manhattan. Cherry Bounce and Blood&Sand were nice and sweet, but I would've liked something more bourbon and scotch forward. Zeinie cocktail was overly sweet and belonged in a tiki bar vs. saloon. If this place had a wider range of options on the cocktail list more fitting to it's saloon theme, I would've happily given it 5 stars.
author: Riz W.

description:
i just had lunch at comstock today.  i was drawn in by the lovely historic decor and nice selection of sandwiches.

i had the cheeseburger and fries.  my burger was done a perfect medium rare and it was juicy.  it was a little salty and the fries weren't quite done but i ate the entire burger and a good portion of the fries.  would i go back?  yes.  their melted cheese sandwich looks good and i might want to try one or two other things on the lunch list.  the prices are reasonable and the service is terrific.  would i order the burger again?  eh, maybe.

i think comstock is worth a try for lunch.  and they have quite a selection of cocktails for after work as well.
author: lori s.

description:
I've drank at plenty of bars and this place hands down makes the Best drinks in San Francisco.

The decor, staff, and ambience is stellar. They have fantastic live music from time to time. The knowledge of spirits is much appreciated, you can learn a thing or two. The food is good although a tad pricy and portions are on the smaller side, but your going there for the drinks, pass on the beer and order a whimsy you'll be amazed. Note that this place gets crowded in the evenings and weekends (thanks anthony bourdain). I highly recommend.
author: King O.

description: Stumbled upon this gem and it topped off our night to a perfect evening. Live music on a Friday night, great staff, and great history of the place. I would recommend going in the back room and finding a waiter who can tell you about the places history.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to Comstock last Friday for dinner and drinks. Comstock has a very cool vibe and live music- a great place to grab fantastic cocktails and small bites. 

The cocktails were all wonderful. I really loved the Saint's Buck and my boyfriend enjoyed the Country life. For our next round we did bartender's choice. We both wanted bourbon drinks and the bartender was cool enough to do two very different cocktails- one smoky and one citrusy. 

The standout food-wise was the rabbit three ways. The tender fried morsels of rabbit were crazy delicious and the terrine paired really well with the acidic celery and pepper salad served on the side. We also shared the bone marrow pot pie which was as yummy and rich as it sounds. The hangtown toast was the only thing we had that fell flat. The toast was thin soggy with a small sliver off egg on top. It didn't taste like much.

I probably will not return for full-fledged dinner, but I will definitely be back for their well-executed drinks and another serving of chicken fried rabbit. :)
author: Ashley S.

description: Friends and I were looking for a place for a nice drink as we're new to the city.  Stumbled on this place and got a set of Old Fashioneds.  They were pretty darn good.  Definitely coming back for more.
author: Eric C.

description:
If HBO's Boardwalk Empire filmed for a day in San Francisco, Nucky and the crew would drop by Comstock's for a fizz. The service is about concocting the perfect vintage flavor profile. I sampled the Sazerac: rye, sugar Peychaud's, and absinth. I'm still not entirely sure what those ingredients are, but I was delighted with the refreshingly fizzy but smooth effects. 

The ambience is soft and yellowy-gold fun with a heavy dose of hard wood. It's been listed in Esquire and GQ as one of America's top cocktail bars. Obviously this is where the straight, attractive, finance district SF men hang out with their lady friends on Saturday night. The place was packed with good-looking hipsters of all ages so I can't imagine how delightfully easy on the eyes it is during the after work cocktail hour. Next time I come, I'm going to wear a faux fur scarf or chandelier earrings so I match the vibe.  

I haven't been there at lunch, but the menu said it's free lunch with the purchase of two adult beverages. Cheers!
author: Kara S.

description:
I'm not sure if I'm the only one who has noticed this, but this place is called a saloon. Quit bitching about the goddamn food! If you don't like it go to Gary Danko or something! 

Sorry. The drinks I had here were awesome. The bartenders were professional yet extremely down to earth; something I appreciate a great deal. I love being able to speak honestly to the bartenders and the folks working here were more than willing to engage me. I even mentioned that I would be spending my evening bar-hopping, and they gave me some great suggestions.  

Bottom line: If I still lived in the area I would come here every day I could. Don't let the naysayers fool you, this is a great bar.
author: Ryan F.

description: Another era bar. I do like the quality and flare... but... ehhh  this one might've taken the time machine too far back in time. Its like the Back to the Future series- the third one wasn't very good because they went back to the old west. I mean it was fine. It was no original. And it was no second one- which possibly might've not made all that much sense after half of it... and this era bar is kind of.... if you really enjoy the 1800s/BTTF Part 3/ a fiesty washboard and banjos band, this is your place.
author: Emily D.

description:
I rarely end up in north beach on a Friday night but recently I did and i struggled to find an open table at a restaurant. Comstock was able to accommodate my party of two without a long wait. They have a great dining room separate from the bar area so I was able to enjoy great cocktails and a meal in peace. 

The entree portions are large and flavorful and the menu offers several interesting choices including a great vegetarian main dish that I shared a long with a few appetizers. Zucchini stuffed with rice on some excellently seasoned black beans with mushrooms. The wait staff are all very attentive. 

As for my drink I went with the barkeeper's whimsy with a bourbon request. I got a very interesting cocktail that I enjoyed. This will definitely be one of my top dinner choices next time I am in North Beach.
author: Leuwam T.

description:
Popped in here last night and for some reason, didn't think I would like it nearly as much as I did.  Unusual since I usually don't feel that way when I hit a new place.  Happy to say that my experience here was way better than I ever expected.

The bartender, Jeff, was a real character.  At first, I thought he was a little over the top, but after a while, I realized he was pretty cool and highly entertaining.  He makes some fantastic drinks too.  Exactly what a bar like this needs.

Had a Southside ($8) made of Gin, Lemon, Sugar, Mint, and Seltzer as well as a Martinez ($12) made of Old Tom Gin, Sweet Vermouth, maraschino liquer and bitters.  For some reason, perhaps because of the ingredients, I thought I would really like the Martinez and that the Southside would be just okay.  As it turned out, reality was the exact opposite and the Southside was the real star of the two for me.  The reason for this was that despite the list of simple ingredients, the bartender used just the right amount of each to turn it into something really special.  A touch more or a touch less of any of the ingredients and the balance would have been off.  This was one made perfectly...mine was so good!!!

I really liked what they did with the decor of the former SF Brewing Company and the band playing overhead brought back memories of some clubs I've been to in LA.

As I sat at the bar enjoying cocktails and good conversation with the fun couple next to me (Hello to Manuel and Alicia!), who should walk in the door, but Francis Ford Coppola himself.  Yes, that's right...Francis Ford Coppola!  Drinking a well-made, old world cocktail in those surroundings with Coppola just a few feet away really made the place for me.  The crowning end to a day that started awfully with a broken car and then slowly got better and better. 

Was originally going to give it a four, but because of the above, decided the Comstock deserves a five as it far exceeded my original expectations.
author: Roy N.

description:
In love with this bar.  Only tried the drinks here.  There were old fashion style and yummy.  I had a Pisco punch, which was excellent.  My better half had an old Manhattan.  omg, it was incredible.  They had homemade maraschino cherries.  Not normally a whisky drinker, I could have drunk this without a problem.

I also loved the ambiance here.  The decor was like a 20s parlor, but not cheesy.  There was a fun, upbeat crowd there that made you not want to leave.

Also, the bartenders were awesome, fast and delicious.
author: Victoria P.

description:
Great cocktails! I had the "blood and sand" which was delicious in spite of the fact that it lacked cherry brandy (I think they used a cherry liqueur instead). The decor charmingly evokes the intended time period but, thankfully, reinterprets it for a less rugged clientele (urinal at the bar, anyone?) 

Especially nice for tourists.
author: Catherine T.

description:
Even though, as you enter, and you notice everyone from every sort, urban hipsters, Noe vagabonds, tech geeks let out of their cage, lost bridge-n-tunnelers, and people who obviously have a Banana Republic employee discount or just really, really, really like Mad Men...you swear everyone is wearing spurs on their cowboy boots and that the couple from Noe actually tied up their horse instead of parked their Mini Cooper...but...

Side note, people can debate all they want, but that little narrow trough at the foot of the bar may, just may have been used back in the day by lazy cowboys to urinate into while they stood at the bar.  Some say yes, some say no.  All I know is that I sort of wanna try it.

Anyway, what to order...the hangtown toast, corn fritters, pig in a biscuit, and, by all means necessary, the beef shank and bone marrow pot pie...you'll enjoy ordering it aloud...say it with me...and you'll most absolutely enjoy devouring it with a loved one.  Oh, and don't forget the pretzel.

Really good...really damn good.  Eat and then go next door to Vesuvio for a Guinness or two.  Perfect evening.
author: Eric H.

description:
TWO WORDS: Pisco Punch!

Love this little spot! And, to my delight, just discovered it was on SFoodie's Top 92 Picks AND that my favorite server, Dre is there - one of the city's friendliest, and rather knowledgeable servers to date! She used to be at Delarosa, and now she's here! Defintiely going to come back for more cocktails here!  Oh, and to try their food offerings as well!

Think: the casual, unpretentious version of Bourbon & Branch! New favorite thing in my life, and rather prevalent in the city: Prohibition themed spots!
author: Tammy H.

description:
This review is strictly for the bar only. I will update this if I try the food.

My friend and I walked over here after dinner in North Beach around 11pm on a Thursday night. The aesthetic is beautiful, but the lighting could have been a *tad* darker. I'm really big on cozy ambiance. 

The music was meh (piano player only played like 3 songs and then Tom Petty-esque music began). 

The service was...okay. The hostess was really nice and promptly took our drink order. However, the bartender never made them and the hostess took the initiative to get them made when she realized we were waiting for a long time. After she went home no one attended to us when we were done with our drinks and were ready to go. We had to flag someone down for our bill (and it was not really busy). 

Oh, and the bleach smell?? I could barely concentrate on having an enjoyable time with that horrendously strong bleach smell. Not sure what that was about but it was really distracting.

On the bright side, the drinks were good (stiff) and there were hooks for coats/purses, which I love. This place might be better for a larger group than just two people.
author: Cindy M.

description: I was so overwhelmed by Comstock's gimmicky feel that I left after the appetizer and finished dinner elsewhere. Stop trying so hard to be a saloon/tavern and just be one. Drinks were ok, but not anywhere near Wayfare's.
author: Natalie J.

description:
I finally was able to make it to Comstock & thoroughly enjoyed my afternoon there. Started with a FREE lunch (yes, I stated free) which was a wonderful cod sandwich & salad. BUT...it was the cocktails that were a big hit. Had a "Cherry Bounce" which was delicious and then had another. The wait staff was great & the bartender who happened to be one of the owners was charming & gave us the backstory of the place.
Will definately go back & recommend big time.
author: Googie G.

description: I finally had the chance to grab a drink at Comstock Saloon and had a good time. Yes the drinks are expensive but the atmosphere is great and harkens back to an earlier time in San Francisco. They have some good concoctions and I'm sure I'll be back to try some others.
author: Blake B.

description:
Since I already reviewed the drinks here, this review is for their dining area. Decided to eat here with a friend since it was close by to where we had to be after dinner. Now don't get me wrong, I LOVE Comstock Saloon. They make awesome drinks and the scene here is incredible. The food however, is inconsistent. Since it was my first time eating here, I decided to go with the 3 course pre-fixe menu.

The pre-fixe menu consisted of a cold pea soup, a prawn salad, and a beef dish. I did not enjoy my soup. It was mixed with sour cream, cold, and just was too thick and sour for my taste. It looked amazing, and I probably should have just looked at it instead. Might have even enjoyed it moreso. The salad though, WOW. Amazing salad. The prawns had a little crispy coating over it, which was just lightly fried. Salad was very well seasoned and didn't have that heavy feel to it. In all, just a great combination of a light prequel to my entrée that I would order over and over. My entrée was a beef dish topped with mushrooms and a side of sauteed vegetables. Yummy vegetables, but I was just confused by the meat. It looked like a steak, smelled like a steak, but was not a steak. It was a mushy round piece of meat that was squishy in the middle. To be fair, it wasn't half bad, but god damn the sauce was salty.   

If I were to come back, I would not order the pre-fixe menu again. I should have listened to everyone and gotten the bone marrow pot pie, but I wanted to be charismatic and go with a different choice. That choice busted me in the ass. Service here is great as always, and the waiter was very cordial. Great drinks, just don't know if I'd eat here considering my dinner was $55.
author: Michael W.

description: One of the few places that makes quality, craft cocktails. Jeff and his team know the art of drinks created for the connoisseur, not the consumer, of libations. Not to be missed!
author: Noah L.

description:
It's all about the liquids at Comstock

The drinks are awesome.

The food made liquids come out of places liquid shouldn't come out of.
author: Fahkin A.

description:
Order the Poutine! Made me miss Montreal! The bone marrow and shank pot pie was tasty too.

The fish entree was huge! Cooked perfect with crispy skin, along with hash browns and sauteed kale.

Awesome classic cocktails, with heavy pours so watch out! 

Great old school saloon ambiance.
author: Derrick V.

description:
I needed to kill a Friday afternoon - what better way than with alcohol!

It was my last day in SF on a work trip.  I had dinner reservations and an open afternoon.  I'm a certified cocktail geek and knew SF had a great cocktail scene.  I sought out a joint to live up to SF's cocktail reputation and Comstock did not disappoint.

I hoofed it over from Union Sq on a warm, sunny afternoon.  I stumbled in to find 3 other patrons chatting with the bartender and sipping drinks under a large paddle wheel type fan - definite vintage feel.

I was thirsty from my trek and figured I needed a long drink to start.  The Southside Punch seems to be a bit of a signature drink so I went for that.  Wow, I could have slurped down three!  I've put this drink into my own rotation at home.

I had heard the bartender talking about Death in the Afternoon, so I inquired about it for round two.  I wasn't smitten by the champagne base so I asked for another suggestion.  But the bartender replied "No, I'm making you a Death in the Afternoon."  Of course it was just what the doctor ordered!  It was my last cocktail before heading to dinner.  It was in the afternoon.  It was perfect!

The bartender was quite friendly and engaged me in pleasant cocktail geek conversation.  The tab was $20 for two quality cocktails and I had a good buzz going.  It was a screaming deal as far as I am concerned.

If I lived in the neighborhood, I'd spend every Friday afternoon here.  And then I might be unemployed.  Perhaps it's a good thing I don't live in the neighborhood.  I enjoyed the quiet afternoon atmosphere, but would love to come back and check out a Friday or Saturday night.
author: Karl R.

description:
Two words: Free lunch!

That's right, following the century old San Francisco tradition of free lunch (in the late 1800's, the bars used to be owned by the brewers), you come in have a couple of adult beverages and your lunch special is on the house.

I missed out on this last year when they were open everyday for lunch, so now this is only available for Friday lunch.

But let's not just talk about free food.  They cocktails are killer as well. My favorite is the "bartender's choice" where you let the bartender make you something based on guidelines you provide.  

The Manhattan and pickled egg, is actually listed in 7x7 magazine as one of the things to eat in SF before you die. It's really nothing fancy, just exactly what it's supposed to be.

Several times I've stopped in there, there's also been some kind of old-timey music ranging from a barbershop quartet to someone just pounding away on the upstairs piano.

I've been here with a group, with a friend and even alone, for a cocktail and sometimes something more substantial (and possibly even free), I've always been pleasantly surprised!
author: Michael M.

description: After a slightly underwhelming dinner at Park Tavern the BF and I ambled over here, took a seat at the bar and took in the wonderfully old timey saloon decor. We were immediately greeted by a bartender named Karri, and given drink menus. As we perused for something tasty, a three piece jazz band started to play in the upstairs area that looks over the whole bar. We were impressed, and relaxed into our seats. He got the Cherry Bounce and I got a Bar Keep's Whimsey, which Karri nailed in making according to my vague and pretty silly instructions. We chatted about the significance of 4/20 with our bartender and a fun couple next to us and ordered 4 more Bar Keep's Whimseys, which we all different and all delicious. We agreed that everything here is quality - the service, the ambiance, the alcohol, even the ice cubes. And the best part, its totally unpretentious! Thanks for a fun night out Comstock!
author: Courtney L.

description:
FINALLY I can say I've been to the Comstock and it did not disappoint!

First off, the fact that they even had Tecate in a can as a beer option receives two thumbs up in my book.

Second the richness of the mahogany bar, the heat of the stove fire in the back and the assortment of sliders/appetizers makes for a perfect hangout for the Fi-Di drained souls who work nearby. The ambiance, dark lighting, cool bartenders and live music (upstairs) makes for an awesome date spot or happy hour go-to. 

Highly recommended. Look for me at the bar with my Tecate in hand...
author: Stephanie J.

description:
I visited the Comstock Saloon to celebrate a friend's birthday on a crowded Saturday night. All of us were impressed with the decor that paid homage to San Francisco's history. We also enjoyed good, live jazz.  I had a seat at the bar and received attentive service.

The bartender really knew how to make proper drinks. I appreciated that my martinis were stirred and not shaken, that cloves and cinnamon sticks were added to hot toddies (many other places skimp out on these two very important ingredients), and that he lit my Manhattan on fire before he served it to me. Actually, I'm not even sure if that last step was necessary, but it had a definite wow-factor!

This place is definitely worth visiting. Why not sip on a delicious dirty martini and learn a thing or two about Emperor Norton (among other things)?
author: Ellen L.

description:
Drinks were strong and tasty. I especially liked the south side cocktail and the brandy drink with elderflower. The crab cake was tasty with big moist pieces of dungeness crab but it was a bit salty for my liking. The beef shank and marrow pot pie was flavorful but the meat was dry. Surprisingly, my favorite dish of the night was the gnocchi with mushrooms, which I wasn't even excited about ordered (why order vegetarian when there's bone marrow on the menu???). The gnocchi was cooked just right and those mushrooms were great. I'd say a 3.5 but with an extra bump for the fun live band playing in the balcony.

Bottom line: drinks were great and the food was decent, but not amazing. It's a cute place and gets crowded (and loud). But is it just me or are others getting a bit tired of the whole old timey theme that so many bars/restaurants are doing lately?
author: Ji-In L.

description:
this is a very cute place on the corner of the st. the waiters and bartenders are also super nice. it def has a fun character to do with it's wooden decor and tall bar seating. the music is not too loud that you can still carry on a decent conversation and you can also people watch if you are near the window. the atmosphere is fun and slick. 
take some time figuring out the drink or just talk to the bartender and they can make you something tasty.  

will def try to come back next time when there're bands playing
author: Ai L.

description:
The service at Comstock Saloon was some of the best I have received in San Francisco. Instead of waiting at the bar for 20 minutes to ask the bartender for a menu, he promptly passed one towards me and my friend as soon as he saw us enter the bar. It was crowded, and the host went out of his way to find us a place to sit. Our server was incredibly attentive, and didn't seem put-off at all by the fact that we were only ordering drinks and dessert. I was blown away... I've never been treated so well!

The live music was tucked away in a loft above the bar, which was perfect because it didn't take away any floor space, and made it enjoyable instead of awkward. (see: musicians who come to your table.)

On to the goods. The drinks are STRONG. We ordered a Hop Toad and a Blood & Sand. I guess we should have expected to be knocked over based on the descriptions, but we were obviously not very observant. They were good, just verrrrry stiff. 

For dessert, we got the maple pudding, which was awesome. It had a great, real maple syrup flavor. 

I can't wait to go back for a full meal!
author: Kristen B.

description:
Best Bar in the Chinatown/NB

Terrific and friendly staff
Wonderful hand-crafted cocktails 
Delightful Atmosphere 
Delicious Food
Historical Charm 
Great Jazz
author: emily b.

description: This place was amazing. Randomly stumbled in and had a drink to the tunes of a live jazz band. This is what a bar should be like. The next day we came back for dinner, which just confirmed our suspicions - this is the kind of place that does things right. They don't have an extensive menu but the things on it are incredible.
author: Fredrik G.

description:
French 45. What a tasty beverage. It's a healthy mix of gin and sours topped with a splash of champagne. I went on a Monday night and they had a really cool guy jamming out on the second floor piano.

Great environment, great services, and really tasty unique appetizers. I'll be going back for sure.
author: Jason M.

description:
The bar at Comstock is like going to a friend's house who collects glassware. Never have I seen such beautifully delicate glasses from which lovely-tasting cocktails are served. The bartenders take their craft seriously and arrive for their shift with their own briefcase full of tools of the trade. 

My sazerac was New Orleans-worthy and was nicely complemented by the bar snacks. The fried potatoes, gravy and cheese curds (poutine in my book) was rich and delicious and the light and flavorful Hangtown toast was just the right amount of snackage for our cocktails. 

Try the boot and a beer happy hour special which will get you a shot of whiskey in a boot-shaped shot glass with a beer back.
author: Lee H.

description:
I really like the atmosphere of Comstock Saloon.  It's old-timey and everyone seems to be dressing to match the decor.  The drinks are mostly bourbon and whiskey, so be prepared for a delicious vodka-free cocktail menu.  

Here's why the 3 stars:  I work very near Comstock, and on Friday we go there for their Free Lunch special.  If you order 2 cocktails, you can get a dish for free (which changes from week to week and is not on the regular menu).  The first week we tried it they brought us a lovely rabbit stew.  Very, very good.  Then last week, they brought us a pot roast over polenta.

Bad enough that the polenta was completely tasteless (I'm not so sure they even salted it?), but the meat was like rubber.  I honestly thought they microwaved it.  We politely informed the waiter that it wasn't so great - and he was very nice... but mentioned that they don't even have a microwave.  I have NO idea how they ruined what was clearly a lovely cut of meat this way without the help of a microwave.  It was a real bummer.

So, we ordered a few appetizers to make up for the sad meat, but nothing seemed to be going well that day. The scotch egg was overdone and over-salted, the fritters were overdone... it was just not their day.

I'm big on consistency. I really want to like this place, but I don't want to play the "Will it be edible?" game when I go out for lunch.
author: Lindsay S.

description:
I happened to stumble upon this place and was so happy I did.  This place is a hidden gem!  I felt like I stepped back into time.  Great atmosphere!  There was a musician up above playing saloon tunes and it had that 1800's feel, even down to the detailed antiques placed throughout the place.  

Great mixology on the cocktails.  I went for the pisco punch.  I haven't tried the food but highly recommend the saloon.
author: Brea B.

description: Eh.  Maybe I caught it on an "off" day (aka Weds at around 5 pm-ish), but I wasn't extremely impressed.  The barkeep was really pleasant and "The Barkeep's Choice" was pretty decent, but the crowd was pretty mellow.   I'll have to come back soon on a weekend to see what the HH crowd is like and maybe, to sample the food.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
~3 Stars as a restaurant; probably more as a bar.

Went here last night to celebrate our friend Grace's birthday.  We split the rabbit starter (tasted like chicken nuggets, didn't care for the rabbit toast), pigs in a biscuit (the best) and the beef/marrow pot pie (good but not overly flavorful).  One of our group got the tri tip salad, which was dreadful, inedible.  Something definitely went wrong with the seasoning of that dish.  The the five of us split the butterscotch pudding with short bread, which was a total hit.  I had a Blood & Sand (something with whiskey and cherry liquor -- I just can't resist cherry), which was quite good.

I found the menu to be hard to grasp, as it was all over the place with no discernable theme.   It was amazingly noisy even though we were in a cozy, very cool booth.  The server was very friendly but service was slow (15 minutes to get drinks) and then all the dishes came out at the same time, even though we ordered two appetizers.  Add the cost factor into the experience (~$50 per person, tax, tip, with one drink per person, average one dish per person and two desserts split amongst 5 people) and this doesn't seem like a good use of dining dollars to me.

Live jazz band and the overall decor were big positives.  This is a cool spot, which is why I imagine rating it for just drinks would garner a higher rating.
author: Kevin M.

description:
First time coming here since the space changed hands and I'm really impressed.  The place looks pretty similar from what I remember from 6 years ago, but obviously a lot has changed.  

I went for "barkeeps choice" on all my drinks, cause I love going to a place for the experience.  All the drinks are excellent.  Live music?!  Fried grits with a salad.  This place intrigues me!   The view is pretty great on a Saturday night of the North Beach crowd party buses.  D-bag central outside.
author: Corey V.

description: Not your average bar! Bartender used only the finest and freshest ingredients. He mixed drinks like an artist and never seemed flustered. Only suggestion is to be patient for your drink! It will be worth the wait.
author: Brandi G.

description:
i got the bartenders choice-
told him i liked fizzy and gingery.
he nailed it.
author: coffeecake j.

description:
There aren't many other places I'd rather be when I want a proper drink.

Be it a "serious" cocktail like Sazerac or Manhattan, or something for the casual drinker in all of us such as an Arnold Palmer or the house-style Martinez, Comstock does not disappoint. Neither does the live music or, for that matter, sightings of men with handlebar mustache or other old school relics.
author: Son N.

description: I met a good friend here for lunch today and I am so glad I did. We split the burger and the chicken sandwich. Both were really great and at around $12 each seemed like bargain. Glad to have found this place. I will definitely be back soon!
author: Adrienne G.

description: Very classic bar. At first, I enjoyed sitting down and chit chat with my group of friends. It was a birthday celebration, to be honest we are not making too much noises, its average noise. We stayed until 2AM and we were standing outside and saying our goodbyes, one of the bartender come outside and said "go sit someplace else, kids". We are, mostly, 24-26 years old. And we pay good amount of money, there's no need for an attitude like that.
author: Sabrina S.

description:
If I had gone in here with zero expectations, my review would be four stars, but I made the mistake of hearing good things and falling for the sexy decor on the outside.

...which is not to say the decor disappoints.  It's got an old-enough feel with some anachronistic elements like belt-driven fans, but all cool stuff.  when I went, it was late on a Friday and the bar was packed, while the rest of the seating was open to all drinkers, kitchen was closed.  I should mention here that it irks me when a place that serves food allows drunk people to sit at their tables during a more "club-like" scene later in the night.  Makes me suspicious they don't change tablecloths or keep hygiene up to a high enough standard, and makes me suspicious they really care about the food.

However, my drinking experience was good.  Got a table in the window with my two co-conspirators, and even though it was late and a bar, there was still a water boy filling glasses.  Very nice touch.

I'll go back to try again, during a different time, like a weeknight or maybe for food.
author: Lauren J.

description:
Came here last night for my friend's going away. The live band up in the balcony was a nice touch to the lounge-y atmosphere. When we first arrived there was only one bartender on duty making drinks for both the restaurant and bar area, so the wait was pretty long. But after an hour another bartender joined him and shit got real.. 

The sazerac, old fashioned, and manhattan were the drinks of the night. And they make their drinks STRONG. Like burns-all-the-way-down-maybe-I-need-to-take-my-time-with-this strong. we scored a table around 11 before it got too crowded. But once it got going we were shoulder to shoulder in the bar area. Definitely a place to stop by if you're barhopping in north beach.
author: Calvin L.

description:
Some of the best cocktails I've had - and they make a mean manhattan. 

When you walk in you feel like you've been transported back 100+ years. There is a bartender there with a curled mustache and wears suspenders with his black pants and white collared shirt - makes me smile every time. 

On some nights they have musicians playing live jazz up on a loft platform. It's a great place to take someone new to the city or stop by and have a few drinks after work. 

Food and Wine recently rated this in the top 5 bars in San Francisco, making the top 100 list in the US.
author: Holly C.

description:
OMG OMG OMG, just lunched at the Comstock Saloon with the incomparable and infamous Chili Bill (www.thechilidog.net) and I am in a swoon.
 
Although I did NOT have a "live" drink (tonic water w/lime twist was my choice) due to it being a workday for me, my partner in food, had what they call a "Free Lunch", if you order two drinks! Today it was their amazing homemade bratwurst, and all the fixings.
 
I had a delicious, fresh bowl of chicken and rice soup--what made it "fresh" in my terms was the lightness of the broth, to which they had added basil, kind of Thai-esque.  And while we waited for our food we were treated to a VERY AMUSING amuse-bouche of thinly sliced boiled/pickled eggs on toast triangles with a see-through thin slice of twisty-crispy bacon.  I sort of wished they could just make me up a platterful of those and then go away.  But then came my three little piggies: perfect little buttermilk biscuits with pork rillets, cooked and then put on the grill and smashed good until crunchy, ohmygod.  There was a little allspice that gave the crunch just one more flavorburst, the biscuits couldn't have been more perfect, and it came with a couple slices of homemade pickles and some coarse, stone-ground mustard.
 
I am FULL, but I feel like I floated up to heaven.
 
'nuff said. 

OK, maybe not 'nuff: bartender and host were wonderfully pleasant, too.

Yep. Maybe it was heaven.....
author: Kimberlista M.

description:
Old school vibe with carefully crafted cocktails.  I liked the vibe of the place.  It's divided between the rambunctiously loud bar area (including a live jazz band performing on the terrace upstairs) and a much quieter dining area.

What stands out here are the drinks.  The blood and sand was really good and although I didn't partake, there's an option for Barkeep's Whimsy, where you rely on the bartender to prepare something delicioso for your palate.

In terms of food, I liked the starters and appies much more than the mains.  The cheddar crackers with pepper jelly and cream cheese sounded  like an odd combo but was a big hit of nice complementing flavors.  Also, the pig in a biscuit was a mini pork burger with slaw that was a good way to start the meal.  

In addition, we had the rabbit prepared 3-ways - chicken-fried (yeah!), served on toast (meh) and a terrine (blech).

Although I chose the pot pie for my entree based on our waiter's rec, I found it to be rather dry.  I did, however, like the juicy and large scallops that were the entree of the day.

One big negative: when we sat down, we were the only ones in the dining room (the place filled up though by the time we left).  And a worker there takes out a large compost garbage can PAST US through the front door to take outside.  And then brought it back inside the same way.  Ugh, pretty disgusting, especially since the offending odor lingered.  Isn't that rule number one that you don't bring trash out through the dining room?

Anyways, overall a pretty good experience though.
author: F. P.

description:
We loved it, and we'll return. The skirt steak and fritters were much more than "just OKAY" per an earlier comment.

Hubby and I were buzzing around on scooters looking for a late dinner spot. It was a gorgeous, misty North Beach night with a late moonrise. We found the Comstock, wandered inside and had a wonderful experience!

My husband ordered the skirt steak, I ordered ricotta gnocchi, and we had fritters. When we ordered our meals, they arrived in about 10 minutes, maybe a few more. It surprised me how fast, but we didn't feel rushed either. We enjoyed some champagne and good conversation, listening to the string band upstairs. When the main courses arrived, oh my goodness the smells wafting upward were (here comes cliché) intoxicating. I took a moment to appreciate the smell of the hot ricotta and reggiano parmesan mingling with what looked to be home grown string beans, baked & sliced elephant garlic, etc.  Mmmm!  We shared dishes. I wanted to order another skirt steak!

The meals were perfect. I had the banana bourbon pudding with a birthday candle. It was damn skippy. We had Turkish coffee from silver French presses, more cocktails, friends joined us, more food, more conversation, more music. Really, it was a lovely, memorable dinner. Our waiter was knowledgeable, attentive and commendable.

I'm not a foodie. Simple fare, perfectly prepared at a reasonable price is what I love. Delicious comfort food with a slightly (but not overly) California cuisin'ish feel. 

There are lots of little places, little parlors to duck into if you wanted to come for cocktails only. I plan to do so.
author: S S.

description: Great saloon, bar keeps are in bow ties and know how to make drinks. Got a old fashioned, gin and tonic and a darn all were very good. Be sure to walk a couple blocks to SAMs and get a double cheeseburger and fries great food.
author: Toby T.

description:
Really nice bar in a great location.

This is a great place to get water!  We sat down and ordered a couple of drinks (nothing special just beers by the bottle) and I swear my water glass must have been filled four times by the busboy before our drinks arrived.  I mean my god, how long does it take to pop the cap on a bottle of Sierra Nevada and get it over to the table??  Also order food and it never arrived.  After 45 mins had a WTF moment and told the server to cancel the food.  To finish the whole wonderful experience the food was on the bill so I was ready to have a fit.  No tip and I made sure to give the busser five bucks for being the only person in the joint with a work ethic.
author: Neil A.

description:
I liked this place. Comfy, cozy, great drinks... Love the old timey atmosphere.

word to the wise: if you're ordering a fancy drink, be patient. This isn't McDonalds, yo!
author: Sarah N.

description:
Very underwhelmed.

The lounge atmosphere is great, but we ate in restaurant part and it was nice, but not nearly as cute or cozy. The staff was also excellent. But I go to restaurants to eat, and the food was unimpressive.

Wine - we ordered a bottle of Chardonnay. It was so acidic we had to send it back. I realize it was the cheapest bottle on the menu, but it was still $28 and there were only a few wines on the menu and this one should have been chosen with more care.

Pigs in a Blanket - by far the standout dish. This is worth ordering again. The pork was delicious and it came inside these lovely biscuits with homemade pickles, coleslaw and mustard on the side. The whole dish worked beautifully. I would recommend going to Comstock for this and cocktails.

Salad with creamy dressing - this was literally lettuce covered with the most flavorless dressing ever. There was no flavor.

Rabbit fried chicken - It was a good dish. I was fairly full by the time they served it but the rabbit roulade and the fried rabbit nuggets with celery salad were quite good.

Sausage and white beans - I was unimpressed. I didn't think the flavors worked well together. And personally, I do not like very buttery dishes and this was served with a greasy piece of toast.

Overall, I would recommend going to the lounge for drinks and the pigs in a blanket, but on the whole I thought the food was too pricey for the quality.
author: Jordana M.

description: Went it this place on Monday night for a few drinks after dinner and so glad I did, ended up working our way through the cocktail menu with some great guidance from the excellent bar staff. Drinks were smooth and very well mixed. The menu looked very good and the food we saw on tables looked delicious, unfortunately we had eaten but would go back to eat. Being a Monday there was live music which was upbeat and lively, great staff and friendly patrons, struck up a few conversations and had a thoroughly good time. Carefully though, easy to get very drunk on those cocktails!!
author: Alistair S.

description:
This is a great place. Great classic cocktails, and the group of people who run the bar are really cool, too. Pre-prohibition style, live music, what else do you want?

The downside of the bar for me is the second room: loses much of the character and you can't hear the live music. But it's more appropriate if you want to have food proper dinner style and also talk a lot. Not that the main room is ever that loud. Somehow, despite the fact that this place is mighty popular even on a Tuesday night, I've never felt it's overcrowded or waited too long for a table or drink.

Oh and those fan-like contraptions on the roof -- you just look at them and relax, sipping on your sazerac. Yes.
author: F K.

description:
Classic cocktails, impeccable staff, great music coming from a stage overhead, San Francisco style decor and lively but approachable atmosphere.  

I'll be ordering a not very sweet Bamboo cocktail, possibly a Sazerac.  The bartenders are good and happy to make recommendations especially if you just give them an alcohol like rum or whiskey and a descriptor.  The well dressed staff is super polite and helpful.  The drinks are too small.  I've been to dozens of cocktail bars and unfortunately these are the smallest of the list.  The food is also good (chili, etc.) as well as served fairly late but in correspondingly tiny portions.

The self-proclaimed Emperor of San Francisco (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emperor_Norton) looms over the barkeep directly across from a large working vintage clock.  The walls are textured metal with glowing incandescent bulbs lighting up some of the surfaces of your face leaving some mystery in the shadows.  

They take open table reservations even late and for a bar this is fantastic, how nice it is not to wait in line makes you look like a pro to out of town visitors.
author: Taylor O.

description:
We were recently in SF for the day and decided to recreate Anthony Bourdain's Layover San Francisco.  So we decided to stop in here and give it a shot, or 2.....

Authentic bar with nicely refurbished wooden accents and features.  Old school bartenders with bow ties and ties.  Al of our drinks were chilled in old beakers from high school days.  I had a Makers Mark Manhattan on the rocks and it was awesome.  Great find.
author: Stewart B.

description: Ok this is a real live actual saloon!! Told the waiter I wanted to try something new and different. One word. Stinger. Great night from then on out!
author: Cinnatea L.

description: Classy joint with great cocktails. It feels upscale and the clientele tends to be quite different from that of venues only a few blocks north on Columbus / Broadway.
author: Victor W.

description:
Great place for drinks! Ask for Sudeep on Mondays...he knew how to make a Vieux Carre!!! First time in ages where a bartender knew how to make this drink! 

The only reason I give it 3 stars is because the food menu is not very appealing. My friend and I ended up going elsewhere to have dinner.
author: Jeanette S.

description: Stopped in on New Year's Eve for a couple drinks - I didn't have any food, but Comstock had a variety of local and unique beers (not much on tap) and the bartenders were extraordinarily attentive, kind people. The Host was one of the most friendly gentleman I have met. The saloon itself was beautiful; vaulted ceilings lined with steampunk-esque horizontal fans, all on a single belt system - leading to a motor to rotate it all, placed right next to a balcony-stage filled with jazz musicians. The bar top and other decor was equally unique. Appetizer items can be ordered at the bar as well. A very classy speakeasy experience.
author: CJ V.

description:
Stopped by for some drinks before heading to an predetermine dining establishment around the corner.

Drinks:

Pisco Punch - pisco, pineapple gum, lime (I was told this is SF original cocktail)

Sazerac - rye, sugar, peychaud's, absinthe

Next Time:  I can't wait to get back there to try the food.  I would have to say though it is a little loud if your trying to converse with your group.
author: Ron S.

description:
Dressed up a bit from the SF Brewing Company days, and with an awesome gourmet menu. We had delicious chicken fried rabbit if you can imagine that, as well as housemade pickles. I was really in the mood for wine even though I knew I was going to a saloon, and they suprised me with a well-chosen wine list. Friends enjoyed their fancy cocktails as well. 

Service was also 4 stars--I think the only thing we waited any length of time for was the check. It was definitely loud (difficult for our table of five to hear each other across a small table) due to a large party next to us, but the waiter said he was trying to usher them out as quickly as possible and apologized to us at the end. 

I've noticed that the establishments in North Beach, perhaps more so than any other neighborhood in the City, do an excellent job of honoring their history as they evolve. Comstock is a perfect example.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
Tried Comstock Saloon on a Saturday night.  Came around 9, 9:30, which apparently is the exact time that everyone comes because we spent 30 minutes or so being pushed and elbowed as we tried to enjoy our drinks by the bar.  But then we scored two seats and we really got to enjoy the evening.

Drinks are made with precision and care.  The cocktail menu is mainly old standards with some modern twists.  I really liked the Hop Toad and my bf asked for a bartender's whimsy of "something like a negroni" and really liked what he got.  Our other round of drinks (Martinez and Blood and Sand) were kind of abrasive and not as special.  

At the prodding of the bartender, we decided to get a snack and had the hangtown toast-- pickled eggs and bacon on super thin rye cracker toast.  It was pretty delicious and the perfect bar snack.  Made me curious about the rest of the menu.

Its a loud, bar scene, definitely no place for a romantic dinner.  Large booths are reserved for diners.  Cool old style New Orleans theme with the fans-- and on Sat. night they even had a jazzy live band with stand-up bass and trumpet.

Solid cocktails, button down shirt crowd, tasty bites.  Would definitely recommend it for nights when you just don't want to slum it with $2 Tecates (although, most nights I do).
author: Kristin P.

description:
this place has nice ceiling fans.

we were a little late because i was using the cross-streets listed in yelp (i.e., i was slightly lost...and a block off)...damn you, yelp! 

i'm going to review the food only, as i didn't spend time at the bar.  it was freaking crowded!  

the bbq potato chips were a bit on the stale side, but i just dunked it in the ranch dressing, and shut up and ate it.  what?  

the chicken was hit-or-miss...the dark meat was juicy, the white meat was dry.  it was okay, overall.

had the bourbon pudding with banana cake or something?  it was just okay.

i will probably give this place another shot, and try some of their other food.
author: Miss P.

description:
You will not find these cocktails on the happy hour neon body shot menu at Harrah's.  

You will find a place that oozes style and is true.  

You won't find a better drink in North Beach.
author: Matt P.

description:
I really hate to trash this place since it is fairly new and in the same neighborhood as my husband's business but...........

Overpriced, bad service, crappy food. 

We sat in a booth in the bar area. Maybe that was the problem. I am going to give this place another try on a weeknight, sitting at the bar, no food!!
author: E S.

description:
This is one of my favorite places in San Francisco for QUALITY food and drink. Drinks have depth, showing a delicate hand, and food is hearty while being neither overly heavy or portion sizes too large (or too small).

I've been to Comstock 4 times in the last year, with quality results each time. My favorite meal was:
Appetizer: Chicken-fried rabbit
Main: Marrow and sunchoke casserole 

The rabbit was rich and juicy while not greasy, whereas the marrow and sunchoke casserole was a substantial vegetarian main that was packed with earthy flavors and heartwarming bites, but not too heavy. You can tell by the menu that Comstock has culinary cred, while not being pretentious.

Go for a drink. Stay for the food. Enjoy the retro decor and often live music.
author: Mark P.

description:
Free lunch.  Yes.  A free lunch.  

Order 2 beers and you get a free lunch.  Best deal EVER! For business travelers, you don't get a receipt for the food, just for the beer so you may not be able to expense it (I will add this as a tip too).

The lunch was respectable.  It was BBQ pulled pork sandwich.  I normally won't eat BBQ, but it was a free lunch!  It came with chips.  All in all, the best deal in San Francisco.

Now, the decor is awesome.  The corner of it was once a barber shop and the adjoining space with the long bar was owned by a boxer (I can't remember his name but you will likely recognize it).  The staff where outfit that look similar to old west bar keeps.  There are articles on the wall explaining some of the history.

Really, it is a great place (and I found it on accident).  Definatley give it a go if you are looking for lunch (the two beers don't really help in making it a quick meal)!
author: Ted H.

description:
Handlebars mustaches are back. Jazz bands are back. Vests are back. Proper cocktails are back.

Housed in a venue that has been serving adult beverages since 1907, Comstock is an excellent addition to the San Francisco scene. We sipped our vintage cocktails (mine being the off the menu dark 'n' stormy) and enjoyed the live jazz soundtrack, all while indulging in eclectic bites such as pigs in a biscuit and grilled trout with alligator pear relish (now known as avocado). It looked, sounded and tasted splendid.

The old school style. The stylish ambiance. The timeless cuisine. Comstock Saloon brilliantly does it all.

And one more thing they brought back: my grandfather's pocketwatch. Still one of the best gifts I've ever received, there could not have been a more appropriate place to wear it. Grandpa would approve.
author: Jason B.

description: Came here Saturday night. Late night finger-licking burger, comforting mushroom pot pie, delicious booze, accompanied by jazz. I guess it doesn't take much to make me happy.
author: Stephany J.

description:
No matter how creative the menu, or how charming the decor, a cocktail program is only  as good as the bartender who is serving you, both in terms of mixology skill and customer service.   I have been following Comstock bartender Matty from place to place since he was at Citizen Cake, maybe five year ago?  Since then my tastes have changed a number of times, but Matty continues to hit the bullseye every time I ask him to just make up something not on the menu.

Last time I was in, I had a different bartender who not only remembered the costumer who sat down right next to me (who, as it turns out, had just flown in that afternoon and had made a special trip back to Comstock after having been in only once before on a previous trip) but what he liked to drink as well.  Now, this bartender ended up making me the wrong drink by mistake (I ordered something with a name very similar to one that is on the menu, and that he must make 50 times a day) which, you know, happens from time to time, right?  What matters in a situation like that is how it is handled.  In this case  I was only charged for the drink I had actually ordered, and I got to sample the other one (which I ended up liking) while I waited.  No problem there.

After reading some of the negative reviews on here, I sincerely hope the management realizes that service like that isn't just the reason that customers like myself come back, but possibly the thing that brought us in in the first place.  I'd like to think that everyone who comes in gets treated as well, and that the staff is appreciated by management and clientele alike.

As a full time musician, I've got to say the live music has been top-notch, not your typical "background music" but still understated and appropriate to the size of the room.  Thank you for that!  Oh, and the food is great.  Don't expect anything healthy, and don't come with a giant appetite after working out at the gym.  But try everything, even if -- especially if -- it sounds a little weird to you.
author: Sven E.

description: Very cool bar, strong drinks and late night food served.
author: Kim K.

description:
Yes
Yes
And more yes.

As soon as my buddy Nish N told me we'd be stopping by here and mentioned it is from the same mind who brought my liver Absinthe, well, duh, I was as good as there! And so, with only one night to spend in my favorite city, we opted to head over here and partake in a little (okay a lot) of food and libation. From the cocktails to the nibblies, it was an absolute win win for my palate and judging by the elevated noise levels of our party, the feelings were mutual.

Service was also super friendly and you can't really hate on a place that has bartenders with super duper curled up mustaches and vintage wear. Well you can, but then don't read anything I write since you clearly don't share my brain :)

Definitely check this place out if you are nearby or even cabbing distance, it's sooo worth it!
author: Stephy S.

description:
Maybe my biggest mistake was the XL expectations I came here with.  This place caught my eye when walking by and ever since I have been reading yelp reviews and giddily awaiting a chance to go. 

So a few weeks ago when I met a friend here at 6:30 on a Thursday, I was a bit surprised to find the place pretty empty and quiet.  Where was my mustacheoed bartender? Where was the crowd hovering over busy tables? 

After enjoying one cocktail (which was tasty and nicely presented) we mozied off in search of a more lively scene.  I will give this place another try maybe on a weekend night and hope for better results.
author: Meagan C.

description: Betty and I came here as part of a mini bar hop. The cocktails were well crafted. I had the cherry bounce which was delicious. I would have given this place 4 stars but we sat at the bar for about 10-15 minutes before the bartender even acknowledged us. The place was not crowded at all either. Very sad.
author: Bob B.

description: Mixed feelings about this place, I felt a little unwelcome, and there was an incident involving a very very large roach... That ran right in front of me. But the drink I had was good and the oysters were fresh. Authentic speakeasy/saloon  experience I guess.
author: A R.

description: nice drink of coke and rum and the bar was dark and the interior was casual stools and the dirink was very good.
author: N A.

description: Had a couple of good Blood and Sands here one night, though the burger was just okay. Liked having the jazz band playing in the background (and I don't like jazz). A solid experience, would return for the drinks (though I've had a better Blood and Sand at the Alembic) and atmosphere.
author: Kent L.

description: I went with friends for the first time Wed night to hear the band that was playing.  They were tremendous!  The servers were great!  They took very good care of us, including letting us know when a better table was available and moving us there quickly and efficiently.  We had planned to have dinner there, but we didn't because there was nothing on the menu that we wanted to eat.  Too bad.  My friends loved the drinks they were served.  Apparently it is known for it's drinks.  Decor, band,  servers and drinks were 5 star.
author: Betty G.

description:
I went to Comstock Saloon after a recommendation from my brother.

We went on a Friday night -- it was super loud, so we were seated in the side room to eat. The noise was a bit better, but still really hard to hear the person sitting across from you.

The service was on the slower side, but nothing too bad for a Friday. The menu isn't very large, so we struggled to find what we were going to eat. The food was good, but greasy. 

I think this is a good place to get a mixed drink and a starter, but wasn't thrilled to be eating there and would not go back there for a meal.

++++++++++++

Fast forward 2 years and add 2 stars: I have since gone back more than a handful of times to enjoy Comstock's vast array of vintage and artisan cocktails. 

While I still find the noise level bothersome and the floor plan kludgy, I've enjoyed my experience (and the food) more each time I've gone back. 

My favorite item on the menu, hands down, is the pig on a biscuit -- delicious sausage patties on flaky, buttery biscuits -- heaven on earth. I also had a rabbit pot pie there that was delicious.

More than the food, CS has become a convenient place (easy to make a reservation at a reasonable hour) to meet up with a date or a few friends (large groups not advised) and have a high brow drink and a fun time.
author: Caitlin L.

description:
OVERALL:3.9   DRINKS:4   SERVICE:4   AMBIANCE:4   VALUE: 3.5
Not for the kiddies, this place serves up some serious drink action (food looks pretty adult, too, but haven't tried those goods yet)...And yes, you'll be out $8-$12 to have a taste, but whoaa! Your entire oral & esophageal  cavities will be free of organisms & bacterial squatters after all the alcoholic vapors are through. St's Buck was mahhhvelously stiff & gingery, as were the Moscow Muel + Blood&Sand...I might've had more, but things get kinda hazy after that point...

Stepping inside is like going back in time...place is decked out in kitschy 18somethings knickknacks and servers are bow-tied & waistcoated.  Small attic/mezzanine space houses a stream of live musicians on the antique piano or crooning over the guitar.  Will def be back!
author: Amy K.

description:
The decor is cute, with rotating banana-leaf fans, African-looking statues, and saloon lamps.  Our waiter was very professional and cheerful.  

The fried oyster sandwich was excellent.

I really felt for a moment as though I was in the Old West in a saloon.
author: Niniane W.

description: A group of 6 of us walked in on a Sunday night and were seated at a table immediately. There were only about 4 other people in the restaurant.  We were a little disappointed with their food menu, but I guess this place is known more for their cocktails than food, so we just went with it. I got the spicy fried chicken and it was delish. Crispy coating, spicy flavor but not over powering.  The worst part of our experience was our waitress, she was very impatient with us and not helpful with the food menu at all. A lot of our questions were answered with a quick, yes or no, and the look on her face implied she was either annoyed with us, or had messed her self and needed to go home soon. I'm sad there was an automatic 20% added to our party of 6.
author: Angie H.

description:
