Just had dessert and they were totally friendly about it (we'd already had PLENTY to drink).  We got there just before 12 and the waitress made sure we could sneak our order in just before the kitchen closed.  How nice!

I had the pudding, while my wife had the home made potatoe chips.  After drinking, the two made an interesting combo! :)

The decor is awesome - reminds be of the 30s/40s.
author: Brian K.

description:
Order up a Sazerac it will put hair in places you don't need it. Indecisive? try a Bar Keeps Whimsy and they will get you in the mood, all you'll have to do is just sit back and drink. Straight up as in no ice and straight up as in one of the best damn cocktails I have ever had the pleasure of drinking...the Blood & Sand. Scotch, sweet vermouth, orange, cherry liqueur. 

It is places like Comstock that remind me the pleasures of enjoying a damn good cocktail in the middle of the busy city.
author: Christa A.

description:
Two words will define your experience at Comstock Saloon:  "headbutt" and "whimsey". 

The headbutt is a happy-hour special which comes with a shot and a short beer.  The shot is filled to the brim, and you drink your first sip standing up, with your hands behind your back, bending over at the waist.  For $6.  An excellent way to start things off.

Aside from that, all you need to do is practice saying "barkeep's whimsey" so much that you can still utter it even though you can't stand up.  Put your faith in the highly talented bar staff, and they will keep you supplied with interesting, tasty, and conversation worthy cocktails until you can consume no more.

And there's a dinner menu.

And the kitchen's open until 1am.
author: Jay M.

description:
I was here on a Saturday night for a brithday, and we were definitely one of the few groups there just to drink. It seemed more restaurant than bar, which surprised me.

If you're not looking for a scene though, this place is incredible. The wild west saloon decor was pretty unique for SF, and there was even a couple there dressed in wild west attire! Although when I asked to take a picture, they seemed a little surprised, so not entirely sure they were dressing for the theme.

I asked the bartender for 'Bartender's Whimsy' shots and drinks, and wowza! The shots were actually delicious, which is something I definitely don't normally say, and the drinks were a great combo of alcohol and sweet without being gross sweet. I think she said it had elderflower in it. 

If you're looking for a unique SF drinks experience, I recommend checking out Comstock and asking the bartender to stir you something up!
author: Megan S.

description:
After reading Bauer's review for the Chronicle, where he claims the cocktails are some 'the best in the city,' I am left asking myself really?

My overall experience at Comstock was nice. Three friends and I walked in around 8pm this last Friday and were promptly seated at a booth. Our waiter was thorough and helpful, but he did seem a little unhappy when we decided to only order drinks. Nevertheless, he brought our drinks over with a smile and left us to enjoy them. 

I was really excited to taste my South Side, but really... I shouldn't have been. I would say it was fair at best. I gave my friends' drinks a try, which included the John Collins and the Hop Toad. All seemed to miss the mark. I feel that given the ingredients in each drink, many of us could mix a better cocktail. A certain expectation comes when paying ten a drink and the drinks here just do not make the cut. 

Bored with my drink I kept looking over the menu. I was tempted by a few of the appetizers and was pretty close to ordering something until I caught a look at some of the food plates at the bar. I do not know what it was, but it was the worst presentation of food I have ever seen. The image of a chubby 5 yr. old boy serving himself at HomeTown Buffet should come to mind.  

I am curious to know what gin was used to mix my drink. I should have asked after finishing it, but it seemed a moot point. The impression was made. Something is lacking at Comstock. For what they got to work with, they have to pull it together.
author: Lee M.

description: Comstock never disappoints! Service,cocktails and food are always top notch.  How can you not give 5 stars for Free Lunch Friday .. Just amazing
author: Jennifer S.

description: Oysters average, shrimp cocktail less than average. The cocktail sauce was ketchup with a hint of horsey, and the service was pretentious at best.
author: Lost S.

description:
My friend: "I found a place that I think you will like because it's like drinking in Disneyland."

Me: "What does that mean?"

My friend: "You have to go to understand."

Okay, now I understand. Cause this place is super duper cool and old time-y. It feels like you walked into the ice cream parlor on Main Street Disneyland except instead of 1 million rug rats and ice cream you find adults looking for some libations and cuisine. LOVED IT!!! 

We had lots of different drinks and a sampling of their desserts. No complaints. Great service, great beverages and unique sweet treats. We had a great time & will be visiting again I am sure of it.
author: Lori B.

description: The food was decent as well as the drinks, however i seem to find that as far as drinks go they are not able to stray from their menu very much. Worth a try, but I personally would go elsewhere for cocktails.
author: Shadi N.

description:
I've heard good things about this place. 
Sadly I never got to try a drink because the (live) music was too loud. 
Crazy loud. Like 11/10 playing at an amphitheater loud.
People were shouting conversationally.
The Hostess seemed nice, although I couldn't really hear her. 
Hostess: "WE HAVE MUSIC EVERY NIGHT!"
I had to split.

...and Jazz isn't even in keeping with the theme!
author: R W.

description:
Comstock is like a beautiful blend of Bourbon and Branch and 15 Romolo. Upon telling our bartender JB this his reply was, "and we won't ask you for a password." 

As soon as my friends Nicole L. and Chris J. walked in we were greeted by a fantastic host who said it would be a couple minutes if we wanted a booth and showed us a menu. The menu is a soft leather bound creation (and yes the bar does smell of rich mahogany). After perusing the menu I went to the bar and said to myself, this is the kind of place I can get a real old-fashioned. Brandy Old-Fashioned sweet.. with orange. The owners brew their own brandy, which makes your mouth extremely happy.  I'm going out on a limb to say it was the best old-fashioned I have ever had... and I'm from Wisconsin. (Did I mention it's also only 8 bucks?!)

We were seated quickly and our server JB did a great job. All 3 of us were huddled around one menu and literally within 30 seconds he appeared to place another in front of us. Nicole went with the appetizer, the cheese crackers (which are like crack covered cheese-its with pepper jelly mmmmm). Chris went big and got the beef and bone marrow pot pie. Talk about comfort food, the crust was buttery and flaky and I really understood why my mom always called it "mud meat" when she put beef in the crock pot. Per usual I ordered dessert, I went with the Bourbon pudding with shortcake. WOW... seriously WOW, that is all I can say. 

To sum up the food I will again quote our fantastic server, "I would eat pot pie and bourbon pudding for every single meal if I only needed to live to 27." 

It was fairly busy but all the waitstaff and employees were attentive to everyone's needs. Best hospitality I have experienced in a long time. 

Kudos to you Comstock, and I am sorry Romolo.. but you are very close to being replaced as my regular watering hole.
author: Hailey P.

description:
I've long since written off North Beach for any type of activity outside of seeing shows (Cobb's, Bimbo's, etc.). However, Comstock throws a wrench into my entire characterization of this neighborhood. 

Great 1920's decore, bartenders that can actually mix - it is true, get the Bartender's Whimsy, tell them a few things you like and they will deliver, and a great mix of people who come. If I ever dared to live in North Beach, I would easily make this my neighborhood bar. As for now, I'll keep it a great after work drink spot.

Just go and see for yourself!
author: Adeola O.

description:
Hell. Yes. 

I actually ate and drank at Comstock last night, so here's a review of inside. The space is gorgeous -you've seen the pictures,  all lovingly refurbished, from the polished wood bar, to the lazily-rotating fans, to the player piano. Yes, they kept the old (now non-functioning!!) piss trough under barstools. Hilarious and a nod to the past. There are booths in the bar area, a sitting area in the back and a separate dining room. Love the tile, the ridiculously soaring ceilings and textured wallpaper in here.

oh? the food? just wait. Belly up to the bar and order yourself something strong - I had the Manhattan, followed by the Sazerac - both done right. If you aren't inclined for alcohol they serve ginger beer and sarsaparilla (!!). 

Ok, the food. Crackers with cheddar cheese spread - so tasty. Can this really be bar food? I'm never going back to hot wings. The potato fritters were lightly-fried, potato-bombs of goodness. The crock of beans can be had vegetarian and non-. The non-veg is savory and delicious. Finally, the beef shank and bone-marrow pot pie: I think this will be their signature dish. I have never tasted pot pie so complex in flavor and light. It's hard to share once you start eating it!

Oh and dessert - I love the desserts. They are the kind of desserts my grandma used to make - desserts forgotten and such a pleasure to rediscover. The filbert cake is a savory cake with whipped cream. It comes out warm and is perfect for anyone who doesn't like really sweet desserts. If you do have a sweet tooth, I recommend the confections plate: sassafras (which tastes like root beer) candy, peanut brittle, and chocolate fudge. 

All in all, I had a terrific night. The mustachioed staff dashing around were helpful and friendly. You can also tell there is real genius in the kitchen. Comstock has transporting ambiance and food- it's everything I imagine the perfect saloon to be. I can't wait to go back.
author: Mission S.

description: Wish I could have tried their drinks. Waited about 10 minutes without service or even having our presence acknowledged. Way to run a business team!
author: Ashley G.

description: The hand mixed unique cocktails here are fantastic!  I've only eaten here once and the food was GREAT!  Wish I didn't live on the other side of the continent.
author: Marcia B.

description:
I like everything about this place except for how crowded it gets.  Some amnesia gas would help if people forgot about it when I'm on the way over.  The drinks are excellent, the food is great.  Usually I'm there for drinks, but when I got the food, I was very, very happy with it.  Bartenders and servers are also excellent, and it can be a friendly place.  The only other negative besides how crowded it can be is the parking sucks and the bus routes to North Beach suck too.

It doesn't get crowded in the afternoon, so if crowds really bother you, go on Sunday afternoon.
author: Spike S.

description:
Came on a Saturday night just past 9pm with my mom and her friend.

We needed to eat food but after eating some bread and cheese during the Laker game, we didn't need a full meal.  I figured I'd take them to Comstock since we were nearby and I had heard good things.

I got a Southside Cocktail, which was light and refreshing (but with a good pour of gin).  We also ordered the fried oyster cocktail, the crock of beans, and the beef shank and bone marrow pot pie.

The oyster cocktail was delicious with perfectly fried oysters, though at times they were hard to get out of the cocktail cup (they kept sinking into the cocktail sauce).  The beans came with a biscuit (tasty but a bit chewy in a non-biscuit-y way on the outside) and included salt pork.  It's a subtle dish and similar to something I make in the slow cooker at home.

The pot pie was delicious, though small.  The side of salad is a perfect accompaniment as the pot pie itself is rich.  at $18 it seems pricey for the portion but bone marrow isn't easy to come by.  

I definitely recommend this place for a date (in the dining room where it's pretty quiet) and with friends in the bar room.  I would love to go again and see if I can get a booth in the bar area.
author: Naoko M.

description:
So it seems the common denominator of the new must-try places in SF is friendly, attentive and genuine service.  Came here for predrinks on my birthday while waiting for a table at Tommaso's.  Great interior, and classy in the best sense of the word.
They won me over when not only did our waiter load up the olive garnish in bf's martini, he also bought our olive-loving table a couple extra cocktail sticks loaded up with olives.
I love olives.  Comstock is a gem.
author: Jane F.

description: I got seated quickly, and the service was wonderful. I'll remember this place, yes, but I'll never forget the kindness from the staff here. Thank you!
author: Nathan N.

description: Wonderful old-world atmosphere with a wonderful bar staff. Had a drink mixed with absinthe, amazing!!!! Just what we needed after a long day in the city.
author: Melissa F.

description:
I started this place out at a mere 4 stars. It's grown on me, so I'm upgrading it. Plus the waitstaff all recognize me on sight now. I still don't spend nearly as much time here as I'd like - the usual greeting the waitstaff starts out with is "Haven't seen you in ages, it's good to have you here!"

I never pick my own drinks - I always order Bartender's Whimsy. Unless you're dead set on the perfect sazerac or Sidecar, you should too. Just tell him your favorite flavor.
author: Darren M.

description:
Huge improvement for SF Brewing Co, which seemed to take a nose-dive in service and quality in it's last few years of operation.  The place looks way nicer inside.  The tall booths were a nice alternative to the sticky tables.  

We trusted the bartender to make our drinks, choosing only the Hangar One Buddha's hand as a base.  Aside from the obvious fresh-squeezed citrus added to it (unnecessary) I'm 90% sure he added absinthe.  Now I'm not opposed to absinthe, but I don't think it lends itself well to such an acidic drink.  The first sip tasted a bit like NyQuil right after brushing your teeth.  After that, it was less abrasive, but far from tasty.  

I say order one of their suggested cocktails, I'm sure they are a bit more familiar with those flavor profiles.
author: Dave H.

description:
My review is a bit biased because I didn't really eat dinner here...but I did drool over the dishes my friends had.

Why wasn't I eating? Well, I had just stuffed my face at the Craw Station (see my review http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=cXoKpS2xgsAuZlmR__Dm-g) and met up with friends who were having dinner at Comstock to catch up. They had the fried rabbit, a chicken with peas dish, and the trout. I will say, the trout looked amazing, and my friend raved about the fried rabbit.

I did share the shrawberry shortcake-esk poundcake dessert and thought that was kind of mediocre... but I'll need to return for that trout!
author: Shafaq C.

description:
This place really knows their cocktails & the bartenders do a great job with their "barkeep's whimsy"  You just pick a liquor or style of drink and they'll make you up something random or unique.  5 stars for the bar!

The food is comfort with an upscale twist, which unfortunately means smaller portions.  We had the hamburg steak & the pot pie.  We both felt the steak was a much better dish, a sort of deconstructed burger & fries with a rich tomato gravy & duck fat deep fried fingerling potatoes.  The pot pie was very rich and tasted of bone marrow, but it was small like the ones you get at the grocery store, and with only a very simple, lightly dressed salad as an accompaniment.  3.5 stars for the food.

Finally, the ambiance.  This place is plenty loud, but a great live jazz band cut through the surrounding chatter.  They have a lot of interesting historical pieces on the walls near the bathroom.  5 stars for a fun atmosphere.
author: Sally L.

description:
I'm just the IT guy and taste tester. My wife writes all the cool stuff

A few weeks ago we went to Comstock Saloon for a bite to eat.  The entire place is amazing, from the decor to the food, and everything in-between.  When you step inside you feel like you are traveling through time, or probably more accurately, walking onto a movie set.  The staff and musicians dress the part of this Barbary Coast saloon and restaurant.  Every detail of the interior design dates back to historical periods from the wallpaper to the glassware to the wood furniture and lighting.  The clientele in their modern day clothing, and with their modern day portable electronic devices, are the only things reminding you of present day.

Many people go for the classic cocktails, which are created using a variety of sherries, bitters, brandies, and herbal liquors and include drinks such as Manhattans, John Collins, and Sazeracs.  The food is also based on the fare served at the turn of the century.  Pork terrines, Hangtown Toast, and Shrimp Louie among the dishes.  For our dinner three of us shared corn fritters, jalapenos, and basil yogurt dip; fried rabbit with rabbit toast and celery & fennel salad; arugula and watermelon salad with goat cheese.  The corn fitters were light, fluffy and sweet.  They paired beautifully with the spicy jalapenos and the tangy yogurt dip.  I don't know if I've ever had rabbit before, the fried rabbit was served as three little nuggets of juicy, tender rabbit meat with a nice crunchy coating.  A slice of toast topped with shredded rabbit was served alongside.  The shredded rabbit was moist and rich.  The celery and fennel salad offered a nice complement to the rich flavors of the rabbit.  Lastly, the peppery spice of arugula was paired with the sweet watermelon and tangy, sweet goat cheese to provide a nice bit of green to the meal.
author: Chad G.

description: I came here for drinks and really enjoyed the atmosphere. Classy vibe, jazz vocalist  on the upper level, decent drinks and a relaxed crowd. Based on the reviews, I think I should try dining here some time aside from getting drinks.
author: Celia C.

description:
This is just about the live music setup,but could be reflective of the whole place.
It's great that they have live jazz,but ISOLATED upstairs?They can have background muzak piped in if they are going to do that. The drums sound the loudest with the overall balance unsatisfactory.The best experience will come if the players are at the same level with the audience/customer for maximum interaction,audibility, connection,and satisfaction(Gold Dust, O'Douls,etc.). The players can play softly if that's what they want,but don't treat them like lepers. Weird...
author: Mag N.

description: Sunday dinner experience was lovely.  Dj spins Americana (yes!) that is fitting for the classic interiors.   This is a historical building and brew house.  Dinner was potato stuffed squash blossoms, fresh beet salad, and fried chicken.  Ordered coffee which was served individual press pot and was good.  Service was excellent and food was conscientiously prepared.
author: cm g.

description:
Went here a few days after they opened. I have absolutely nothing to complain about. The place was beautiful, absolutely gorgeous! So many original details, has a very old NYC building feel to it (which I personally don't think we have enough of in SF, thanks to all the red tape).

The staff was super friendly and the drinks were great. Not syrupy, classic and spirit driven. This place is definitely geared towards local folks who enjoy great cocktails. NOT geared toward the vodka drinking bridge and tunnel crowd at all. I am sure eventually they will get complaints about the drinks taking too long and the lack of "vodka like" drinks but YAY for SF, we finally have a reason to go to North Beach!! I can't wait to go back.

Thank you Comstock!
author: Kara S.

description:
Stopped here last night and had the best Blood and Sand I've ever had.  Everyone else at the table enjoyed their cocktails as well.  Although I think 3 of the 6 of us had the Blood and Sand.

Beautiful inside, saloon style but classy (not cheesy).  LOVE the huge pulley fan.  Loved the old style clothed bar tenders and waiters.
author: Lauren S.

description:
You can tell from the sidewalk that Comstock Saloon will serve up a mighty fine cocktail, but I was primarily interested in the snacks. Sure, the old-time-y ambiance is comforting, and it's still early enough that you can get a seat during happy hour on a Friday. But I can get a tasty adult beverage in my kitchen. What I CAN'T get is a bone marrow pot pie. So.

At 6PM on a Friday night, we were seated by a window, through which we saw the antics of more than a couple of unsavory characters. My friend ordered a Sazerac (described as "boozy") and I ordered a Pisco Punch (which I will call "delicious"). Along with our drinks, we placed an order for the crackers with pepper jelly -- which I could eat every day, for breakfast even -- which arrived promptly. It took the drinks much longer than the 5-10 minutes others have quoted, and then it took 20 minutes of furtive glances at our server to get the chance to order food.

We ordered the crock of beans with biscuit, the fowl, and the pot pie. I was under the impression that the portions were small, but we WAY over-ordered. Everything was fairly yummy, but we barely touched the beans. We just didn't need them! The pot pie was ridiculously rich and creamy, and I found myself doling out bigger and bigger bites to my companion. There was no way I could finish it myself.

Even though I was stuffed, I would have considered the platter of confections, which reminded me of the treats my grandmothers made when I was a kid. However, the service was just too slow. Our server was far more attentive after our food arrived, but it took us so long to get to that point that I just wasn't interested in rolling the dice. 

Next time, we're going to sit at the bar and see what happens. I'm torn about the rating, because the food/drinks were pretty fabulous, but the service (for us) just wasn't up to snuff.
author: Katie T.

description:
I really liked Comstock Saloon, it was a nice place to lounge and relax with friends in the city.  The decor was pretty awesome with it's dark, understated wood and old fashioned fans cranking and churning along the ceiling to create some air.  Though located in North Beach right by all the strip clubs, entering brings you into a totally different atmosphere.  We entered and were greeted by someone (the manager perhaps?) in a cream colored suit who led us to a choice of several places to sit.

We got situated towards the back of the room (as you walk in, the bar is along your right and there are tables with cozy looking booths along the left), where there was a large comfy old fashioned sofa, lights and a few side tables.  The menu is pretty simple, with tasty sounding small bites and interesting drinks.  

I ordered the barkeep's whimsy ($10), and told the server to make it a bit light and refreshing, while my boyfriend ordered the sazerac.  Both came out quickly, and I was very pleased with what was concocted for me -- a pineapple gimlet!  It was the perfect blend of tart and sweet and alcoholic tastes.  The sazerac ($9, rye, sugar, absinthe, bitters) was SUPER strong.  This is not something you can chug, peeps.  It's served room temperature, and just one tiny sip made me feel like I was going to exhale ethanol fumes.  

This place is NOT the destination to bump and grind against some sweaty creep, chug your drink like it's Pepto Bismol or even wait 25 minutes for some extremely complicated drink by a bartender who has to use a science textbook and periodic table of elements to make your cocktail.  Comstock Saloon is an unpretentious place to go to chill and enjoy your company with a perfectly made drink at hand.
author: Laura S.

description: Manfriend and I had just polished off two delicious comstock cocktails and tucked into some amazing oysters and the cheese plate, when he (manfriend) started to feel an allergic reaction. Super rare for him, but sometimes happens. Crux of the issue, the entire staff within proximity was so, so helpful. Sarah, our server, was really great and understanding, in particular. While this is more a review of the service than of the food (unfortunately, because what we had thus far was awesome) I do get to say, the service was exemplary, and we'll absolutely be going back.
author: Eileen O.

description:
I seriously read about Comstock in 3 different magazines so I just has to go. 

The first impression of this place was great, the staff were all really nice and attentive. Just went in for drinks on a Saturday night and got a booth right away. 

Get the cheddar crackers with pepper jelly. Amazing. 

I got ballsy and ordered a sazerac. Holy shit. Tasted like cough syrup. Not my kinda drink, but good for a few sips. 

I traded drinks with my boyfriend who got an orange something or other and we were happy campers. 

So glad this place is in my neighborhood, definitely on my short list of places to go.
author: Britney K.

description:
Comstock has great cocktails, an interesting and delicious menu and a cool old-timey vibe, often with live music. I'm not sure you could ask for a better combo of attributes in a bar. 

The menu rotates, but favorites include the corn fritters, the hangtown pickled eggs, the duck liver mousse and the bone marrow pot pie. (Especially the bone marrow pot pie.) I dare you to sit down with a few friends, order a table full of appetizers and snacks, and not end up smiling. 

Drinks can take a little time to arrive if the bar is packed, as it often is, but they're made with care. The bartenders are smart, knowledgeable and easygoing. Don't be afraid to riff off the set cocktail menu. They can handle it, and welcome it.

Biggest drags about Comstock tend to be that it's crowded and expensive, but come on. What place worth visiting in that neighborhood isn't, especially at prime time? This is a city. Deal. Someone wrote an earlier review and mentioned no parking options? Be serious.

Bottom line: Comstock is wonderful. An easy five stars.
author: Brian C.

description:
A great bourbon drink made by a guy with a curly handlebar stache is always going to get 5 stars.  The laid back atmosphere (even if you can see tourists with fanny packs walking by) and amazing food would be reason enough to check this place out.  

We went for happy hour on a Friday, and it was a bit of a wait/hover/stalk-people-who-look-like-they're-getting-ready-to-leave to get a seat.  Over the course of the night I had a Sazerac (better than average), the gin & mint drink (very refreshing), and the "barkeep's whimsy" - my favorite by far.  You basically tell them what liquor, or any other info a/b preferences, and they make something up for you.  It took a while but involved setting orange peels on fire, so I was fine with waiting...

For the food - pepper jelly + homemade ricotta reminded me of really fancy deconstructed pimento cheese (in a good way).  Fritters - who doesn't love crispy fried melty goodness?  Best of all were the little sandwiches - pulled pork stuffed into biscuits so buttery my southern grandma would approve of.
author: Katie P.

description: Great cocktails, vintage saloon feel.
author: KB B.

description:
awesome. great small plates. vegetarian friendly. place is very cool and feels very "kentucky derby/great gatsby" in scope. 

get 'the derby" cocktail special. 

their 'upscale" HH is decent. you get GOOD booze for your buck here. The white bean hummus was light and refreshing with crisp crudite.
author: Jenn T.

description:
If you loved Maverick or Tombstone, then youll love Comstock. Walking into this bar alone is enough to make you wish it were halloween so you could put on your garters and chaps. 
Themed bars and restaurants are a dime a dozen, but whiskey and bourbon bars are few and far in between. Start off walking past one of the hosts with the amazing moustache, and sit either at the bar or in one of the many booths. 
The drinks are not too stiff but very refreshing, even on a cold SF night.  I would def stear clear of the pigs in a biscuit (very dry, think cold hard Mcdonalds egg muffin) and the corn fritters (way way way too greasy)
Service was pretty slow, considering we were the only patrons at the bar, mid week at 2pm. 
Would come back , again for the decor but not the food or drinks...
author: Jenn H.

description:
The good:
- Very well constructed and tasty beverages
- Friendly staff
- Excellent atmosphere & decor
- Classy option for the area

The bad:
- The corner of Columbus and Broadway gives me the ick's

Overall we really enjoyed this place. We came here late on a Saturday night. I was surprised (but pleased) that it was not very crowded. I suspect that was just due to the Union St fair. 

I didn't realize that Comstock served food. I was under the impression that it was drinks only. We will put this on the list of possible places to grab dinner in the future.

Frankly I don't see this as being a regular spot that we visit. More of a special occation type place. Or an excellent place to bring out of town guests.
author: ruby h.

description:
Our usual order: a Martinez, a Southside, the picnic plate, and a pot pie. 

The cocktails here are among the best in the city -- in the same league as Nopa, Jardiniere, Absinthe, Rickhouse, 15 Romolo, Burritt Room, and  so on.

It's all killer. The hosts are warm and friendly, and the live music is appropriately eclectic for a saloon.
author: Joe G.

description: Love the atmosphere. Came in with my fiance after dinner and it was pretty busy. We just sat at the bar for a drink since I just wanted to experience it. I would love to come back some time to eat dinner. Nice bartenders. Had a nice time chatting with a few people here.
author: Lynn C.

description:
On first impression, I'll admit I was a bit nervous. Sit down at a corner table in the bar area. Water comes out. Wonderful. Host spills water all over. Wonderful. And apparently not entirely uncommon. 

Move to bar itself and have an entirely different experience. It's much brighter (yet definitely not too bright) and more open. There's also a great view of the balcony where they sometimes have great live music. Friday night it was ragtime-ish. Annnd you get to watch all the delicious cocktails being made. 

The frst round of cocktails was quite tasty. Sazerac and manhattan ($9 each, both on the menu) are albeit kinda hard to mess up. Round two bodes even better with the bartender's choice option ($10 each). Just let them know what you like (my preference was bourbon or rye, not too sweet, and spirit-heavy). Alicia made two delicious concoctions of her own bourye (four roses bourbon and old overholt) and various well-chosen mixers such as lillet and orange bitters. Seriously two of the tastiest cocktails I've have in recent memory, and, trust me, I've had plenty. 

My advice: definitely sit at the bar (you can still order food there), and  if you know what you want, go with Alicia's recommendations. You won't be sorry.

The food was pretty good too, although we just had snacks. Pickled eggs on rye toast ($6.50) were a great accompaniment to the creamy pumpkin, kale and ham soup ($7.50). I would personally have preferred a little less oiliness on the toast itself, but the eggs were nonetheless delicious. Didn't try any of the entrees, but the rabbit looked awesome.
author: Monica C.

description: Really enjoy the feeling of this place. Will be back soon.
author: Parichehr M.

description:
I heard about Comstock Saloon from the Sunday Chronicle at the beginning of August. The review describing the restaurant/bar's dark and rich atmosphere completely drew me in. Went about a month ago to check it out. 

The atmosphere was perfect! Cozy, intimate, with wooden decor. Felt as if you had stepped into a secret haunt during the prohibition period. Their pocket book menu is quite antique as well. Booths are roomy (4-5 ppl comfortably).

Drinks were excellent! Full bodied and rich with flavor. I had the Manhattan (they really know how to use their Bourbon here!) My friend had the John Collins, also a smashing hit! Small bites are what I am drawn to. They have unique names such as Alligator Pear Toast ("Avocado" is your alligator). Their mushroom soup of the day was tasty and the Maple Bourbon Pudding... HEAVENLY (if you go you MUST get this). 

Loved this place and will definitely be coming back soon.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
A lotta lunch for $20 in the FiDi. As Mimi said, great food with sizable portions. I ate both my and her bourbon puddings back at my store, and they were great. 

Can't wait to return for a 3 martini lunch. Or just maybe happy hour.
author: Priya S.

description:
Definitely one of my goto bars when I'm in the area, and for the following reasons:

- Even though the bartenders can be a little on the slower side, it's b/c they're taking their time to make your drink, and for the most part, the drinks are fantastic
- The crowd is usually filled with upper 20's young professionals that know how to behave themselves. In other words, no obnoxious types here
- The atmosphere and decor offer a warm feel that blends nicely with your drinks

Enjoy!
author: Alfonzo J.

description: Please don't come here if you are expecting a Budweiser or margarita.  You would just be getting in the way of others ordering a real drink.  The bartenders know their craft and make a Sazerac and Old Fashioned the right way, gawddammit.  We didn't try any food, but the drinks are well worth the visit.
author: Tim L.

description: My buddies and I came here on a friday night. This bar is freakin awesome! a little small, not much sitting room, but the ambiance makes up for it. The drinks are really exotic and one of a kind. The place is attached to a restaurant, but i didn't wander into that part. There was a live band that played some cool folk music on the level above. Prices for drinks were probably typical of most expensive bars in San Fran. Getting in wasn't too bad, but if you don't have a reservation then good luck with getting a spot at the bar, you're probably be doing a lot of standing.
author: Carlos M.

description: Great bar with a very old school feel to it. Think of Cole's in DTLA or 7 Grand without the hollywood hipsters. Here's what I feel like drinking when I sit at the bar: an ole' fashioned, martinez, gin and lemonade, jack and coke, absinthe. The bartender is attentive and quick. The food I haven't tried but it looks very meaty. Great ambiance and well-prepared drinks.
author: Judy T.

description:
This place kicks ass.  Unfortunately the drinks were so strong they totally kicked Poppy's ass and she had to sit there for nearly two hours eating her way through the menu because she wasn't sure she could stand up and walk.  

Poppy had every dessert on the menu that day in addition to a few cocktails.  Highly recommend cobbler of the day (with chartreuse whipped cream) as well as the pudding.
author: Poppy C.

description:
WOW! What an incredible surprise. This capped a wonderful day and a disappointing meal in north beach (what we could expect from wandering to the touristy part of town) - then...we found this! 

The atmosphere is stellar, vintage 1900s - '20s, the prices are excellent 
(for the quality) and the service is second to none - our waiter was as good as they get, funny, charming and high class without seeming too posh. And the music - wow, great old school jazz in a great speakeasy type feel - this has, tonight become one of my favourite bars in San Francisco. 

Thanks for saving our night!
author: Ben B.

description: Cozy spot for a late night bite and drinks. We shared some Corn Fritters & Pigs in a Biscuit, all great to share and delicious.  The Chicken Pot Pie & Shrimp Po'boy all excellent. Great late night spot or after a show.
author: Sean W.

description: Great service with perfectly crafted drinks. Came here on a Friday night, and it was pretty packed. Though we were lucky enough to snatch a place to sit, tucked away in the corner. Waiters were attentive and loved how there was a live band! The interior is also nicely designed; very different from other bars in the city! Would definitely recommend this place.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Decent cocktails and ok service, but no vegetarian entrees at all. 

My boyfriend's parents were coming to town and I made a reservation based on the menu on Comstock's website and the reviews on yelp. Despite those two sources, there was nothing vegetarian other than the soup, so my boyfriend's step mom couldn't eat. I asked if it was possible to get a veg entree(since there are lots of veg sides that come with other dishes), but our waiter said that the chef refused. We had to down our cocktails and items off the snack menu and find somewhere else on Saturday at 8pm. It was pretty embarrassing. 

The snack menu was pretty good though. The big artisinal cheez-its and soft pretzel were tasty, and I would have liked to try something else.
author: V K.

description: What a treat! We stumbled across this place last weekend. A super cool  friend of mine had heard of it. We had just walked by and discussed the coolness of the Bay Bridge only to stumble into and then upon a 75th celebration/ birthday party for the Bay Bride hosted by the Clankers inside. I had a Sazerac and was very impressed with the authenticity of the servers, saloon music and even the tile hole running the length of the bar, previously used for relief purposes while drinking. I am not sure about the food, I know they have Father Junnipero's heart in a jar. Overall SUPER COOL PLACE.
author: Theresa G.

description: The staff is fun and energetic. Drinks are amazing! tourist spot! beware!
author: Michael T.

description:
lovelovelovelovelove.

The first time I came here, I loved the fact that it wasn't packed on a Friday night. You feel like you've escaped from the city into an old time saloon with super friendly bartenders. The cocktail list is a little overwhelming (not to mention potent), but everything I've sampled has been really good. I really enjoy the Blood & Sand (scotch, sweet vermouth, orange, cherry liqueur), but it's way too sweet to have more than one. 

We saw a bunch of people getting food at the bar and I was drooling. Definitely want to sample the food next time around.
author: Karena Q.

description: Came in for drinks was told a great place. Only to be put in the back of the restaurant were it took 10 minutes for our extremely unfriendly waitress to greet us. When asked what cocktails were popular it almost seemed as if we were bothering her. As a visitor to San Fran don't waste your time.
author: Nicole V.

description: Perfectly dim and great atmosphere. I loved the fans above the bar. Steampunkish and makes you wish everyone inside were wearing top hats. Cute newspaper articles for decoration and the waiters are friendly. We had some awesome ice cream sandwich thing and plenty of liquor before stumbling towards North Beach. Good classy place to start off your night.
author: Kevin L.

description: Great service staff, friendly and helpful. Was looking for a late night drink and some food, arrived at 11:45 not expecting much. They not only seated us but served a full appetizer menu. Ordered 3 items, all of them excellent.
author: Toren A.

description: Fantastic food, drinks and service!!! The ambiance is superb!
author: Katy H.

description:
This is the bar Jonny & Jeff were meant to open.  It's gorgeous -- all steampunk (the pulley-driven fan on the ceiling), all period (the etched glassware), all original details (the spittoon trough beneath the bar).  And of course their cocktails are what god intended.  It's a living artifact -- one at which I intend to spend every evening when I can bestir my ass as far as North Beach.

Congrats, boys.  It's beautiful.
author: Nori H.

description:
Came in here for dinner last night after we couldn't get into Cotogna.  Sat down quickly, good helpful service, and three cherries in my manhattan (bonus!).  We ate the fried mashed potatoes, which came with a terrific dipping sauce studded with a bunch of fresh herbs.  Shared the duck pot pie after that - which was totally old school and was very good (it reminded me of the old marie calendars one in the best possible comfort food way).  

Had thought of this place as mostly for drinks, but happy with the food, too.
author: May A.

description:
The drinks were quite well made and the food menu, though I did not get a chance to try any of it, looked really interesting.

Our waiter looked like he was directly out of the victorian era. One of our friends asked him for a food recommendation and he just sort of read off the menu. He was very quick with our orders and very helpful in general. 

The beer options were super limited but keep in mind, this is a cocktail place.

I wil be back to try the food.
author: Eric G.

description: I came here with a group of guys and their wives, after work.  We hadn't all hung out too often so it was the perfect place to be casual, get to know one another a little better, and have decent drinks and food.  That said, don't come here hungry...they mean it when they say "small plates."  The drinks, however, are really good and unique.  The owner was our server and he was super cool.  It is a little noisy and a little overpriced, but...i'd go back for a drink if i was in he neighborhood.
author: Min M.

description: Great Bartender! Fabulous drinks. We were in SF over Valentine's weekend and dropped in at the Comstock on a whim. The bartender could not have been nicer. Very informative and engaging. On a crowded evening, well-crafted cocktails were sent out rapidly. The atmosphere was warm and inviting. We ended up spending the evening at The Comstock Saloon and can't wait to go back.
author: Elle M.

description: When you order the barkeep's whimsy at Comstock, you are in excellent hands. My friends an I all did, and we were very happy with the outcome. I ended up with a variation of a "Shotgun Wedding", which that had bourbon, lemon and maraschino garnished with fresh mint. All I can say is yum, yum, yum! I was less impressed with our dessert, which was a chocolate pecan tart. I'm picky with sweets, because I bake myself. In this case, my tart crust is better. I love it when I go to a restaurant and can't say that. I did like the fact that it was served warm and had a lovely bourbon cream on the side. The live jazz was a nice touch and the old-time decor is both elegant and fun.
author: Nicole M.

description: Always in search of a great Whiskey Sour and this place does not dissapoint.  They make em  traditional; with egg whites, fresh lemon juice, and a sugar of course. Also, they were one of the few bars that carries extra Oban Scotch...that ish is like buried treasure!
author: Pedro R.

description: This place is hipster paradise, but that's not a bad thing. The drinks are awesome, and the staff is friendly and armed with cute bow ties. The place has a really cool vibe to it and you instantly feel like you are in a different era once you enter the place. From time to time they have a band perform, which livens the place up even more. This is a fun place to go with a group of friends.
author: Abena O.

description:
The atmosphere & decor of the place was great - easy-going, old time-y/saloon-like decor with these awesome old metal fans. 

The cocktail menu looked enticing & interesting but I stuck with a basic vodka soda. 

The maitre'd was sooo nice & helpful. The wait staff was also very nice, friendly w/ a personality. The actual service & timeliness of getting the drinks was a little slower than I liked. We were sitting outside so it was hard to tell if they forgot us or if that's how it is in general.
author: Kristie M.

description: Nice atmosphere, but the friendly service was pretty slow, as was the mediocre food. Split the chicken and ribs, not a meal either of us will remember a week from now. Everything was just kind'v... muted. Bland. Underwhelming. Ah well.
author: Leah S.

description: This is a beautiful Pub!  Super busy - so plan ahead.
author: Jenn B.

description: Simply one of the best drink spots in S.F.   Stopped by with my lady on a trip thru the city and had the best time... If u know what u like .. let the bar keep make u what they want... Im a country/midwest boy now living on the left coast but still enjoy a whiskey cocktail.. after one round of off the menu ordering i let the keep rip and had some of the best drinks in many many attempts... Stop by. Give them a nod to do what they do best and call it a Good Day.
author: Nick S.

description:
Stopped into the Comstock Saloon for a quick drink and a bite on my way home, being as I happened to be in the neighborhood and I'd just seen a glowing review in the SF Weekly.

The statue of Norton I (Emperor of the United States and Protector of Mexico) over the bar would earn this place five stars from me on its own.  Add to that a menu featuring dishes and cocktails that I'm told are representative of what was being served in San Francisco 100 years ago.  And cool bartenders who will make up a drink for you on the spot.  And curly mustaches.  I had a Pisco Punch (a very tart old-timey cocktail) and a plate of alligator pear toast (buttered toast topped with slices of avocado and grapefruit).  Both excellent.

Sad though I was to see the SF Brewing Company go, the Comstock seems like a worthy inheritor of its awesome pulley-driven fans.  Looking forward to returning for a full meal so I can sample more of the menu.
author: Sam S.

description:
A coworker and I went down here for lunch one day.  I know most reviews will be about the drinks, but we just had lunch. It's only a block from my office, so I've been excited about this place before it even opened.  Fun lunch spots are rare in the touristy NB hood.

If I were more adventurous, I would have loved everything on this menu, but for lunch I usually want something simple.  We ordered the Brisket.  It was awesome.  It came with a bunch of random stuff like mini toast and pickles, can't go wrong with pickles.  The food definitely fits the brand.  The decor is old west themed, so is the food.  I will definitely go back to try out more, maybe I'll even ride my horse.
author: jessica b.

description: Great experience overall!  Fun and engaging waiter, window seat to watch the Chinese New Years parade and FANTASTIC FOOD.
author: Brooke E.

description: I heard all about Comstock Saloon and I would have loved to give it 4 stars, but unfortunately, the waitress made me have to downgrade to a 3. Drinks were great, the pork sliders were awesome but the snobby attitude of the waitress I could have done without.
author: LuLu M.

description:
Awesome atmosphere... great place for cocktails with a big group or just on a date. 

we came in a group of 10 just in time to get the little nook in the corner with 10 chairs... cozy and warm with the little furnace in our corner too! 

The decor is lovely, and old school but in an awesome way. :) 

Tried the PISCO PUNCH - super strong but good tasting at the same time, not sweet. 

As for other drinks... you can tell the barkeep or your server what your poison is, and what you like "fruity or gingery" and whatnot... and they'll create something for you. :) how creative is that? 

I'll be back. definitely a great place for visitors, and for locals alike.
author: Judy N.

description:
Super bangin' bar. If you've drank at Elixir, you prolly recognize Alicia pouring tasty bevies. Damn fine ol' fashioned. 

Damn good food too. The cheddar crackers with pepper jelly and cheese was awesome. The mushroom special was forgettable, but the Picnic plate stole the ephin' show. I'd eat that til it hurt. Po' boy and pot pie, both top notch.

Liked the interior too. Classy in that 20's way, nah mean?

I plan on making more appearances here.
author: Nate R.

description: Great spot for some earlier weekend drinks (I can imagine it gets totally packed during prime time).  While the drink list is pretty standard, the bartenders know what they are doing and can make a fine cocktail.  The saloon vibe is always cool, and I bet it gets even better when they have a band playing in the background.  I would like to go back sometime when they are serving their full menu since I am a big fan of Absinthe, one of their other restaurants.
author: Julie M.

description:
Comstock glorifies a past that never was with kitchy decor and surprisingly good food and service.  On entry I was seated in the back just near a small fireplace.  Wonderful on a chilly night.  My server took some time to get around to me as he was stretched to the limit by a good sized crowd.  But he made it all good by simply apologizing, offering good advice on the menu, and getting my order to me in good order.  Simple hospitality.

Chicken soup told the tale of the restaurant.  A good, tasty chicken stock that contained abundant and fresh vegetables that retained real taste.  And there was chicken in the broth as well.  Very nice.

Crab salad was a tulip shaped glass that contained a nice helping of fresh and tasty crab over cocktail sauce.  Very nice again.

Finally, the beef and bone marrow pot pie.  The flakey crust was buttery beyond belief and somewhat overpowered the beef and marrow.  But when sampled on their own the beef and marrow obviously had been freshly prepared and were of good taste.  

This place is a really nice alternative to all of the faux Italian in North Beach.  And it is obviously run by professionals who had the remarkable good sense to get a good chef.
author: David D.

description:
Had dinner here last night for a friends birthday. 

Kevin and I shared 3 dishes: chicken-fried rabbit w/rabbit toast, marrow pot pie, and pork in a biscuit: enjoyed them all!

I started with a manhattan: yum!.. and kevin had an equally delicious drink. 

Love that you can have a great drink and good food. 

The five of us sat in a booth, which was great as it blocked half of the insane amount of noise. I was sitting in the middle of everything, so I was able to hear the entire conversation. 

One of the dishes was tragic: the (steak) salad was just terrible. But 6 other dishes more than made up for that one dish. 

One down side: menu is a bit hard to follow and understand. Is this a main or an appetizer? How large is this portion? Would this go well with this?

Our waitress did a very good job, but she could have done a great job by helping us decipher what we should order or how we should order. 

Other down side: I specially ordered an app, well two (between Kev and I) and a main to share. They all came at the same time. Kind of a bummer as I didn't want anything to get cold. 

Would definitely come back and sit at the bar and have a cocktail and order some good food at the bar.
author: Art A.

description: Nice enough place if you appreciate old-timey music and beards.  Two beers on tap or you're navigating the cocktail menu.  Cool space.
author: Jeff P.

description: I came back for dinner and though the menu it is limited, everything is good. I had the rabbit done  three ways and the green salad with buttermilk dressing and both were delicious and my friend had the chicken pot pie, which was also great. It was my birthday dinner so I got a bottle of Spanish red wine for $37 and it was excellent..oh, and the olives, oh God, the olives. They keep the olives warm, generally the olives are in a container sitting in hot or warm water but when they come to your table, they are still mighty warm and just so tender...love the olives and at $5 you can't go wrong. The music playing was sort of early rock from the 50s and it went well with the place and boy, on a weekend night, the bar area gets packed! If you are on vacation, try and come on a Sunday through Wednesday if you are...ahem....somewhat older like myself or shall we say, definitely into the aged part of middle age.  Jeff, the main barkeep, was not there on Friday but he was earlier in the week and he is the master of the cocktail preparation, worth seeing him in action.:-)
author: George L.

description: Good drinks, good music. Host was really nice to us. Bartenders were a bit snooty.  A tad pricey for the neighborhood but over-all I dig it.
author: Krista I.

description: We had an absolutely charming and extended after dinner drink round here one evening in San Francisco.  After hearing about this place elsewhere we were brought here by my boyfriend's cousin and seated in a lovely and intimate booth area.  Above us in a small alcove an incredible band serenaded us at just the perfect volume to both chat and and enjoy their wonderful music.  We loved the decor and the whole story of the Barbary Coast and its tall tales of adventure. The staff here were so incredibly nice, helpful, and friendly helping us choose the perfect hand crafted cocktail and choosing a dessert.  We chose the carrot cake. It did not dissappoint.  In fact it may be one of the best I've ever tasted.  This place has an amazing vibe and ambeiance for dinner & drinks, or after dinner drinks that it makes it a must do for our next visit to San Fran.  Thanks for the amazing drinks and music and keep it up.
author: Moe M.

description:
Went there for dinner last night with my boyfriend.

FOOD: Just 'ok'.  The menu sounded creative & interesting but the pickled egg was hardly pickled and the beef short rib & bone marrow pot pie was dry (it had a great, flaky pie crust but the filling was rather plain -- not indulgent -- as one would think bone marrow would be). My boyfriend thinks the Chicken Fried Rabbit with rabbit toast appetizer was excellent -- rabbit was tender & moist, yet crispy on the outside. The chile vinegar was a perfect compliment, he thought. I thought the rabbit was great for what it was but realized rabbit just isn't my favorite thing.

DECOR/ATMOSPHERE: Great that they had a live band playing -- good rag time music -- but it was a bummer that the main seating was in another, side room. The dining room was cold and the wait staff apparently had to go in and out to bring in deliveries or something, which caused an intermittent draft.  We both loved the old west saloon style -- lots of wood, great wallpaper, nice lighting. Re loudness, something about the acoustics, made it an overly noisy place, esp. near the bar area. While it was much quieter in the side dining room -- and that's where we ate -- it was disappointing not to be able to hear one another and thus spend more time post-dinner at the bar. 

STAFF: Seemed like an overall friendly place.

COCKTAILS: We tried both the Saint's Buck (Brandy, elderflower, lemon, Angostura, ginger beer) and the South Side Cocktail (Gin, lemon, sugar, mint, seltzer). Our fave was the South Side -- crisp and refreshing. Nice balance of acidity. Saint's Buck was good too. Ginger gives it a nice kick.

IN SUM: Would I go again? It was a decent enough place that if my friends wanted to meet there for dinner or Happy Hour, I'd go again, but, particularly given the prices here, I'd never pick it as my first  choice. 

(Note that if this place had lower prices, I'd likely give it a four. But, for the prices, I was really hoping for something a little more ..exceptional.)
author: Nhien V.

description: This place on was on "andrew bourdain's- layover." ironically ended up here after an Occupy protest to have happy hour with a buddy and his banker friends. Mixology is nice. they didn't have regular juice just fresh squeezed orange and grapefruit juice. the cute bartender was very cute and witty!
author: Chris M.

description: Comstock mixes stiff drinks in a somewhat upscale setting, which doesn't necessarily stop it from getting rowdy.  They sometimes have live music in the balcony above the bar.
author: Dan W.

description:
Went here for a pre-dinner cocktail, I had heard they make mean ones; not surprising considering that Absinthe tenders are in the mix. Rumors are true and the place awesome. Here's the run down so far:

Ambiance: AWESOME! feels like you're walking into the set of Deadwood; a lot nicer though.

Service: Great, very attentive and polite.

Menus: Old-timey for sure, both food and drink, with a some new-age flare.

Drinks: Ordered the "Barkeep's Whimsy"-got a Frisco Sour or something like that. It was as mean as it gets, great buzz after a single cocktail.

Food: Going back for the food and if the beef shank and bone marrow pie is as good as it smelled, this place will be getting an additional star.


...update soon to come.
author: SF C.

description: A lovely place.  We really enjoyed the cocktails - cherry bounce and America's cup - and the free lunch - housemade gyros with housemade tziki sauce.  Scrumptious!  And the service was outstanding.  I recommend it!
author: Betty F.

description:
I like the ambience a lot and the drinks were pretty good, but this place gets Packed and mgmt is not very organized when it comes to seating people at the booth. Our group of 6 was forced to huddle around a stool at the bar for 2 hours while the booths were taken up by groups of 2-3 people. When the booths opened up, they proceeded to seat MORE groups of 2-3 people (apparently they had a "waiting list" which we were NOT privy to) while our group grew to 8 people. When we were finally seated after 2.5 hours of being there, we were VERY hungry, not thrilled with the odd food selection and decided to go to R&G Lounge. We literally sat there for 20 mins and left.

We would have drank a LOT more if we were seated at the booth a lot longer before instead of being shoved and pushed standing in the way by the bar. We may even have eaten there. 

Not smart
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
I agree with many of the reviews.  This is the place to be on Friday nights.  Live music and great locale for people watching.  A diverse crowd.

The atmosphere captures the essence of a saloon without trying too hard.  i.e. Bourbon and Branch makes you feel like you have to be in full character upon entry, and Rickhouse is just too Coyote Ugly.

Drinks are served well, but they could pay more attention to when drinks needs a replenish and how long you have to wait for your drink order.  i.e. if you have to ask 3 times for the status of your order... something is wrong.

I'd recommend Comstock... check it out!
author: Brian V.

description:
Believe the hype.

The interior is gorgeous.

The drinks are refreshing and creative.

The food is DELICIOUS. The bar snacks are unlike any other bar food you will have in your life, and the full dinner entrees are to die for.  Bonus: The menu is full of delightful vegetarian options.

Can't wait to go back again. And again. And again. And again.
author: Thuy L.

description: Awesome bar atmosphere and great drinks!. I would not plan on having dinner here though. The food is mediocre at best.
author: Mary Q.

description: Sitting at the bar is AWESOME. Barkeep's whimsey is killer and my boyfriend and I love going to this place. We have also tried the marinated olives and BBQ chips with ranch dressing. They make the chips in house and also the ranch. Can accomodate gluten-free. I love this place. It has an old school, hipster feel and is just awesome. Service can be a little slow, but its worth it for a couple awesome drinks.
author: Rachel W.

description:
Good drinks, lovely food and nice atmosphere on a Tuesday night.  The brisket dish beats out the trout, as well as the beef and bone marrow pie.  Get "snacks" for apps, as they're small an fab and affordable.

Cool mustache on the maître d'.
author: Em P.

description:
At 10:30 pm, this is one of the few places serving food on the block.
Come here for the fantastic cocktails and an interesting menu. (Actually, "weird" was the word used by my adult companions to describe the tasty saloon food)

alligator pear toast-  avocado and grapefruit together, who would of thunk it would taste so good?
cheddar crackers and pepper jelly with a creamy cheese- tasty jelly
beef shank and bone marrow pot pie with arugula salad- it was a little dry for a pot pie
funnel cake- not like at the fairgrounds, it was burnt :(

blood and sand scotch cocktail- smokey and delicious
author: jane d.

description: I have no complaints except for maybe needing a little better beer selection, though it is a cocktail type of place.  The food isn't cheap, but the ambiance is great, the service is good, and the food is great.  We entertained friends (all local), and there was nothing but satisfaction.  Excellent location off Columbus near the action of North Beach.
author: Mark Q.

description:
Come for the cocktails; stay for the food!

Based on reports from friends, I was expecting the cocktails to be fantastic (which they were).  The list is short, but everything we had was fantastic!  Plus, there's always the option of The Bartender's Whimsy, where you put yourself at the tasty tasty mercy of the house mixologist (with maybe a suggestion or two).  We ordered both a bourbon whimsy & mezcal whimsy, and neither disappointed.

But I hadn't realized the food would be so amazing!  We started with the chicken fried rabbit and celery salad.  The rabbit meat was tender & succulent, and battered in a light, fluffy, perfectly seasoned flour.  The toast was buttery and delicious and topped with decadent rabbit confit.  The celery salad (sliced celery in a tasty dressing) went very nicely with it.

Beef shank & bone marrow pie was HEAVENLY.  Stupid rich, and definitely in the heart-attack-on-a-plate category, but tender, creamy, perfectly cooked, and served in a flaky pastry pie.  (Served with nicely dressed greens.)  Griddled trout with alligator pear relish & smoky corn was slightly healthier, but just as delicious - flaky and tender, & perfectly complimented by the sweet, savory, & smoky relish.

For dessert, we had the maple bourbon pudding with shortbread.  This was definitely tasty and maple/bourbon flavored, but it was a little too sweet & ordinary for my taste (I prefer slightly more adventurous dessert with more variety to them).  Still, some people with LOVE it.

In addition to tasty noms & elixirs, the place has a neat steampunk kind of atmosphere (aspects of it remind me of Alembic, like the paddle fan).  The servers were dressed appropriately (not to mention being extraordinarily attentive), and there's even a pianist playing all kinds of music on an old upright in a nook above the dining area, which adds an old-timey vibe.

We were surprised at how un-crowded the place was; although we'd gotten reports that it was usually horribly busy, we were seated right away (though it did fill up later).

Will definitely be back!
author: Angela B.

description: I liked almost everything about this place!  Tasty food and good artisan cocktails.  My only gripe is that the flavor profile of the cocktails lacked depth.  I would only go there if I was in the mood for a certain type of drink.
author: Kim W.

description: The ambience in this pub is great. Good location and easy to get to by walking. That is the only reason it even gets one star, the service was horrible! It was happy hour and it was beginning to get busy.  We sat at a table in the bar area because bar stools were all taken, some with people in them other stools with people's coats, messenger bags etc. :( it took the waitress 20 minutes to even come and take our order. My husband ordered a scotch and I ordered a Moscow mule.  I asked if they made the cocktail with ginger beer not ginger ale, because it makes a big difference in taste, the waitress said oh yes of course!  Well, another 20 minutes and still no drinks and nobody even checks on us we have to stop someone as they wisk past our table.  When we finally got someone to stop by our table the waitress said yeah, I know we're busy.  Then she asked what we ordered and I told her she had the audacity to say, that the Moscow mule took special crushed ice and that is why it as taking so long. REALLY??????!  When the drink came it was awful and not made with ginger beer. This place has a lot of potential, we just had a terrible experience. We will not go back or recommend it to friends.
author: Janis S.

description: Great vibe, great neighborhood they know their booze and how to mix it and last but not least they introduced me to my favorite ginger beer in the world Fever Tree. The stuff is crack in a bottle. Oddly my first visit I was on a break from booze " insane yes, I know especially in SF" which is how I came to knowing the magical elixir. I hear the food is pretty good as well.
author: Martin S.

description: This is our go to place when friends visit from out of town or when we need to suggest a place to meet up with friends.  As close to perfect a place as I've found anywhere. Awesome live jazz, the best drinks in the city, (perhaps with the exception of bourbon and branch) and awesome staff. I don't have enough nice things to say about this place. The vibe is excellent and it's cool with out being pretentious.
author: Kim K.

description:
Order a Dutch Headbutt.
Bols jenever and a short pils beer.  
You don't really need to chase the jenever, it's tasty stuff, but having the beer too is refreshing.
Super interesting and creative food and drink choices.   
Try the drink called 'blood and sand'.  It contains neither and will leave you smiling.
Fried rabbit anyone?  Yes.  Seriously.  Yes.  It's pretty amazing.
author: Kev M.

description:
loved everything!!! tried the Whisky soaked gravlax, Dungeness crab cocktail, and Brisket and marrow pot pie! OMG!!  

Love the decor and it was a great experience.
author: Hilary L.

description: Amazing staff, totally warm and welcoming. It had the atmosphere of a slightly shi-shi NYC West Village and almost elite NYC Uppereast... minus the potential douchiness. Amazing Gin Mojito and unique drinks.
author: Christine L.

description:
Surely, there are few places that serve a finer cocktail than the Comstock. 

I have to admit, I was bummed at first when the SF Brew Co. shuttered its doors for good. But when Comstock moved into this location, I instantly forgot my woes. 

If this place weren't so devoted to creating expert drinks and crafting a complete experience from them, then its Old West, late 19th century saloon motif would seem comically ironic. But when I went here, I realized that irony was in no way the aim -- the folks at Comstock really are just dedicated to the business and culture of cocktails, and their aim is to please. 

So yes, there are bartenders in vests and tiny ties, and yes you'll feel like you stepped back in time a bit when you walk through the doors. But that's only to enhance your experience there. 

What to drink? I am a huge fan of the Saint's Buck (brandy, elderflower, lemon, sugar, bitters, seltzer) because I love drinks with a slightly herbal, earthy taste. I also recommend choosing the Barkeep's Whimsy, where you tell them what kind of liquor you enjoy and they'll surprise you by whipping up something custom. Has never failed me so far. 

My friend also tried the food here -- the beef shank and bone marrow pot pie, which he applauded.
author: Andrew K.

description: Saw this on the Travel Channel's "The Layover" and wanted to check it out. It looked like fun on TV but once there, we felt ignored.  I loved the decor which was restored from the 20's/30's.  Would be willing to give it another when I'm in SF again.
author: Wendy J.

description:
Fantastic. They really got the concept down. The service was some of the best I've experienced in a long time. They were professional yet humorous and very helpful/attentive/positive the whole time.  My only knock would be that the pork and beans with biscuits could use some work. The pork is sometimes in HUGE chunks that need to be broken down to smaller bits to be comfortably eaten. It makes for awkward in-bowl cutting. The biscuits were great but there weren't enough of them in proportion to the pork and beans, and finally the pork and beans was only marginally better from what any average person could make at home. I was expecting maybe a little sweetness or spiciness but it just was what it was. Pork. Beans.

Drinks were solid, and the picnic sampler app was enjoyable - any way you could get us those cherries without pits? I tried to gently chew them to get the pit out, but for one of them I completely bit the seed and it shattered in my mouth...my fault I know but I wish it could've just been some sort of cherry compote/jam/spread/pieces instead to avoid all the effort.

This also marks the first time I've ever raved about olives as a side dish. The olives are influenced by the orange zest they sit with. They are exemplary. Best olives I've ever had.

On the food alone I'd give them 4 stars, but the service easily bumps it up to 5. I have a feeling over time the food will refine, rework, and improve, so I'm not too worried about it and will definitely be back!
author: Eric R.

description: Can you say Manhattan's with a smile?  Brandied cherries so divine, mixed w/ Four Roses Bourbon ~ Good Lord delicious! Two is my max, but I could keep drinking these all day!  Definitely sit at the bar or booths or parlor, it will take you back in time, The feel is cozy and relaxed each time, Specially if the entertainment above is scaling the old piano. Now food is consistently good also. Salmon crostini, pigs in a blanket, pot pies, and warm olives all good. I can comfortably say this is my favorite bar in the City!
author: Tarabud J.

description:
this place rocks.  end of story.

love the old timey feel of the the place inside.  the servers are enthusiastic and knowledgeable.  

every time i have been here, the cocktails have been excellent.  Really well balanced and not over wrought.

i was really impressed by the food!  we were there on a cold, chilly day and the food was all so comforting and flavorful.  my friend had the chili which was really good.  better than my grandma's and that is saying a lot!  my other friend had the beef and marrow pot pie....the insides were warm and flavorful, and the crust was buttery and flakey.  i, myself, had the fried chicken, and it was probably the best fried chicken i have ever had!  it has SO much flavor and was so succulent and juicy.  it was served with charred broccoli and german potato salad.  never had charred broccoli before, and i certainly hope this isnt the last time i have it.  i am NOT a fan of potato salad in the slightest, and german potato salad is something that i have always simply found more palatable than the typical potato salad, but this was bursting with flavor.  i dont know what they did to it, but i was delish!

i can't wait to come back.
author: Christian C.

description: I loved this place. So far some of the best cocktails I've had in SF. The bartenders were skilled at getting just the right balance of flavors in the drinks, not overdoing it on bitters like so many fancy-pants mixologists do. The bartenders and manager fussed over us and I felt taken care of all evening. The live jazz was also a plus in creating a relaxed, unpretentious environment. I wish I could go back every night!
author: Emmy S.

description: Cool bar cool atmosphere. I have to say any place where the bartenders make a good sazerac is ranked highly in my book.
author: Roger P.

description:
This review is for the bar only.
A colleague had organized a happy hour here for our small company get together after work. Since it was her last happy hour with us before leaving for grad school, I ordered a dozen cupcakes for the festivity for everyone to share. I called to confirm our reservation of the back booth area with the antique seating and fireplace (great ambiance) mentioned to the hostess I would be bringing a box of cupcakes and she said that would be fine.
Come to find out when we get there and racked up a hefty bill in celebration, there was a $36 fee for the cupcakes!!! WTH?! When I asked our waitress about this charge she said there was a cake fee of $3... ok... a cupcake is about an 1/16 of a cake, shouldn't you have just charged us the $3 for the 1 box of them instead of $3 PER CUPCAKE?! Really?! Or how about letting me know of said "Cake Fee" when I call to confirm and mention to you that I'm bringing a box of 12 cupcakes! What a scam!
Never. Ever. Bringing my business here again. If you are an EA like myself, do not plan a happy hour event here for your coworkers.
author: Tashina G.

description:
I've been here on two occasions now.  The first time was during a Tuesday night and it was packed.  We walked in an were greeted by several people with smiles are on their faces.  There was no room at the bar so we nabbed a small table for some snacks and cocktails.  We had some bar snacks, mixed nuts, the pulled pork sliders are phenomenal and my favorite were the pickled eggs.  Cocktails were nothing less than stellar!  We all tried something different; Saint's Buck, Hoptoad Cocktail, Blood and Sand and the Martinez.  I gotta say, I really do need to come back and have a full meal sometime.

The second time I came here it was on a quiet Monday.  I was lucky enough to have a seat at the bar and the piano was playing some mighty fine tunes.  I brought a friend in to show him what I was talking about and I think he's a lifer now as well.  Thanks to Kenny for the fantastic service and delicious cocktails at the bar.  I will be back!
author: Brian M.

description:
Comstock reminds me of a saloon that you would see in old movies, complete with interesting characters and old world charm. 

Their drink menu will wow you with old fashioned concoctions. If you feel like rolling the dice, order the "bartender's whimsy" and they'll create an impressive blend that might include anything from frothy egg whites to Maraschino liqueur. 

It's really the finishing touches that make Comstock complete- from their antique inspired glassware to their rugged leather bound menus, Comstock has created an atmosphere that takes you back in time.
author: Lauren T.

description:
snazzy cocktails that make gin sing.  snazzy vibe and live music on saturday night.  snazzy suspenders on the bartenders and stylish wait staff.  snazzy place for a second date.  

a new favorite for a cocktail crafted with care.
author: Bria L.

description:
Odd spot.  

Highlights: decent, if pricey, drinks, neat decor and reasonably friendly staff.  

Lowlights: the johns need to be cleaned more regularly, and when I order a drink, and the manager (?) comes by to confirm my order 10 minutes later, it seems odd that waitstaff would need to be reminded of it again.  In the end, it took about 30-35 minutes to get a pretty simple drink.  Yes, it was busy in there that night, but it wasn't that busy.
author: Yo U.

description:
Rudest bartender (Karrie C) I've ever encountered. If you want to be publicly berated after spending nearly $70 on scotch for grabbing an extra ice cube from a glass of ice that accompanied your order then this place is for you. 

Management needs to check their staff (Karrie C) or your going to start loosing some business. Huge disappointment.
author: Emily C.

description: A decent alternative to Bourbon and Branch, but not quite up to par. Cocktail selection is average, but the consistency between the bartenders making them is poor.  Great ambiance and good music.
author: Eric H.

description:
Stopped by for lunch with some friends. Service was good, but not impressed. The pig in a biscuit was okay--but slightly on the greasy side, and what's up with the side of cole slaw serving? Literally one tablespoon! All four of us were disappointed in the serving sizes. And we found it alittle odd that they don't serve decaf? Maybe they only cater to the 18-28 crowd, but some of us still do drink decaf--and like to sleep at night. 

The decor is great, you have to admit. Straight out of the early 20th Century. The bar is impressive, but overall, we felt like we were in a bar--not a restaurant. We'll be back for drinks, but not the bar food. The tab was $60 and only one of us had a drink (straight up coffee). And we were still hungry (and wired).
author: Yvo R.

description:
I went here last night with a girl friend after hearing about the bar on Thrillist a couple of months ago. I was pretty excited to check it out because the atmosphere seemed promising

Upon entering, we were vivaciously greeted by the doorman who was the most amiable doorman I have had the pleasure meeting. He quickly saught to accommodate us since the bar was full, and we were seated by the woodstove at a small table in a lovely nook.

Immediately after being seated, the bus boy stopped by to place water before us and carelessly spilled an entire glass all over my friend, our table, and the sparse amount of floor. While the bus boy frantically looked to clean up the mess he made, he did a poor job of wiping the floor. Thankfully we were in an area that would dry quickly because of the fire and would not be subject to much foot traffic.

Shortly thereafter, the waitress stopped by and took our drink order. It did not take long to receive our drinks, but we did have to wait - what I would consider an exhuberant amount of time - for the waitress to process the payment of our bill. Between not getting a seat at the bar and having water spilled all over us, we were definitely not in the mood for remaining at the establishment very long and would have appreciated a quicker turn around with the bill.

Other than those minor discrepancies, I loved the atmosphere as I thought I would and plan to return to sit at the bar with the expectation that the second time around will be better than the first.
author: Falyn J.

description: Ladies and Gentlemen. Ready to enter a refined turn-of-the-century saloon, where attractive younger after-work locals relax to the entertaining live music that causes scandal, sit on the gilded bar stools in a semi-dark ambiance eating snacks, and served by a bartender that studies your comings and goings, and his stare appears most... sinister? Don't be fooled, he prepares the most tastefully executed cocktails for you in the most impromptu manner. Just make sure not to drink too many Manhattans, Martinez, or Blood & Sands. and Welcome to Comstock, you'll suddenly feel as if you were in the 1900s.
author: Stephanie M.

description: IF i could I would drink a southside cocktail daily for the rest of my life! SO DAMN TASTY!! (if you like gin.) Speakeasy atmosphere with great live music.
author: Chandra W.

description: I went in with high hopes but was actually a little disappointed. My drink was too sweet and not all that strong. The appetizers were also overpriced IMO.  I might go back, but it wouldn't be my first choice.
author: Mark W.

description: This is the spot!!  Great drinks, good service, good music(often times jazz bands playing, always pretty decent).  This is definitely my favorite bar in SF
author: Yan L.

description: Really disappointed.  My friend and I went for an early dinner and drinks.  The waiter was indifferent.  It took 15 minutes to get our drinks when there were MAYBE 10 people in the bar.
