The menu items were really unappetizing.  We ordered the pigs in a biscuit and they were flavorless and super greasy.  My friend then ordered the Shrimp Louis and although I didn't taste, she said she'd said that it tasted like something one would get at Appleby's.  I get that the food is in keeping with the Barbary Coast theme, but it should at least be tasty.  II might go again for a drink, but the food was horrible.  Did I mention the indifferent waiter?  That goes for the hostess as well.
author: a d.

description: We tried the beef shank & bone marrow pot pie and the shrimp louie salad.  While they both tasted good, we were disappointed in the small menu selection and the small portions for what they charge.  The ambiance was cool and the server was friendly and attentive.
author: Julia H.

description: We had only 1 thing - the Derby.  perfectly refreshing drink to finish our big walk on a weekend afternoon.
author: diana t.

description: We had a really good meal and experience here last night. Friendly service, really tasty dishes (fritters, pretzel, green salad with buttermilk dressing, pork sliders, salmon and carrot cake) all really good. Cocktails were really good too, but had to knock off one star as we waited pretty long for our first drinks-the appetizers came out before the drinks. The dining room was nice, quieter than the bar, but had a good vibe. The whole place was decorated well, although my chair with minimal padding  felt like it was an antique. Overall though, very good experience.
author: Holly K.

description: I don't get up to this part of town often, but given the hype around this place and my fondness for their other restaurant, Absinthe, I made the pilgrimage up here one weekend night with my gf and came away pretty impressed.  We were in more of a cocktail mood then a big dinner mood, so we ended up sitting at the bar and getting a few appetizers.  The Cocktails were all superb, and the food was just as good.  A real stand out was the chicken fried rabbit.  The pepper jelly that was served with the cheddar crackers was also great.  I probably won't be a regular here due to the fact that it's a real schlep over here from the Inner Sunset, but it was certainly good enough to recommend to anyone who happens to be in the area.
author: Joshua W.

description: AWESOME. early 20th century (i think) saloon decor with a live band to match (at least on Fridays). on top of that, killer cocktails: Country Life and America's Cup in particular.
author: Sean B.

description: Found this place looking to get some after dinner drinks.  We were able to get seated right away.  Also, the decor was kind of cool.  The wait staff was friendly and efficient.  The drinks were reasonably priced and we had a good time.
author: Joel G.

description: i usually don't drink cocktails (i prefer beer, wine or single malts) but i came here because of my wife.. her martini was but my no means was well balanced or eclectic... my cocktail was poorly made and i couldn't even finish it..
author: Stan L.

description: Went to get drinks here with friends late at night and were treated excellently. A man greeted us and showed us a place to sit, and was really friendly on getting our orders. The drinks took a while to get to our table, but they were good and no complaints from anyone. Never had their food before, but I'm willing to come here again to try out the food and have another amazing cocktail. Also, I love the environment of this bar. It has a vintage/classy vibe that's also low key and casual at the same time, I saw people dressing in basically sweats to have a drink here and they were treated nicely as well.
author: The T.

description: Stopped here to treat myself to some scotch on a cold, grey, melancholy San Francisco afternoon. Don't forget to look up at the fantastic antique ceiling fan.
author: Kat A.

description: Cool looking and inviting space but unfortunately the bartender provided terrible service (unfriendly and rude). If you think it looks like a good place for a beer - think again. They have TWO beers on tap (one of which they were out of) and maybe 10 bottled beer options. If you want a pretentious experience this is the place for you. I hear they have good cocktails but I won't be back to try.
author: Nichole F.

description: Staff is friendly but we weren't feeling the vibe.  We had one drink and moved on.  There's other places to drink in that area.
author: Rich S.

description: Kind of yuck.  Service annoying and detached.  Bar tenders think they are all that
author: Laura M.

description: I've been drinking here since it was SF Brewing Company.  This old spot has been taken to another level by Comstock, though.  I appreciate their throwback saloon atmosphere along with their classic cocktails, as I haven't had a disappointing Old Fashioned or Manhattan yet.  Bonus for the piano-playing singer upstairs too--can't beat the background music.  As much as I love stopping by the saloon for drinks, the limited & pricey food options are a letdown.
author: Manny R.

description:
Great food, surprisingly mediocre cocktails.  I had the barkeep's whimsy.  Maybe that was my mistake; I should have just picked a tried and true item off the menu.  But I was feeling adventurous and figured how could I go wrong?  Well, I did, or rather, the barkeep did.  I was served an extremely sour lemon, apricot liquer update on the lemondrop.  Mind you, I cut my cocktail teeth on lemondrops.  I would have been a little disappointed in the barkeep's creativity had I been served a lemondrop, but I would have enjoyed drinking it.  Instead, the balance on my mystery drink was all off - so tart, my tongue burned slightly for the rest of the evening.  Any apricot flavor was slight and jarring when I could taste it.  Of course I did not send it back b/c that's like admitting defeat, that you're not adventurous enough for barkeep's choice.  But here I am complaining anyway!  Point being, just don't get the surprise drink, and if you do, don't be too shy to send it back.  My boyfriend had two bourbon based drinks.  One was good, but too icy, and I could barely taste the bourbon in the second one - too much ice and seltzer.  All in all, the balance was off on all three drinks.  I'm willing to think it was an aberration, but still will think twice before coming back.

For food, we enjoyed the hangtown toast, shrimp sandwich, and rabbit three ways.  All three dishes were excellent.  The shrimp in the sandwich was super sweet and tender.  Ham accompanies the shrimp, and the pairing is so delicious.  The rabbit three ways came with fried rabbit, rabbit terrine, and some other way that I forget.  The fried rabbit itself was possibly the best fried anything I've ever had.  The meat was steaming and tender beneath a tasty, crispy batter.  We also loved the sliced pickled eggs on the hangtown toast.  Yum!
author: Pearl L.

description: Was excited to go here on Labor Day and arrived with others at 3:45 pm.  We had gotten there a bit early as we were not sure they would be open on Labor Day.  The door was open and the person standing there related they opened at 4:00 pm.  We said fine and waited until 4:10.  When we asked if they were then open the man in the bar yelled to us they would open when they were ready.  We promptly went across the street to the Francis Coppola restaurant and had a great time.  Will never even attempt to try this place again.  Very rude!
author: Betty P.

description: The pigs in a biscuit and poppers were delightful.  Too bad our drinks (which were definitely well crafted) came way after our mini meal was demolished....but our drinks were comped for the wait - so we'll be back.  Great vibe, not too pricey (happy hour menu, at least), and the drinks (when they finally turned up) were with the wait.
author: Heather L.

description: I find this place so much fun, maybe because I am a total history buff and love all things from eras long forgotten.  Comstock is old San Francisco, they have grandma's crystal for their drink service, they brought back turn of the century drinks, they serve these drinks poured over oversized ice cubes.... I could go on!  The bar staff is really great too, they enjoy telling you the history behind the drinks, what was popular then, and its honestly and art watching them do these drinks.  I will definately be back soon.  Oh I almost forgot they had a live band in the balcony the night that I went.... so much fun.
author: Loretta M.

description:
loved it. gorgeous decor, feels like you're in a real old time saloon back in the late 1800s, i mean for real...well, except for the fact that this place is classy. there's no spit on the floor or sour beer smell. you can take a lady here and she will think you're a gentleman. 

i do have to say i'm a sucker for bars that now require their bartenders/servers to dress. our waiter was spic n' span in his starched white shirt, tie, and clean apron. i didn't notice if he had an arm band, but in my embellished fantasy of my evening he did. nothing like getting served a perfect manhattan by a man in an armband. (note to mgmt: if you don't already have armbands, get some.)

i have to say that our server was so polite and so nerdily attentive to us that we ended up really liking him.

it's worth it to eat here. i'm in love with that rabbit dish. little nuggets of fried rabbit and more rabbit on toast served with a crunchy celery salad. sooo good. i also was a big fan of the weekly prixe fixe menu. we especially loved the sunchoke soup and the chicory salad with bacon and poached egg. the steak didn't blow me away, but was still pretty tasty. 

as for the drinks...i tried the bartender's whimsy but he put some absinthe in my drink which always ends up making everything taste like cough syrup to me. just a personal taste thing. but my rye manhattans were money and bonus points for 3 brandied cherries!
author: rachel p.

description: Our new favorite bar when we're in SF.  Well prepared and stiff drinks!  Be sure to check out seating in both parts of the saloon.  We walked in one side and didn't realize until we left that there are two sides that connect at the back.
author: M G.

description: I remember this location being some brewery so when I showed up to meet my friend, I was pretty excited to try this place.  I love the decor - so swanky and old fashioned.  The bartender was great - I let her pick my drink for me and she came back with Cherry something - I don't remember the full name but I will remember how amazing that drink was!!  It was incredibly delicious and refreshing and the drink my friend ordered was strong and good.  We also had the pretzel and the cream cheese with pepper jelly - both were very good.  Unfortunately, we had dinner plans to head out to or else I would have stayed the whole night.  This is a great place for happy hour or casual drinks and I will be back.
author: Arica V.

description: I checked this bar out on one of my first nights in San Francisco because it was on the Food & Wine best bars list.  I'm not sure that I'd rank it in the top 50 bars I've ever been to, but it was fun. The bar is beautiful, with an old-timey vibe--lots of dark wood and a 1930-ish ceiling.  I ordered a champagne-bourbon-cherry cocktail, thinking this will either be the best drink I've ever had, or horrible. Unfortunately, it turned out to be closer to the former.  But my friend's julep-y  drink was so delicious.  AND THEIR HOMEMADE PRETZEL WAS SO YUMMY!!! We came on a Saturday night and got seated pretty quickly. It was quite enough to chat with my friends, and yet so lively that I definitely felt that I was out and about on the town in a really, really cool city.
author: Lynn M.

description:
ok i really want to like this place. i've given it a few tries. 

i love the ambiance, the atmosphere, even the drink menu. 

but there's something that smells horrible there. like a dead rat's flesh is rotting. every time i've entered the saloon, this persistent smell has kept me from enjoying my time there. i've never smelled that odor anywhere else. 

another downside is that when i was hanging out with friends there, the service was touch and go and the drinks were watered down. maybe i'll give it a final shot in the next few months. all the four-five star reviews make me feel like maybe i've gone on the wrong nights or something.
author: Maria A.

description: This place is very quaint and cute and the drinks were really good but the portions for the appetizer were just so small.. We left there still hungry but didn't wanna pay anymore for another appetizer knowing how the portions were. Very tiny place but it's a good place for happy hour drinks
author: Kell S.

description: Perfectly mixed cocktails by skilled mixologists. I'd come here again.
author: Scott M.

description:
called for reservations yesterday... we got there... and the reservations weren't in. got on the list for a table --- 45 minute wait or dinner & they got my ph # to let me know when a table is ready. never got a call back!! waited outside & was given poor service... slammed the drinks menu on the table. not very good hosts. we felt unwelcome!! didnt realize people still discriminate against others... even if it is in san francisco! never coming back & will let all my friends know. pretty sad & disgusting for an establishment to train people like this. 
absolutely unacceptable.
author: Faye N.

description:
i really like this bar/lounge and i definitely want to come back here at try their food!

first of all, they have live jazz band playing upstairs, which i completely didn't notice in the beginning. second, the decor is pretty awesome, set in the 1920s, so it's a bit antique but the lounge feels very classy. 

they have quite a bit of interesting drinks, including specialty antique beers, a good selection of cocktails, and a large selection of other alcohol, like brandy, bourbon, scotch, etc. that you could try. it's a little pricier here but i really like the ambience. it's good for group or a smaller more intimate setting.
author: Joyce B.

description: Always a good time. Excellent drinks, great music, cool atmosphere.
author: Kristen M.

description: Love this place! After leaving another bar that felt it was ok to give me a dirty glass, I ended up here! That bartender knows how to make a Manhattan! There are many places that serve drinks but don't know how to make drinks. No this place. It is awesome on so many levels.
author: Korinne B.

description:
Decor is tastefully old-fashioned. Love it. Feel like I've been time warped. I think this place used to be the SF Brewing Co. They definitely made this place classier...

Review is only for the drinks, will have to go back and try the food sometime though.

Had the Pisco Punch -- enjoy it for the complexity, flavor is unique...

Barkeeps whimsy -- also a good choice. I guess I'm a fan of having the bartender surprise me wherever I go. I can't remember the name of the drink he made, but will update when it hits me.
author: L C.

description: I first came across Comstock Saloon at a company party and oh boy did I fall hard! From the ambiance to the wonderful old fashioned cocktails to the freeking piano this place is like no other! This is a bar that takes you back to prohibition SF and you just have to love it for that, my new office is super close so I'll for sure be a regular fixture!
author: Margot K.

description: Had a few hours to kill before a big dinner late that evening so we decided to stop in and check it out as it has some very favorable Yelp reviews.  The saloon itself is delightful, the bar, with its rich dark ornate wood is one to admire, the décor is old west.  The bar tables are way too small, very difficult to place an appetizer, appetizer plates, silverware and drinks  ... not real comfy.  The drinks and appetizers, while tasty, are a bit overpriced!  The pickled egg was disappointing...to me a pickled egg has to be pickled in beet juice, missed the purple!!  The Rock Cod sliders were so, so and the Lamb meatballs were good, not great for the price. The service wasn't overly friendly, just take our order, no real personality. The best part of the experience besides the décor itself was the BBQ Chips that were on one of the appetizer plates, they were awesome.  Like the rating says...Just OK
author: Patricia G.

description: Good cocktails.  I want to eat the food here.  Beef shank and bone marrow pot pie.  Fried potatoes with beef gravy and cheese curds.  Sounds nice and fatty.  I will be back.
author: Fatty A.

description: For a restaurant, it's a little better than ok. For just a fun afterwork bar it's pretty good. I came in due to their new standing on the 7x7 big eats list to try their manhattan and pickeled eggs. Walking in you really do feel like you're going into the wild west, it's cute. I'm not normally a bourbon drinker so I was looking forward to trying something different. And I'd never had any type of pickeled eggs so that was a new experience as well. Overall the combo was pretty good. the sourness of the eggs went well with the warm sweetness of the manhattan. We also had a side of some type of rabbit which wasn't bad, but i probably wouldn't order it again. And split a buttermilk dressing salad with some tasty impression of croutons mixed in. Overall we had a nice experience, service was good and I can see why they made the famous list. I'll be back.
author: Audrey V.

description: I had a horrible horrible HORRIBLE experience this weekend at Comstock and will never return. We made reservations for a large party to celebrate a special occasion. I purposely checked their menu and website to see if they had any restriction or cutting fee and was happy to see that nothing on their menu or site stating any fee would be charged. As soon as we stepped through the front door, the manager, a young Asian female approached us and tried to force us into a "deal" to be able to bring in our cupcakes! I explained to her that I didn't see anything on their website or menu that indicated there would be a fee. She told us that dependent on how much we spend, she will determine at the end of the night if a fee would be applied. I was completely shocked at her clear lack of professionalism and customer service. I approached her at the end of the night since we had drank and ate plenty to cover any kind of extra fee, she again had the audacity to say she still needed to think about it, proceeded to talk to our waiter and asked him to come around the table again and try to con more drinks and food out of our 12 people table. In the end, we decided to take our dessert elsewhere, we weren't interested in spending another penny with a business that would stoop to such low standards of service.
author: Jen P.

description: Great space, well made drinks, live music made the night. It was a good time and place to meet up with friends and share a drink. I intend to visit again and maybe venture into the dining area for a bite to eat next time.
author: Ryel O.

description: It was pretty late...and I can't recall much.  However, I do remember their homemade potato chips.  I'm such a potato slut...but really they were fantastic.  Esp. dipped in my husband's pudding.  LOL.  Wow, that sounds wrong.  What a friendly place =).
author: Jenna K.

description: great live music, great classic and classy whiskey drinks. Could use more seating.
author: Carly B.

description: We mistakenly showed up a half hour late for our reservation, and they still were able to seat 6 of us on a very busy Saturday night!  The host was super cool, and our waiter was just as accommodating.  Delicious cocktails and tasty bites.  We loved the crackers with cream cheese and pepper jelly appetizer.  Several of us had the South Side cocktail and loved it!  Great ambience--felt very "San Francisco."  Would definitely go back!
author: Haley S.

description: This place reminds me of Marlowe but better.  You come here for a loud time.  There was a really good jazz band playing.  The bar food is the quality of some restaurants.  Nice staff as well.
author: Laurence H.

description: Awesome place to grab a drink! The staff is friendly and make excellent cocktails. I love the "boot to the head" special. It's really great when they have live music playing on the 2nd floor. I highly recommend checking it out!
author: Christa B.

description: very cool place.  went there on a monday night.  place was fairly busy and lively.  they had a band playing some light music, even had a trumpet.  made for a nice old school atmosphere.  bartender was friendly, attentive and knowledgable.  he apparently had won some kind of bartending award and made me some unique drinks that were very, very good.  met some cool people here too while sitting at the bar.  will definitely come back
author: Nathan C.

description: At some point, one of the bartenders called me pussycat, while another poured shots of whiskey into tiny glasses shaped like boots, while asking me if I had eaten his donut (I had).  Friends, I have found my church.
author: Pammy C.

description: A really cool find!  We kind of stumbled on this place on accident.  We needed a restroom and decided to stop in here for a drink and the facilities.  Little did we know what a cool place it would be.  There was live music - a woman was playing the piano and singing jazz on a little second floor landing - and it was being played for the whole bar.  The service was friendly and prompt.  There were cozy booths and the bar was like an old-fashioned saloon.  Great date bar or fun place for a night out with friends.  Loved it and will definitely go back next time we are in town and stay longer.
author: Allegra G.

description: This review is for drinks only: amazing cocktails mixed by friendly, knowledgeable bartenders. Comstock has a lively atmosphere that is welcoming and fun. Great to bring out-of-town visitors who equally appreciate a fine drink. Looking forward to going when there is live music.
author: Kadie C.

description: Great live music and friendly service.
author: Vicki L.

description: I love this place! Their old timey drinks are superb, the bartenders know how to make a damn fine Old Fashioned and they look good while doing it, the decor is classic, and the food is yummy! There's never room at the bar, which is a bummer sometimes, but there's usually a cozy booth or small table in the other room. Also, they do mustache parties, which is pretty rad. Just cause.
author: K N.

description:
Swanky, old-timey feeling bar?  Check!
Appropriately old-timey-dressed staff? Check!
Live (somewhat) old-timey piano coming from an upstairs nook? Check!
Fantastic cocktails? Damn right check!
and finally... obscenely delicious food?  Uber check!

Comstock is a marvelous update of the old SF Brew Co space, adding a number of booths in the bar half, and additional tables in the front space.  The fantastic old belt-driven fan is still there, and the rest of the space has been fantastically redone in a classic style.
The cocktail list is only a single page, but offers infinite variety with the last item - "Bartender's Whimsy", an explicit excuse to try something new and different without knowing what it'll be, perhaps with a suggestion.
All of our cocktails, both listed and whimsical, were excellent.
The service was astoundingly attentive and friendly.
And the food!
The chicken-fried rabbit, rabbit toast and celery salad appetizer is even more decadent than it sounds.  The toast is a luxuriant pile of what seems to be rabbit confit atop bread toasted with no small amount of butter.  The salad, really just slices of celery with a light mustard dressing, makes for a crisp and cooling contrast.

The beef shank & bone marrow pot pie is even more rich and hearty than the rabbit - the marrow isn't identifiable as itself; it's clearly just melted into the richness of the pie.  Umami to the Nth degree.

Finally, the griddled trout with alligator pear relish & smoky corn was flawless - perfectly flaky, with great richness of flavor, only enhanced by the relish (a mix of avocado and blood-red chunks that look like beets but certainly don't taste like it), and further improved by the incredible smoky corn (sort of a succotash-like mix) which had amazing flavor.

You can't go wrong.
author: Don H.

description: Delicious traditional cocktails in an environment that will make you wonder if you left your flapper dress at the cleaners. I mean the bartenders wear arm-guarders! Careful, the drinks pack a punch. It's a welcome addition for Nob Hill where sometimes you just want to sit back, sip and speculate about the way things used to be 100 years ago in SF while feeling you're still a citizen of the 21st century. The blood and sand is a favorite of mine.
author: Jacqueline S.

description: Now this is a fun place, Interesting bar food, tasty cocktails and live music coming from heaven, actually the loft over the back of the restaurant. If I close my eyes and can easily picture myself in a old western movie hanging out and a noisy saloon in the wild west...fun, friendly,  noisy but not smokey, yeah! Great place
author: Garden Lover S.

description: Fun place to hang out for happy hour.  The place is upper scale and well preserved. The  bar tender is funny and has a nifty mustache.
author: Karla g.

description:
Drink review only. 

Best drink ever!!! Shot gun wedding is the name of the best drink I've had in my life. The bartenders are so nice I called to ask the ingredients so I could make it for an upcoming party and he told me how to make them, yay I can have a shot gun wedding anytime I want!  

P.S the service was good when we were there too!
author: Rachel T.

description:
The food here is very mediocre, and it was actually quite hard to find on my iPhone GPS. I ordered a Hamburg steak - the meat was overdone, and the complementary vegetables looked and tasted like they're a few days old. This place was also a little too small and perhaps gloomy for my taste.

I did enjoy the live music playing upstairs though - definitely one of a kind.

Colleague who was with me concurs.

Price: ~$23 after tax and tip.
author: Jack W.

description: Only 4 starts because I didn't try the food though it sounded amazing.  The bar gets a a lil cozy but the service was great and so was my drink.  I'd definitely go back for another Cherry Bounce.
author: Stephanie B.

description: The Comstock Saloon is a really nice place to grab a drink and some great food. The vintage bar and ceiling fan are really cool. The Chicken Fried Rabbit is out of this world good!  The Italian wedding soup was awesome as well. The beef shank/ bone marrow pot pie was pretty good too! I look forward to trying more things here in the future! **************The only complaint I have with the Comstock Saloon is that our Red Haired waitress was positively abysmal! She ignored us for 45 minutes before she finally stopped by our table. After that, service was sporadic at best. It was like she was intentionally trying to piss off the customers! Maybe she was just having a bad night...oh well!
author: P K.

description: New favorite. Way classier than Bourbon and Branch, excellent friendly service, and cool, speakeasy interior. Great cocktails to boot. I will be spending a lot of time here...
author: Autumn K.

description:
I went to the Comstock Saloon to try their fare in advance of planning an event for our office. Absinthe could not accommodate our group as our numbers would be more than 50. So in taking a chance I went to the Saloon to feel them up. 

I went with a friend to have a few of their offerings and discuss if the location would suffice for our use. I love what they did with the building. The ambiance is light and it appears they have removed the kitsch the "San Francisco brewing Company' had when it was here; note that while it is put up in saloon style it has an elegance of the bygone era they are trying to evoke. 

I suggest if you go here plan to spend time in the bar trying the varied drinks you'd not get elsewhere in this expert fashion. Take time to peruse the combination of foods you can savor with your drink and the company you're keeping. I really recommend bringing friends or business associates and taking your time to enjoy the all of it will be worth it. 


We started with just the corn fritters, Wow, they are delicious, they are fresh, hot, and tres yummy. Fresh pickled thin sliced jalapeños accompanied the plate. The flavor was balanced the fritter was moist to where it was almost creamy but it was light in texture, the peppers were perfection of a light pickling and sweet heat. These are a must and I wonder what else will be after a few more perusals of their fare. I followed that with the egg noodles in cream of mushroom sauce. The mushrooms were in crimini and chanterelles in a sherry cream sauce. I advise, do not share, get your own plate, be greedy. I make egg noodles, so does mom, grand mom, etc. they'd be proud to eat this stuff, and the sauce is balanced light in the weight of flavors yet delicious. I use port and morels similarly. I liked this very much. I am a wine snob so though I found they serve For De Cana rum... a favorite of mine, I accompanied this with (the company of a friend and) a delicious French pinot noir. 

I planned to give these guys a run for their money, to get my business, and I worked in the industry, set up wine tours, worked bar, planning event, and I feel they are worth a daily visit for good times and should be looked forward to visiting for a special occasion. I admit there are more quiet intimate spots to go to in this great city, yet this should be on your list for fun and good food. 

Note I came in near the end of happy hour and yes people were there in droves and happy. It seemed to be a real good time. The staff though swamped with people was accommodating and ready to serve. I will have to go back to try a few drinks now I know I will sit for a fuller spectrum of a meal and savor the company, food and time. 

I loved the staff, they are very energetic, and attentive, I like that the bar staff is reserved yet if you need to order or ask they are all business. in a busy environment this makes efficiency happen. I wish i could recall who waited our table as she was fun, put up with our flavor of humor, helped us out with everything, and got applause from us. Water glasses and other needs were attended to by every staff person who was handy and without our asking, they asked, or offered. Having been on the serving end of the industry, not all hospitality staff is conscientious, but here they seem to be. 

If you by chance happen to come in, look for me, I'm the happy chunky girl who laughs a lot and is soooo cheerful
author: Jennifer H.

description:
The steampunk movement lives on in San Francisco. I can dig it.  
The host's mustache was quite dastardly. I really dig it.
Great bar to hangout and catch up with good peoples; you really feel transported to another time here.
 We ordered small plates to go along with our drinks. The food can best be described as fancy cowboy food. The corn fritters with jalapenos was absolutely delicious; it had a bite but wasn't too overwhelming. My friend had cheese crackers and jelly; great snack if just want to chew on something. We also ordered the rabbit. I've never had it before, but sorry Thumper, you're delicious. 
For drinks, I had the Sazerac: Rye, Sugar, Peychaud's, and Absinthe. This drink had a serious kick to it - definitely a sipper, but blended really well.
Coming here means to take some time off from life and slow down - enjoy the small bites of food, sip (not down) your drink, relax, and enjoy the company and the scene.
author: Mary Ann S.

description: Great place for live music, dinner and cocktails on a Saturday night. A bit pricey, but worth it for the experience and quality of food. Decent vegetarian options
author: San D.

description:
I have had great experiences here over maybe a half  dozen times.  Interesting drinks (warning...these new school artisan cocktails take forever).  I've been seated quickly, the host greets and remembers me.  And the food was good.  Dessert is surprisingly awesome.  

I love the decor, the Old West feel, and the bow ties and curly mustaches.  With the unattended piano I feel like I am in some classic western.

And then the bad.  Several of my friends have had awful service. Not getting seated and so on.  So I docked a star and a half (I wasn't there that day).

So Comstock is possibly on the banned list.  But I am not sure.  Your luck may vary (I have had great service, and I don't look like a hipster).
author: Jame E.

description: This is an excellent place to enjoy a few drinks and bar food (although they have entrees as well).  We got the county fair plate, which had a really good pretzel and pickles.  The lamb sausage on that plate was my favorite.  The pig in a biscuit (three slider sized sandwiches per order) were good and fun.  We also got the cheddar crackers with pepper jelly and cream cheese.  A fun throwback.  The potato chips were also good, but need something for dipping.  The corn fritters were not my favorite, but that's ok, there are plenty of other things on the menu.  I look forward to going back so I can try the rest of the menu.
author: Amber B.

description: Great martini options, but the service is incredibly slow. Best to order your second drink as soon as the first one drops!
author: Sarah B.

description: Just went here for dessert but it had a fun vibe and the dessert was very good. We got there really close to midnight and they still let us order food. The waitress was very nice as well.
author: Jessica W.

description: Stopped by this place today for a drink. The place was nice. Dark old San Francisco Saloon Decor. The wine was good. The waiter was overly attentive. We kept the Menu in case we wanted to eat. The waiter came by about 4 times to take the menu and we hadn't decided yet. Then another waiter came by to take the menu? What a shortage of Menu or what? Needless to say, we  had our glass of wine then out of there. To many interruptions. I am sure its good, but hey just wanted to chill and relax.
author: Susie S.

description: I give the Comstock five stars even after recovering from their generous beverages.  Food was also outstanding. Beef & marrow pot pie was as rich as you would expect and the little corn "dodgers" were fun.
author: Eclectic E.

description: Neat spot. Their drinks were super tasty and they had a gypsy jazz band playing. Will go back.
author: Matt M.

description: Service was great, Chef was really cool and personable. Food was great drinks were unique. I really enjoyed my time here.
author: Ruben A.

description: Comstock, how I love you if you're not that pricy! I like the beef shank bone marrow pot pie. It was delicious but a hint of sweetness will enhance this food to a different level. But for almost 20 bucks, I don't know if I want to order it again as my dinner. The portion was too small and not fulfilling enough. The drink menu is extensive and I got a really nice white! Like the fact that they have live music too. This is a perfect place for friends gathering
author: Cliff T.

description: Great drinks. You can get so many different cocktails. Fun live music playing. I love the booths. Waiters are great.
author: Kristy M.

description: Comstock has an "old west" feel to the bar, meaning: a piano player working the old upright, a unique ceiling fan and a wooden "Queen Victoria"-era bar that looks like it might have come from Cody, Wyoming. Staff are attentive and friendly and the food is excellent. Had an oyster po'boy sandwich; excellent! Nice place.
author: Alden G.

description: Pot pie meh, chicken.soup blanish, smoked salmon, Yum, but still nothing special! we asked for a little sweet, the drink we got was sour. i had wine, the wine was good. pot pie is overrated...
author: Tiff W.

description: Totally classy and throwback atmosphere which I love, pretty good service, and a great cocktail menu. They do serve food although we didn't indulge. A great place to stop by for 1 or 2 drinks...or spend all night!
author: J E.

description:
I came here last Monday night to celebrate my sister's birthday after work and it was everything I was looking for!  We wound up spending THREE HOURS there and hardly noticed--the service was so considerate, the drinks were nice and strong, and the food was delicious!  Even on a slow Monday night, there was a live piano singer and I am a sucker for any live music--especially a jazzy piano and a female singer.

The venue itself is pretty small, so I can imagine that it can get crowded pretty quickly on more popular nights.  I will be interested to seeing what it would be like to come back again closer to the weekend.

My sister and I had the South Side Cocktail (yummily minty, reminds you of a mojito without lime), the Country Jam (really really really strong...at least for me!), and the Blood and Sand (I remember it being good, but I don't remember any details).

To eat, we had the chicken fried rabbit, pig in a biscuit, and the hamburg steak.  The chicken fried rabbit and rabbit toast was SO TASTY--I don't know what it was about the seasoning, or maybe it's just the fact that I love fried food--but eating that alone made me feel like the evening was a success!  The pig in a biscuit was also really good--they were three slider-like biscuits with "crispy pork" (kind of like pulled pork without the sauce mashed into a patty), coleslaw and pickles on the side.  Lastly, the hamburg steak was really juicy and I am still regretting that I could not finish my half of the steak after eating all the other food.

Here's a shout out to the awesome service which secures the fifth star of my review--I only wish that I could remember your name!  (I will blame the Country Jam for that).  The best word that applies to our server was considerate.  He seemed to know that we were out for a relaxing evening, giving us plenty of time to enjoy our drinks before ordering food, but making sure we didn't feel neglected or rushed.  Our food was also timed well so that we could have the right amount of time to enjoy our appetizers before entrees (I know--not a novel concept, but appreciate nonetheless).

Thanks Comstock Saloon!  We'll be back =)
author: Eileen H.

description:
Great cocktails, pretty decent fare. The chicken fried rabbit was probably the tastiest appetizer (and we tried almost all of them between our group). The main dishes were solid, if not the kinds of things that would blow your mind (think fancy pub fare). 
We had a large group and that caused some service struggles (I am guessing their kitchen is challenged when a big group comes in) and our two tables ended up being served at least 15 minutes apart, so some of our group ended up leaving while many of us were still eating our entrees. Very nice servers, just seemed a little strained with the big group.
All in all I'd say I would absolutely go back any day of the week for cocktails, but would likely find someplace else to eat unless I was feeling too lazy to trek around.
author: Elizabeth E.

description: Walk by this place every day on my way to work and have watched the progress.  Finally checked it out and it's a pretty cool spot.  The drinks are pretty expensive but the decor is very nice.  The prices fit the atomsphere.  I probably wont come back all that often unless they get a happy hour menu or do some kind of special.  The one benefit is they do have $3 Tecate, if you are forced to go there.
author: Chris S.

description: I came here expecting awesomeness, which I did get with the decor, however, I felt the food was disappointing.  The food options were interesting, but too expensive for the amount and quality.  Definitely not a place to come have dinner, but is a unique little place to stop by if you're strolling along Columbus for a drink or two.
author: Kim P.

description:
It's like stepping into another era. This place really hits it dead on with the old fashioned drinks, the bartenders are always dressed super classy, and their bar/stem ware is as authentic and classy as it gets.

Perfect place to stop in for a drink (or 3). We always stop in whenever we're in the city!
author: Emm P.

description: Saints Buck an a Oyster Ham Po'Boy ain't nothing dat says New Awlins like dat. I says Saints Buck an a Oyster Ham Po'Boy man dat duz da trick!
author: Rocco F.

description: I wanted to like this place, I really did. I was all excited to try it out and it was so close to where I lived. Bonus: I love speakeasies! I really liked the interior and the whole feeling of the bar. Bartenders were nice and relaxed and the place had a great vibe...but that didn't make up for the fact that they can't make an old fashioned. Really, an old fashioned?! It was as if I had ordered it at some crappy college town bar--cheap burn with sweet syrup taste (maybe they didn't use syrup, whatever it was, it didn't work). I was shocked it was so terrible and I couldn't even finish it. My friends agreed. However, one of them had a pretty good drink. I guess just defy logic and don't order something like an old fashioned.
author: Puneet S.

description: Chicken-Fried Rabbit! Beef Shank & Marrow Pot Pie! And, the off-menu pickles plus stiff drinks and an amaaazing live horn player. I was pleased. Quite pleased.
author: Dina G.

description:
This is currently one of our favorite spots in the city. It has great atmosphere between the live music and friendly staff, and the food and drinks can't be beat.

We love the picnic plate, rabbit and pot pie, but also pretty much everything else we've had to eat there, and just about every cocktail we've had has been pretty near perfect. 

Plus they do it all with largely sustainable ingredients.
author: Hana I.

description: Awesome bar love the decor / concept.  All the details down to the free lunch with purchase of booze customs of the old days.  The Bartender made us some great drinks...can't remember what they were...highly recommend for lunch or drinks!
author: Lib H.

description: Between me and my friends, I think we've tried every drink--twice.  Great old converted building with a lot of the original features still in place.  Both the bar restaurant areas are cool.  Food wise, the corn-jalapeno fritters are where it's at!  The deviled eggs are good, too.  But I wasnt too impressed by the seafood cocktail--way too much sauce and not enough seafood.  The seafood was mixed in with the sauce, so you really didnt have any control over how much sauce you had on your food.
author: brewgirl b.

description: The lapin is pretty tasty and the cocktails never disappoint. Love the vibe, music and the service is always great.
author: Kari G.

description: Not too thrilled.  The bartenders are really cheesy.  They have average prices on beer and wine, so that's ok.  Interesting menu of cocktails.  Had an appetizer of potatoes and cheese that was sort of ho-hum. The interiors are nice.  That's about it.
author: Tapedeck B.

description:
Well I'm going to give it 3 stars for now, but depending on how my next visit goes it could gain or lose a star. I had been looking forward to coming here for awhile now and decided to go on a Tuesday for some day time drinks for a friends birthday. 
We got there around 2 and there was no one there we ordered drinks and I had the south side cocktail gin, lemon, sugar, mint, seltzer. It was OK, refreshing but nothing special. Then we got some apps, corn-jalapeno fritters and Pig in a biscuit. The fritters were OK pretty standard for bar food and the pig in a biscuits were not good at all. I was expecting higher end food. 
The other thing that made this not the greatest experience was the service. The girl was very nice but so slow which I would understand if it had been 5 or 6 in the evening but it wasn't. We were the only ones there. 
I'll give this place another shot. It has a great theme and is in one of my favorite areas, North Beach. But they better step it up with their food and speed of their service.
author: Corynne O.

description:
This place is a gem. All the food was REALLY good. You can definitely tell that there is a skilled chef in the back. Every dish was awesome. I would describe it as gourmet comfort food. All the dishes were very memorable: 

Fisherman's Breakfast - trout was cooked perfectly with a really nice crisp on it which went well with the sauteed chard. 

Beef shank and bone marrow pot pie - very tasty, not overly rich but seasoned very well. 

Rum pudding - light fluffy, probably the best pudding i've ever had. 

I left this place really wanting to come back. The only reason I didn't give it five stars was because the waitress sucked. She had an attitude and didn't want to spend any time with us. She didn't come back to check on us very much and didn't crack even one smile. She didn't even want to give us any drink recommendations...she just said "look at the list". Other than that, this place is a must go.
author: Chi Y.

description: Really great cocktails, in a fun, authentic, old-timey atmosphere.
author: Andrew L.

description: I found the experience at Comstock laughable, only becasue I didnt have to pay for the meal. Had I, I would have been pissed. The kitchen lacks skill and panache. The dining room is cold. The server was annoying, and I thought the whole place to be somewhat amaturish. To top it off, horrible selection of beers. Bummer.
author: Dave S.

description: Met friends here for a quiet, early night... It was the start to a great and certainly not quiet, nor early night. Great service, fun ambiance, great little nook in the back, (but back off, we've got dibs on the nook!).  Good selection of bevies; the bartender's whimsy sounds great and frightening all at the same time.... may help to sit at the bar and have a rapport with the bartender!  The bar snacks menu is a bit lackluster.
author: Danielle R.

description: Classy little bar in North Beach. I recently discovered that there's a little stove in the back with some chairs and sofas for a cozy evening. For some reason I always end up with Fernet shots here, but I can't say if that is or isn't a good thing. They make a pretty decent corpse reviver #2 though.
author: Adam D.

description: my kind of place. came here on a recommendation from Matt at Sanctuaria. and he steered us well. solid drinks, real food, excellent service, relaxed atmosphere. i had the barkeep's whimsy and he made me a boulevardier, which i love. like a scotch negroni. husband had a blood & sand and a manhattan. the latter came with three lovely marachino cherries. the pretzel was piping hot and meltingly soft with just enough salt and grain mustard. and after too much indulgent eating out, the avocado pear toast was just what i needed - avocado mashed on toast with  grapefruit wedges. wish i lived closer so i could become a regular.
author: Courtney D.

description: Came here for dinner and a drink after work on a Friday.  Very cool bar with live music, but it was too bad we were seated in the dining room where you can't really hear or see the band.  The cocktails and food were good, and we especially like the pupping hot pretzel.  The duck pot pot was surprising not as rich as I had imagined, which I much preferred.  Woould return for a drink and nibble, but problably not for dinner again.
author: Courtney J.

description: While being on a tour for Anchor Steam brewery, they told us that this place is serving Anchor brown ale; So one night I went there with a friend of mine. He ordered the beer, which he enjoyed the most and I ordered bloody marry. It was great... the juice, the amount of vodka, and of course the olives were sooo tasty. The place was cozy and the interior design was so cool as you were thinking of being in a 1950s saloon. Each table has a small abat-jour. There was also a fire place at the corner. This is the best place to hang out. The only thing was that the waiter was a bit confused and we had to ask him twice to bring us our order and napkins. You should definitely try this place out because it's the best saloon in North Beach.
author: Zary H.

description: cool bar, mostly just came because we were waiting for a table at the house. the sliders were surprisingly good. i just drink booze straight from the bottle though, so not much to judge in that category.
author: Eric L.

description: Make a reservation. Drinks are generous. The surprise burlesque show was interesting especially for our teenager.
author: Sarita d.

description: Classic cool and full of character.  New fave drinks/snacks (or meal) place downtown/North Beach!
author: Melanie C.

description:
wow yelpers, way to overrate a place.  sorry, this place definitely isn't bad by any stretch, but certainly overhyped.

the old style saloon feel is pretty cool, but you'll wish you were also getting wild west era prices when you see your tab at the end of the nite.  

live music is awesome perched above the bar, but for the seating situation and steep drink prices, i'll head to the mission for a live band and cheaper drinks.
author: dan a.

description:
Classy, dark, and old,
Taste of Southside subtlety:
A North Beach treasure.
author: G. J.

description: This is a review -- for their bathroom.  A friend and I ran in because I had to go #1; she happened to run into a friend immediately, so she stopped to talk; I....used the facilities.  On my way out of a perfectly clean and cute experience, I marveled at how well re-done the interior was.  In with the new!  I am TOTALLY gonna get a drink here next time!
author: e w.

description:
I'm a little cocktail glass short and stout, 
here's my spirit here's my clout...

And clout this joint does have. Any watering hole built with a raised, and I mean 2nd floor balcony for musicians to spin yarns from should be taken note of. 

But before we get to that, let's start from the beginning, come to the middle, pause for a stiff one and move on to the end... 

Comstock is a fine new addition to this city's clout as mixological paradise but I think there's room for improvement. If I could I'd give them 3 1/2 stars for the drinks, there was some consistency that was lacking... for instance: the barman's whimsy found me with a remember the maine, lovely, made with carpano instead of regular vermouth, but the gin mule my girlfriend ordered was made with ginger beer instead of ginger syrup, or it could've been one of those nights when the ginger syrup lacked any punch, but that characteristic bite of eastern bliss was sadly missing from the mule. When we got around to Satan's Whiskers it was a little heavy on the OJ and my digestif, a sazerac, was heavy on the sugar and lacked that blend of bitters and alcohol to sugar that makes it a very easy drinking cocktail. I don't think the cocktails are bad by any stretch of the imagination, the menu's Saints Buck is fabulous as is the Martinez, there was just a lack of consistency. 

Now, as for the food, here's where they earn a solid four stars. Good nibbles on the appetizers, a great pot pie of beef shank and marrow, the rabbit is great, as are the pickled eggs... oh yeah, bacon, pickled eggs, rye how can you go wrong?! 

As for the music, a join that has live music every night, good solid mixology and tasty nibbles, well if I could give them a 4 1/2 I probably would as they've only been around for 3 months and I think like a wine a good cocktail joint needs aging and who knows they may get the ghosts out of the machine over time. We'll definitely be back for wine rabbit and song, oh yes...
author: Len S.

description: Well well well, not a bad thing to say about Comstock Saloon.  I was really worried when I heard that SF Brew pub was closing and that some one was going to turn it into a new bar.  Uh oh, I figured it would be some kind of a yuppie joint or a club.  Not the case.  They renovated the place with out loosing the charm.  Hats off on that one.  The drinks were artfully made (took their time even with a packed bar), the food I tried (potato fritters) where good and the staff was cordial (nice enough to converse).  Great atmosphere and crowd.  One word to the wise, take it slow with the cocktails...they creep up on ya!
author: Drew D.

description: It's a great place for drinks but the noise level is very loud to where you can't hear the people in your booth.   My boyfriend and I met another couple there and it's a very casual atmosphere.  The drinks were great, but when we decided to order Irish carbombs, the waiter replied, "we don't do those here".  So it seems that they want to preserve some type of integrity but we never got the impression that we couldn't order that or that it would be unacceptable.  Eventually, they agreed.  Service could have been a lot faster let alone the waiter's comment.  We didn't try any of their food because it was pretty late by the time we got out there.  I thinkI I will skip this place the next time I'm in SF.
author: Miko E.

description: Should you be in the market for an old fashioned watering hole, it would be hard to find a better place. The staff were lovely, and whisked me through the packed bar (it was a Friday night) to a table, even without a reservation. I had a lovely seasonal salad with dilled buttermilk dressing, a perfectly executed chocolate pecan tart, and a lemony basil cocktail whose name I can't recall...
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Went there today hoping to enjoy their jalapeño corn fritters.
They are no longer on the menu.
Boo HOO.
author: Jim T.

description: Truly fantastic drinks prepared by a truly fantastic (and truly sexy) bartender. Be still my beating heart! Swoon!
author: Matt H.

description: Fantastic Menu, unique, very well executed and Fun.  The service was out of this world and the drinks are sooo good.  This is true gem in a city that has so much of the same types of restaurants.
author: Meg G.

description: I found this spot from Urban Daddy food blog. It featured beef shank bone marrow pot pie. Thus, I booked this spot to celebrate my boyfriend's 30th birthday. My boyfriend loves bone marrow. I must say that this spot absolutely impressed me. Heard from my friend that the drinks are just as good as Bourbon & Branch. The beef shank bone marrow pot pie was super yummy. I was impressed with every dish. The decor is very old school and reminds me of the 1880s.  Just beware of small portions.
author: Helen L.

description: I liked it. I did. Drinks were good, the atmosphere was fun. There were some slow drink moments, but in general, I did like it, I enjoyed myself and I would go back!
author: Danielle V.

description: The decor and expertise are what make this place fabulous. It feels like classic San Francisco - perfect for it's location. Recently, I was there on a Saturday night and enjoyed the piano playing. If you have a question about a drink, these guys know what they're doing and are happy to educate you.
author: sally b.

description: This is my favorite place to go sit at the bar, sip some delicious drinks and share a few plates of creative food.  Watching the barkeeps craft their concoctions is inspiring and the "barkeep's whimsy" is a great way to let them show their mastery of the bar.  Plates like the chicken fried rabbit and tater boats are delicious new plays on old standbys.  The service is friendly and helpful and the atmosphere abuzz with a live band looking over the entire bar from the balcony.  Love it.
author: Alexander B.

description: became a big fan of this establishment during a visit for a friends bday bash. excellent food, great drinks, and laid back atmosphere. definite stop while in the city.
author: Chester R.

description: We went there Sunday, Father's Day.  Bought one of those coupons that was the best deal around: fried oyster cocktail appetizer, beef shank and marrow pie entree, bourbon maple pudding dessert + 2 bourbon cocktails (which they allowed me to swap for 2 glasses of wine instead, to both our relief) for $35!  The food was tasty and generous, the atmosphere was perfect for a saloon, our server was excellent in every way, giving us a bit of the history of the building, the origin of the restaurant's name and going out of his way to make our meal a wonderful one.  I highly recommend it!
author: Yvette F.

description:
Comstock Saloon was on my list of places to go for a while. So glad I made it happen.

The pig in a biscuit was unreal. The biscuits had a fantastic consistency. They didn't crumble apart when you took a bite and the slow cooked pork was melt in your mouth perfection. Also had a bite of the beef shank and bone marrow pot-pie. The meaty flavor was rich and the pie crust was buttery flakey pastry bliss.

For dessert, I had the butterscotch pudding that had a small bit of cake layered in, which was a wonderful sweet surprise.

All in all this was an amazing meal, made with the best ingredients available, in a restaurant with a warm old San Francisco ambiance.
author: Steph S.

description: Great drinks, hearty bar food, inexpensive and a really great scene. I would definitely come back.The fries with cheese and beef gravy are just amazing with a nice dark beer.
author: Shaz D.

description: The Comstock Saloon is for sure an improvement over the SF Brewing Co.  We loved the Brewing Co before, but this is a completely different kind of bar now.  The drinks were strong, seats were easy to get, and the owners were nice, happy guys.  The ambiance is a great, quiet place for a drink and friends.
author: Tiffani C.

description: I got a great vibe from this bar when i first walked by it. Drinks were impressive and excellent as I expected and the friendly service was nice as well. Overall, a great bar in North Beach to go to if you are looking for a classy night out in SF!
author: Thomas A.

description:
Went to Comstock on a Friday night around 6:30. It already was busy with a happy hour crowd. We had the foresight to make a reservation for a table in the saloon area, so we were seated right away.

The place has a great feel. Very cool old-fashioned belt driven fan system and cozy nook style booths with little wrought iron lamps. There was also a pianist who plays from up on the second level. Once it was busy, you really get the feel of a 1920's saloon where a piano-backed bar fight could erupt at any second. 

The menu was very unique and fun. Think gourmet 1920's bar food. We had crab cakes with fennel, pickled eggs on bacon, pork sliders on a biscuit with coleslaw, which were all very good. The build it yourself sliders were definitely a favourite. Also, they have a happy hour special where you can get a beer and a shot for $6. The three combos are an Anchor Steam and whisky, a Tecate and tequila or a Pilsner and Dutch gin. Each combo came with its own presentation - Tecate in a can with a lime, whisky shot in a mini boot, gin in a blue euro glass thing... Definitely just made it more fun. We also had some really good mixed drinks. 

Overall, just really good attention to detail and great service.
author: Jason M.

description: Heading up to the Saloon tonight , hoping for a better dining experience, but most interested in the jazz group playing tonight - worth a trip in the fog:) food last time was very delicious, all four of our entrées, but we had reservations and waited in the bar for 45 minutes. Oh well, the jazz was terrific while we waited.
author: Ann B.

description: I didn't try the food, but the drinks were pretty good.  I gave the barkeep two chances on the "Barkeeps Whimsy" and both times I was satisfied but not impressed.  Unfortunately the competition is pretty stiff, and with 15 Romolo just two blocks away impressive is par for the course.
author: dan d.

description: Be prepared to feel like you took a time machine back to a depression era where this was the only place to drown yourself from your troubles.  Live music at a saloon
author: Emm C.

description: Wandered into here last night after Ozumo's & the W...needed more drinks and food. Interesting atmosphere. We were a bit skeptical at first look but the food we ordered was delicious. The lillet had just the right amount of citrus squeezed into it. I was a lil intoxicated by the time I got here, but I remember all the good stuff!!
author: Lola D.

description: This was a very friendly little place and the atmosphere was great. I didn't like the food, but I'd recommend this place for some drinks and conversations.
author: Mike X.

description: The history, the food, the menu, the art, that bar-- I am in LOVE.
author: Susie B.

description: I love this place, the entire atmosphere was great and they have the BEST MOJITOS i have had thus far in my life!!!! and the bartenders and wait staff are really friendly too!!!!!
author: Elyse M.

description:
The atmosphere is fantastic, I love the period vibe. The food is delicious as well. I recommend:

-corn jalapeno fritters
-chicken-fried rabbit with rabbit toast 
-pot pie
author: Raleigh S.

description: Stumbled in here during the Chinese New Years parade by chance and realized this was the place Anthony Bourdain came to on the Layover SF episode. I was served by the owner and asked him about Bourdain n' stuff blah blah blah. ANYWAYS, I can see why he came here in the first place. It's a very trendy/hipster/divey bar all in one. They offer a ton of different drinks which you can find in a readily available menu. I've heard that their cocktails were excellent so I tried the Blood & Sand which was quite good. Despite the drinks, I absolutely fell in love with the ambiance. It's very laid back and the crowd is awesome too with a mix of locals, tourists, hipsters, businessmen, and other out of the ordinary people. But man I can not tell you how much I love this place. This has become my favorite bar of all time, in the whole world. If you are visiting SF you have to come check this place out and have a drink or two, maybe three, but guarantee it will be a good time.
author: Allen N.

description: Very handsome aesthetic. I love the vibe. The drinks and food we had were all excellent.Great bartenders!
author: m t.

description: Highly recommended. The space, the food, and the drinks were all great, and I even enjoyed the live music being played, even though that usually bugs me. I thoroughly savored my Sazerac, and snarfed down the pickled eggs on toast and spicy sausage. Really hearty, old-time tastes that hit the spot in a cold night.
author: George L.

description:
Came out on a Tuesday night b/c it was our anniversary and I've been wanting to visit the place.

It made me happy. I'm a sucker for period decor, and the cocktails, food, and service were spot on. Probably the best sazerac I've had -- just nice and mellow and round. We had the shrimp louie (yum), salad with pickled figs and mozzarella (omg extra yum) and I had the pot pie (solid, but probably I'd get the trout breakfast thing next time). 

And then funnel cake! 

Only complaint was the loud yuppies milling in the middle of the floor drowned out both our conversation and the live music, which I suspect was very good.
author: James R.

description: Great bartenders. As in, the kind that raise mixology to an art. Order a classic cocktail or talk to the bartender about improvising & either way you will be blown away. Just wish the place were twice as big or half as busy.
author: Curt S.

description: This might be one of my new favorite restaurants.  The atmosphere at Comstock is very laid back, with gigantic fan leaves hovering over head and a good old western movie type vibe.  I came here last night for a late night snack which evolved more into a meal.  I recommend the two toasts that I tried: mashed black eye pea toast with spicy cabbage and the hangtown toast which consists of pickled eggs, oyster dressing and bacon.  Now you might be wondering what the heck is this and I admit, that I was skeptical of the ingredients at first, combining a bunch of different things that I do not eat on a day to day basis.  Putting all doubt aside, I can tell you that they taste phenomenal are are priced super reasonably at  roughly $5 a plate.  I also had the pozole like soup - braised pork, hominy and chile stew with watermelon radishes and lime.  That was a meal in itself and cost just $8.  Staff was super friendly and very attentive, cocktails were strong and food was amazing.  Overall, I am a big fan - solid food for a solid price with a one of a kind atmosphere.
author: Jason M.

description:
Drinks: Martinez, Law Hill (the barkeep's whimsy with bourbon selection), Pimm's Cup 

Food: Crackers with pepper jelly, pickled eggs on rye, mushrooms and rice cakes, pulled pork thing with ham, fried oyster cocktail, and the maple bourbon pudding

Oh lord, everything was wonderful. Southern, old fashioned, and somehow like nothing I've had before. 

As previously mentioned, JB is a delightful gentleman and really the epitome of what I have always wanted in a server, friendly, a good conversationalist, and unpretentious with a twang of charm. 

The food was minimal, but perfect. Great flavors, and good vegetarian options. The cocktails were spot on, and the idea of a barkeep's whimsy is great. This is the place to really submit and let the barkeep do what he does best. 

The decor really won me over. The piano overlooking the bar for live music nights, the little sectioned off area by the fire, or glass cases with the antique bottles. 

JB said they have a great little happy hour going from 4-6 (I believe) with shots and beers for only $5 which I will be back to try, and live music coming in the future. 


Comstock, I think I'm in love.
author: Ally O.

description: the best best best best bar in the city when i've got money to burn and want to drink the best cocktails. boom. review over. nothing else needs to be said. get down with it. why are you still reading this, get over there. now. thanks.
author: mike t.

description: This place has an old fashioned speak easy style. It sort of reminds me of Bourbon & Branch. Great cocktails and delightful atmosphere. It does get very crowded at peak hours but it is worth it.
author: Laura L.

description:
Review for dinner and drinks outing:

Great place to go in North Beach if you are not a fan of bridge and tunnel.  Food was amazing: we had pig in a blanket, fisherman's breakfast (trout, hash browns, chard, easy egg), salad w fried grits and two desserts, a caramel cake pudding thing and a chocolate pecan tart.  Everything was transcendent.  Definitely up there with the top bar food/ restos in the city.  We sat in the dining room - thank god, because the bar room was sardine-style packed because it was Friday night.  Ambiance was good and liked the live band.

Why it didn't get five stars: we had a reservation for 4 people and we ended up having 6 people unexpectedly.  When we told the restaurant staff, the host was incredibly rude and said something like "that's what reservations are for in case you didn't know."  UNACCEPTABLE.  I say this having been a hostess for over 6 years.  He proceeded to act totally put out even though we were profusely apologizing and offering to go to another restaurant.  It was so bad that I couldn't enjoy the meal for the first 30 minutes and ended up going to speak with him and apologize again for the unexpected extra two guests.  If you work in a restaurant, guess what, SHIT HAPPENS and under no circumstances is that reaction acceptable.  Either apologize and say that unfortunately, you can't accommodate groups of 6 or make it happen and don't make your customers feel like shit.  Fire this host.  Server was not overly friendly either but that was fine.

Aside from that tense incident, a wonderful experience!
author: E C.

description: I would have given this place a great review if it hadn't been for an extremely rude and inappropriate waiter. We were having drinks on a Saturday night and everything was good until we got the check. My boyfriend simply asked the waiter why there was an 18% gratuity added to the bill when it was a bill for 3 people - as this is usually reserved for bigger parties. The waiter started getting rude with us because we questioned this and soon there was full on yelling and F-bombs directed at us. My boyfriend managed to remain calm throughout this experience, while still standing his ground, especially after the waiter went nuts. It wasn't even about the money for the 18% it was simply the principle of sneakily adding it on there when we weren't even a large party.  Beyond the fact that this guy as beyond rude to us, I cannot believe he started yelling at us and literally peppering in very loud F bombs throughout the conversation. I'm sure all of the people in the back room were put off by this as well since he was not even trying to be discreet.  I will never go back to this place
author: Lindsay A.

description: wow so many 4 star reviews.  i can't agree with everyone.  the drinks were eh, the food was eh, the service....eh.  if you do come here and make a reservation, make sure to request a booth in the front bar room.  the back room is silent and makes you feel like you're in a totally different restaurant...that you wish you didn't go to.  the pot pie was decent, but i can't say i will be coming back here.  ever.
author: a g.

description: Wanted to like it.  Drink was interesting (Buck something or other).  Menu oddly off-putting. But the alligator pear (avocado) toast (with grapefruit) was very good if idiosyncratic.  Entrees were fine, but only that (pot pie and an uninspired pile of greens) and a unique cornbread/mushroom thing.  The bourbon pudding dessert was extra fine.  But service, well, sucked.  I've not felt that ignored in awhile.  We sat in a mostly empty dining room (an early dinner; the bar was full); there was lots of staff focused on moving chairs and tables and setting and re-setting silverware and glassware at other, empty, tables.  But it took a long time for someone to ask if we wanted a drink.  I had to ask for a second, but not from the waitress, who had disappeared.  And I had to fill my own water glass.  Expected better on all counts.  Oh, well...maybe next time.
author: Keith J.

description:
listen we're all adults here, at least i am. that means, we should be able to eat whenever we feel like even if it is after 10:30pm.

comstock saloon is one of the few places that actually serves food past 'dinner time.' why is this so rare in san francisco? 

try the alligator pear toast which has both avocado and grapefruit on it. interesting. 

do whatever it takes to avoid the funnel cake...this will be challenging. it's nothing like what you'd get at the county fair.
author: kirti p.

description: Came here for a birthday dinner and had a great experience with both the food and customer service. They take pride in their customer service and have fun while they're at it- and it shows. Enjoyed the kennebec potato chips & dip, gnocchi, and pot pie especially. After a terrible customer experience at Father's Office in LA just days earlier, this place was certainly a breath of fresh air. It's good to be back in SF!
author: Charlie B.

description: Great place a bit light on the drinks. Food was very good enjoyed the place. Service was a bit slow had to think ahead... ordering my next drink before I was finished with my last..  but well worth going
author: R A.

description: I recently had here,  the best vodka martini ever to sit in a glass.  And appetizers.  Great atmosphere, first-class bartender, and live music.  The salad I ordered came with fried grit croutons.  Now this is a novelty.  Coming from the South, the grit thing grabbed by attention right away.  The bartender described this salad as a version of a Caesar and that's a pretty close call.  These little crispy cubes of deliciousness over purple lettuces was so good!  As was the BBQ'd shrimp, served up in... wait for it... a martini glass.  Martini's aside, this is actually a really casual place with a good vibe.  I would absolutely return.
author: Kathy B.

description: As far as bars go, this is one of the best.  The doorman and the bartender are even in character , sporting handlebar mustaches!  The glasses are a ll antique (or at least look it).  Very cool.
author: Danielle B.

description: Bartenders were friendly.  Drinks were good.  There was a pianist playing, he looked like a mad scientist, but def knew his craft.  I went around 5 so it was not crowded, if you wait longer you might miss out. Finn has man boobs.
author: Jo W.

description: Maybe 4 stars-the drinks are really good-They have resurrected drinks from the past that aren't drunk much nowadays and they really are better than the modern drinks.  So so on being a friendly bar, but the new addition of free lunch with drinks is enough to get me back
author: Peter S.

description: Bravo! The best thing to happen in North Beach for a loooong time. Classy.
author: Jeff B.

description: super fine service, perfect cocktails, great ambiance. done.
author: Molly D.

description: Really enjoyed Comstock. Great drinks and here is the kicker...they have a pepper jelly and crackers appetizer. I haven't had good pepper jelly in years, since I left Atlanta. Was really excited that they had it here. I will be going back to try more of the drinks here, soooon!
author: Matt K.

description: pretty classy and chill bar. was there on a friday night and it felt like more of a resturant atmoshphere . Really strong and good drinks. This was also rated as one of the top 25 bars in america by GQ
author: Rahul S.

description: Cool place!, went for a few drinks and desert and was pleased. The place is very laid back, made me think of what it would have been like in a bar between years 1905 and 1915....nothing flashy, nothing frilly, no bling, no etc.,.......just right.
author: francis A.

description:
Let me add my voice to the chorus of approval for Comstock Saloon.  I'm a big classic cocktails fan, and knowing that Comstock traces its lineage back to the bar staff at Absinthe, I immediately put it on my "must check out" list.  The other evening, after watching "Harry Brown" at the Embarcadero Cinema, I really needed a drink (if you saw the movie you know what I mean) and decided to walk up to the Comstock.
They've done a great job of capturing the old turn-of-the-(last) century ambiance of the building, complete with the belt-driven ceiling fans, without making it the least bit kitschy or touristy.  The bartenders definitely know their craft, and it was most enjoyable to listen to their comments to each other about various recipes for unusual cocktail order, but nothing seem to have stumped them.  I had a "South Side" cocktail, a gin drink with which I could easily fall in love.
I didn't eat, so I have no comments on the food or dining service, but I'll certainly be back to investigate that as well.
author: Tom R.

description: Having been a long time patron of the SF BrewCo, I am waiting with excited anticipation for the opening of the Comstock Saloon.  4 Stars just because the refurb looks great thus far.  (I hope they serve Budweiser - really.)
author: Michael C.
